description:
This is one of my absolute favorite places in SF and I like to bring friends here who are visiting for the first time or who have done the touristy stuff and want to see more of the actual city.

You can walk around to Land's End to see the whole expanse of GG Bridge from the ocean side, looking towards the Bay, and there are several nice trails and vantage points. You can explore the baths from above, below, and inside the cave (there's even a hope in the middle directly into the ocean). The stairs down are uneven and there's not a proper handle, so it can be tricky for those with mobility issues, since there's no ramps. The visitor center and Cliff House have info about the history, old photos, and artifacts from the height of the baths - definitely worth a look to see the former grandeur! 

Side note: Don't be dumb. People have died by going over barricades, trying to climb on rocks/ledges, or attempting swimming. The waves can be unpredictable and strong. If you fall or are swept away, you will get caught in the undertow or thrashed on the rocks. Just stay on the paths. It's not worth it.
author: Bren C.

description:
Lots of parking spots available! Just make sure you hide your valuables as a few cars parked had broken windows :( 

Get ready for a small little hike. Going down the stairs is fine, but coming up is another story... 

DO NOT bring anything that you would not want to fall in the water.. The water is really gross. Also if you try to cross the bath, you're going to have to wait for people to cross on one side. Two people cannot walk side to side unless you want someone falling into the water or the rocks. 

It's a cool place to go to, but try to go when the weather is nice (although its unpredictable)
author: Tiffany K.

description:
GRAFFITI-ED RUINS SURROUNDED BY SCENERY
[Warning: Young adults from Central Florida in for vacation] On its own, the Bath Ruins aren't much (more on that below), however, the area surrounding the ruins are great for walking among the rolling hills, the hidden beach, and all with excellent views that make you feel like you're away from the city.

FREE TO WANDER THE STONE
Free admission. A visitor center sits at the top of the hill with amenities. Those with walking disabilities won't be able to descend into the ruins area. The largest remaining structure of the Ruins is covered with some pretty cool graffiti, but most of the ruins just look like short, stone walls peeking out of the water. It was pretty fun to walk atop those stone walls. Even if your balance is terrible, it's not difficult to do, but if you fall, it'll be a 6-foot tumble. The entire structure lasted until fairly recent in history (early 1900s)- the visitor center was closed when we visited, so we had to research on our own how the Ruins looks like prior, as well as its history.

WALKING THE SURROUNDING TRAILS
Next to the Ruins is a very, short trail leading through a cave and into a decent view of the cliffs and large rocks in the rear. Similarly, other trails zig-zag around the Land's End area and lead to more sights. The entire area is very photogenic, and during our visit we saw many budding photographers and models- yes, even the Ruins themselves can provide artsy backgrounds.
author: Pyra-Danny S.

description:
Want to walk down steep paths, burn some calories climbing stairs, scare yourself into thinking you'll fall into one of the nasty pools of moldy water in the baths, explore a cave that is more like a two-minute descent into temporary darkness, draw near to the crashing waves of the ocean? Go to Sutro Baths...I don't THINK you'll regret it. I mean, it's actually really beautiful.

Note: You will most likely run into young couples who don't shy away from PDA and at times don't know how to avoid standing in the middle of a path while others try to navigate around them.
author: Christine H.

description:
There's plenty to do in SF and Sutro Baths is a nice stop. You get a nice ocean view and can explore the remains of an old pool/bathhouse. While Sutro Baths has become a bit of a tourist attraction, it's still a nice stop if you haven't been before. There's an interesting history behind it if you ever wanna look into it. In addition to the decrepit pools, there's a cave that you can enjoy for a hot second. 

If you end up at Sutro Baths then you should also make time for a quick mile or so hike to Land's End Labyrinth. There's plenty to do around here so don't feel like you have to spend hours in one location.
author: Derek T.

description:
A must see! Just Beautiful. Historical Landmark by the ocean with spectacular views. We were staying at the Grand Hyatt Union Square and did not have a car. Convenient to the bus line, its a straight cross town ride. Bring water, maybe a light jacket (it was windy) and comfortable walking shoes.

Note if you go to the Sutra Baths, you should make the time to hike some of the trails especially to the Lands End Labyrinth.
author: Melody K.

description:
When I first came to San Francisco, I would have never dreamed that something so beautiful could have existed in this city. But after living in the Bay Area for quite sometime, I've learned that the City has a ton of gems that are just waiting to be explored. The Sutro Baths and its' ruins are just one of the many San Francisco landmarks that people from all over the world come here to see.
 
It tells a story of a painful past. A struggling indoor pool infrastructure that proved to be too costly to operate. Memories of a building being engulfed in flames due to arson. And now, the ruins left behind from the whole catastrophe. All that's left behind are remnants of what used to be. Pieces of an unfinished building. Parts of the large swimming pools. It's so crazy how something that would normally be defined as an eyesore has turned out to be so incredibly beautiful. 

When I come here and I see these ruins... my heart bleeds. There's such a strong sense of history and sadness that you just can't help but to feel a certain way. And then, there are the caves down below. It feels like you're going back in time while you're walking through those caves. If you walk up the stairs towards the Coastal Trail, it will take you to a great viewpoint. The views here are just immaculate! Sweeping views of the ocean waves and the dilapidated ruins down below. It will make you feel like you're on top of the world. 

Nothing beats seeing this incredible part of US history. Pair it with the magnificent views of the California coastline and the sounds of the calming water waves, and you'll end up with some of the most precious and vivid memories in your lifetime.
author: Shayla B.

description:
This place was on our top 10 things to see while visiting San Francisco. It's free, first and foremost but better than that, at the time it was built it was the worlds largest privately owned indoor pool. The history behind it was so intriguing. You hike down some steps, then a pretty steep hill and are able to walk out on the ruins of what used to be the biggest indoor pool. They had a salt water one at the edge of the ocean before "infinity" pool ideas were even thought of which cycled in fresh salt water right there front he ocean. 

While there, we discovered a cave and also climbed up to what seemed to be an outdoor patio and actually saw whales in the distance. Just swing the ruins in person and discovering the history of the place was really cool. Definitely recommend this place. Will be visiting again.
author: Krystine S.

description:
When life becomes a little too hectic and caring for others forces you to put yourself the back burner, it's important to take a step back and to remember to do something nice for yourself. 
For me, a relaxing view, a cup of hot cocoa, and turning off my phone (but first, I make sure to take a lot of pics! Hehe) is exactly what I need. 
The Sutro Baths area is one of my favorite places, and I visit at least 2-3 times a month. I seriously fall in love all over again every time I come here (especially when the weather is nice..& during sunset!)
author: Jennifer M.

description: I was compelled to come here by all the yelp reviews and it turned to be fascinating in so many ways. Such a fun place to check out and it has so many areas you can go to and chill. Try not to fall into what I call an abandon swimming pool because it is filthy. Such beautiful views and I was able to climb over this huge rock with my fiancé and get a better look of the ocean. If you're looking for a fun and fresh breath of air kind of  an adventure then head over to this place.
author: Neloffer E.

description:
I used to come here frequently with friends back when I was in high school, 1999/2000. I vividly remember coming here the night of my first double-date. We'd just seen Mission: Impossible 2, which was da bomb! My best friend and his girlfriend were trying to have a moment inside the cave, but my date spoiled it. Definitely a learning experience! That summer he relocated to Florida to live with his stepfather.
Funny how you stop going places when you get older. Places lose their meanings. You move on in life and discover other paths through The City. That's what happened to me. I didn't forget, rather I moved on.
author: Julio B.

description: The view was beautiful!! We were lucky to get a spot for parking. As soon as we arrived someone was leaving. Bathroom is available and not the portable potty kind. It does get cold in San Francisco so make sure you bring a sweater or hoodie. There's a little cave too which looked pretty cool. The kids enjoyed it.
author: Rach S.

description:
This place is really scenic and beautiful. I see a lot of instagrammers coming here and it made me very envious. Upon arriving, it was very busy and crowded. People were everywhere, but then again I did go on a weekend, shame on me. 

I definitely see a lot of photo opportunities here, but of course, you gotta trek off the beaten path for some really good photos and there are people who monitor the place and will chase you down, which can be annoying. It's not like I'm going to sue their ass when I fall off to my untimely death, but hey... safety first kids. 

Next time, I'll make sure to come back on a week day when there are less people and less "rangers."
author: Anh L.

description: I've been to SF before, but have never visited Sutro Bath Ruins. It was a nice walk to reach them not very long at all and overlooks the cliff side. Or you can also go directly down near them. Either way it's an extraordinary sight to see and a great part of history. I would recommend it to families who love nature and kids who like to "hike" we took our little one and it was great.
author: Abigail C.

description:
"The only foreplay I really need is for a guy to kiss my hip bone. The hip is the most erotic and neglected body part. Kiss the hip bone with your lips... & I'm yours" - Karen McDougal (Playboy) 

Ok, I'm a time traveler and I'll cut to the chase and say the glorious Victorian era was a time of excess, and well excess. The upper class women, often wore a tightly laced corset over a bodice or chemisette, and paired them with a skirt adorned with numerous embroideries & trims; over layers of petticoats. Yes, excess. For the gentleman, it was all about the Norfolk jacket and tweed or woolen breeches were used for rugged outdoor sports, like croquet & shooting. Knee-length topcoats, often with contrasting velvet or fur collars, and calf-length overcoats were worn later in the year. Men's leather shoes had higher heels and a narrow toe. And yes, the male corset was as popular as a waxed mustache on a humid day. Ahh the 1890's...

So what does time traveling have to do with the Sutro Baths? I'll be your voyeur to the Victorian era when the Sutro Baths were brand spanking new. It was mainly for the upper classes as mentioned above, and as we all know by now... the wealthiest are the naughtiest class out there. Or, do you prefer the word "kinky". Whatever your preference the overdressed, excessive, too snooty crowd needed to let loose somewhere and the Sutro Baths was the place to be. C'mon unlace that leather corset, toss those knickers in the air, and let it all hangout!

Back in the day, the Sutro Baths consisted of... 
Six saltwater pools and one freshwater pool. 
The pools included seven slides, thirty swinging rings, and one springboard. The saltwater was cycled naturally from the Pacific Ocean. Private dressing rooms were available for the more prudish ladies & gents. A museum and ice rink was also part of the Sutro building. However, due to its high maintenance and overestimating the wealthy population it suffered financially for many years until finally closing many decades later. A planned demolishing never took place because the entire building was burned down. Sadly, it was arson that took the walls off of the old Sutro Baths. R.I.P.

Today, the only thing left is the foundation of a once majestic Victorian building. The ruins is a daily reminder of once excessive era. It's a popular landmark via a short hike from either the historic Cliff House or from Ocean Beach. It is no longer private and part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area and the Sutro Historic District. All in all, I'd recommend the Sutro Baths to history lovers and the casual hikers. The best part is that it's absolutely free today, so bring the kids, but note it's true ruins, so don't expect glitz or glamour. Just bring your appreciation of yesteryear and a naughty imagination. Another bonus is if you get bored the Lands End and Coastal hikes are nearby too. And no worries a tight fitted corset or bonnet no longer needed, unless you want to showoff those hips;)
author: Eric R.

description: Love, love and love....had a great hike today! never never never gets old here. We tried to avoid the most windy time early afternoon..so the hiking experience was more enjoyable.
author: Souris L.

description:
This is an ideal place to stop for a romantic getaway or simply with the family.  This place boasts amazing views, rich history and nice hiking trails.  Be sure you have some good walking shoes and time to find parking since the lot fills up quickly.  The Cliff House is nearby so don't skip this.

-Pet friendly
-Bike friendly
author: Etienne H.

description:
I really enjoy coming here whenever I am in San Francisco. The Sutro Baths are remnants of the past. 

It is a short downhill walk down to the bathhouses. All that remains of an indoor bathhouse is the foundation, along with stone walls that hold/contain water for the birds to swim in. Located on the beach, the area is very calm and serene. You can walk on top of the brick walls, on the perimeter of the water, being careful not to fall in because that water is not pretty. 

There is a cave nearby where you can hear the crashing ocean waves throughout while inside. It is cold in there, due to the ocean breeze blowing through. 

There is free parking on both the street and in the parking lot. Yes, that is correct, free parking in San Francisco - quite different than every other area of the city.
author: Max S.

description:
Sutro Baths is one of my favorite scenic places to visit when in San Francisco. The views of the ocean, Sutro Baths ruins (former indoor swimming pool, eventually burned down in a fire back in the days), and all the greenery on the right towards the Lands End trail is absolutely stunning. The scenery is even better if you can make it here on a sunny day. 

This is a great place for exploring. Walk carefully on the narrow pathways of the ruins and just soak in the views of the waves crashing. Great place for kids to come here and go nuts!

There's also a cave tunnel you can go in, which is pretty neat. 

There are lots of steps here, so get ready for your glutens to get a mini workout.

There are two free parking lots by Sutro Baths; one right by the visitor center and a smaller one across the street. There is also a parking lot near the Lands End area. 

Once you're done with Sutro Baths, you can go hiking on the Lands End trail. It's an easy somewhat of a flat hike.
author: Lin S.

description: Plenty of free parking and an easy walk! The baths have an interesting history and there are plenty of plaques around for information. The best part was exploring all the ruins around the baths and the cave tunnel!
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
I never get tired of visiting the Sutro Baths ruins and hiking trail.  I love to share my enthusiasm for this place by bringing first time visitors here to soak in: the history of a bygone time, the beautiful views (ocean and City), and the opportunity to possibly view a whale all well being free. On my last visit there were several whales breaching in the distance.  Awesome! 

There is a parking lot at the Lands End information center.  They also have a restroom in the center. But the open hours are very limited. The lot overlooks the Sutro Baths.  Plus if that lot is full, there is another lot across the street. Both lots are free but time limited. Near the main lot is an information board describing the impressive history of the Sutro Baths.  

WARNINGS: 
Please heed the warnings about observing high tide and taking caution. Be aware when going out on the rock outcrops. If you don't know when the high tides come in, obviously you shouldn't be out there.   I watched from afar as a young "teenagish" couple hiked to a far point on the rocks to take selfies and thought it was funny that they got splashed by a huge wave. But oddly enough that didn't motivate them to immediately head inland. Don't be a dope.
author: Lillian W.

description:
If you're in SF, this is the place to be. My definite number one recommendation. The views that you experience here is simply spectacular. This was the place that made my trip to SF worth it. 

Come with a friend so you can get some pictures of yourself with the view! I'd definitely recommend it!! I just can't describe how incredible this place is. The entire place is just so surreal. There's also a hiking trail that isn't too hard to get up and that gives you more height to see the entire place a little better. 

Make this place a priority when you go to SF. It will blow your mind with its beauty!
author: Frances C.

description:
Came here with friends who were visiting. This place is so fun! There are so many different trails. There is a mini cave, a secluded beach area after crossing to the southern tip of the Sutro Baths, and TONS of plant life in every corner (even in the water).

I suggest waiting until the coast gets a little sunny/less windy before heading here. Trying to balance as you are walk across thin slabs of remaining cement from the bath ruins do not sound fun. 

Parking wasn't a problem. We found free parking in a lot across the street from Louis' cafe.

I left Sutro Baths with tons of questions. Why would someone build this? When was it last maintained? There is so much history and mystery to Sutro Baths.
author: Cynthia M.

description: This spot is absolutely breathtaking when the sun is about to set and the shore is lit up! There is a parking lot and room to walk around the ruins. Definitely check it out!
author: Brennen D.

description:
Omg it was so windy here. Really beautiful place for couples though. Is it ever not windy here? I have no idea but it was soooo cold. Come prepared with a big jacket and blanket if u don't want to freeze. Bring ur camera, it's gorgeous during sunset hour. 

Bring ur iPod, headphones and find some peace here alone even. Very peaceful spot. Just really windy.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Have so many memories here.

It's very different every time I go here. The caves, the ruins, the ocean view, the cliff house and the tiny gift shop with interesting Sf fan art works & a delicious hot chocolate..!

A must go spot in the city.

Well and on another trip figured out the rock stack lonely beach that's out of the world and pretty amazing for photo shoots. Especially in early mornings.
author: Deebs M.

description:
Sutro Baths is a very cool San Francisco location. No, no, it is no longer an actual public bath. If you want to see what it looked like in days gone past, you can look it up online to see some great photos. But, long ago that era was lost. Since then, all it has become is place that is in the mode of continual deterioration and reclamation by the sea. But, that it is not a bad thing! Visually, it is very cool!

I have watched this location deteriorate for decades and it is always an amazing sight. There are birds that live in the remaining pools and the colorful graffiti on the walls is in an ever-changing state of presentation. 

To get here, you simply follow Geary St. to its end. When you see the ocean, look to your right, and there you are. 

There is street parking, when available. There is also a large lot above the Sutro Baths and one across the street. Note: If you come here midday on a weekend, all of the parking spaces may be filled. Keep that in mind. But, at other times, parking is usually not too much of a problem.

Mostly, this is a great space to think about what it must have been like in times gone past and to get a great, closeup view of the ocean. It is also a nice little hike up and down the hill, so you will get a bit of a workout if you visit this location. 

This is one of the must see location in San Francisco.
author: Scott S.

description:
Coolest urban exploration I've visited yet in SF. Came here on a Thursday afternoon and was able to park at the Lands End parking lot. It's definitely a beautiful sight when you walk down the stair and look at the ruins overlooking the ocean. It's a beautiful sight. You can walk along the stone walls around the mossy water where the pool use to be. 

If you venture right of the bath, there is a small cave you can walk through. It's a very short walk probably about 100 ft and it's fence off at the end. If you walk to Point lobos, which is right above the cave you can get a great view of the bath and the Pacific ocean. There's a trail at the top that connects to the Lands End trail and will take you all around the park. This is a pretty landmark that everyone should come to visit. Definitely a place I would visit again especially after learning it connects to a bunch of different hiking trails.

PARKING: Free if you can grab a spot in the Lands End parking lot or you can just park on the street
author: Andrew T.

description:
Weather it's a quick stop for a photo op at sunset or hours to explore the area , Sutro Baths in the Lands End area is one of my favorite places to visit in San Francisco! 

Literally the ruins of a historic bath house built in 1896 by the edge of the ocean, its really quite an experience to walk among the remains of brick and mortar .  A few easy steps down the sandy stairs will place you smack dap in the center of the bygone days.  There is a cool little cave next to the ruins and  you'll also get beautiful views the Seal Rocks out in the ocean ! 

Getting here is not a stressful ordeal and parking is not so bad either . The have free parking lots  and parking along the road . It can be crowded during peak hours , but somehow we always end up finding parking nearby without too much of a search. 

A trip to San Francisco is just not complete without a visit to the Sutro Baths! Breath in the fresh salty air, take in the spectacular scene, relish the moment, and be thankful for your pretty amazing life!   

I left my heart in San Francisco... near Sutro Baths at Lands End !
author: Brenda B.

description:
This place is the ruins of really old swimming pools. I used to think people took baths here because it's called baths, maybe. So apparently someone set it on fire. Now some walls and stairs and passageways are still here. Very beautiful.

So there are 3 different kinds of landscapes here. On the left is the beach. On the middle are the ruins of the baths which have cool moss and cool little lily pad things. You can climb up into the ruin that still has walls and windows. There are spiderwebs in there. You can walk through the narrow concrete paths and try not to fall. On the right there are these beautiful trees on the higher altitude which are all misshapen and bent by the wind. There is a very cool big rock between the beach and ruins that you can climb up onto and sit on it and see a beautiful view. There are these very beautiful green mossy rocks between the beach and the ruins. 

Parking is hard on the weekends but very easy on weekdays because this is a touristy place.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Easily one of my favorite places in SF. My college roommate took me here for the first time in 2013 and luckily I got a chance to visit it a second time a few weeks ago. 

It's a ruin but it's so beautiful. And it's so cool because you can walk along the sides, just be sure not to fall into the water because it's dirty and gross haha. We came on a Sunday morning so it was still cloudy and super windy, which made it pretty scary and I had to walk very very slowly. 

It has its own parking lot and another small lot across the road. There's also some street parking along the hill by the visitor center and another lot at the very top. 

You can make you way down to the beach too, which is really nice. There's a huge cliff/rock that you climb on top of and get some awesome pictures. Oh and the area towards the right near the fencing has an opening that leads to a cave where you can hear the waves crashing. The whole place in general is just a pretty cool spot to explore. Apparently, it used to be a swimming pool complex in the 1800s that burned down. 

Lands End labyrinth is around the area too so be sure to check it out if you have the time!!!
author: Abigail V.

description:
What's not to love?  This place is gorgeous.  There will be a lot of people- unless you come at some very odd time.  Midday there were at least 100 people scattered around the baths or walking through the caves- one group was very large (maybe 35?)  I assume it was an organized tour.  Review some pictures of how the baths looked in their heyday before you go- although the bar on the hill above the baths has a nice picture of the baths.  The ruins are lovely and rather sad- I wish they were still here.  The baths looked amazing!  Up above the baths is the Cliff House- wonderful place for a drink (eat somewhere else) and the Camera Obscura is also on the cliffs above the baths- right below Cliff House.

We walked here from the Legion of Honor- so parking was not an issue for us, but we noticed all the parking spots were taken.
author: Alex M.

description:
Great vistas, worth checking out.  Has a really interesting history and a great place to take some breathtaking photos, especially of Golden Gate.

If you'd like to imagine what it was like, check out some film clips taken by Thomas Edison in 1897:

https://www.loc.gov/item/00694314/
https://www.loc.gov/item/00694313/
author: Dana D.

description: I love actually walking through history. Its hard for me to imagine what this place must have been like a hundred years ago, but I see it being as grand as the titanic before its sinking, and consider the way it looks now to being equal to how the titanic looks while sunk on the ocean floor. When you research the sutro baths and the engineer/proprietor behind it everything seems very fascinating. To think about the technology they were using at that time, and how they made this possible using the water in the sea is just amazing to me. Wish i could find a documentary on it.
author: Parker B.

description:
Highly recommend for families, out of town guests, dates, and of course by yourself!

Parking: not big but the turnover rate is very high. Just follow the people who are walking towards their cars. We didn't have to wait at all on a Saturday afternoon in the summer.

The walk/hike: from the left you can find the visitor center(worth a look) and a shaky loose sand hike down to the ruins, from the right you will have nice stairs to descend from. We took the right side down and the left side up, both very fun! It's super short(5 min-10 mins). It's perfect for people who are weak/out of shape, though not wheelchair accessible. 

Scenery: beautiful view of the ocean, beach, ruins and cave. The are also cool trees, shrubbery, and flowers along the way. After you get down to the beach, don't forget to get your toes wet! 

Tips:
1. Bring a bottle of water(for drinking and washing sand off of your feet and a towel for drying yourself/pet. 
2. Do bring your pet. Our 2 year old corgi has never been more excited about a hike/walk as he has on this trip. The ruins are by no means maintained for walking but he really enjoyed climbing the terrain.
author: Tata X.

description:
Not much to say to add to add to the truly excellent and lengthy reviews below, but certainly recommend this place to anyone interested in history and beautiful views.  We rented electric bikes (amazing way to see SF!!) and zipped up the hill to take in the vista.

If you are with someone whose knees can't hang for the hike down, you can get a great view from up at the restaurant overlooking the baths.
author: Erin E.

description:
A great hike. Loved it. Great views! 
It can get crowded with the tourist bus. 
Overall it's pretty nice we took our little one.
author: Ami S.

description: I love to photograph that location, I have many photography clients who ask that location and I'm always happy to use it because of the special feel of the place and the big variety of looks and scenes the location has to offer.
author: Eli Z.

description: Amazing views! Lots of steps upon steps.  The view is amazing on a clear day. wear flat comfortable walking shoes, and dress warmly as there may be a chilly breeze by the ocean. There's plenty of parking around so keep looking, but be aware, you'll be walking so come here when you have time. Great place to bring out of town visitors as theres plenty of photo ops here. you can see golden gate bridge and then after, go to the cafe and get some happy hour.
author: Evangeline F.

description:
Once the largest indoor swimming establishment in the world, Sutro Baths is now an eerie, scenic ruin with pools of salt water and crumbling walls. I find the history so interesting--definitely read up on it. It is such a lovely place to view and hang out for a bit. I went here with a friend and my sister during our visit to San Francisco last week, and we spent a significant amount of time there taking in the views and taking photos (photos do not do the view justice though). 

There are narrow paths you can walk around Sutro Baths, but be sure to focus and pay attention to where you're going and watch out for the uneven concrete paths/rocks/holes between the paths. 

It's a great workout up and down the hills and steps--my legs and glutes sure thanked me. Lands End Labyrinth is also nearby so you can hike to it and take in more beautiful views.
author: Sylvia J.

description: Sutro Baths is a nice stop. You get a nice ocean view and can explore the remains of an old pool/bathhouse. And walk through a cave.
author: Anne W.

description:
Beautiful! 
If you want to take the mini hike down to the water, make sure to bring a pair of closed toe shoes you don't mind getting dirty, it can be quite muddy/sandy/wet.

The views from above are great, but if you plan to walk the border of the baths, its not young kid friendly, you are literally walking on a 1 foot wide border between a small body of water and a long enough fall. I brought my 6 year old and he was able to safely make it down the bumpy hills but needed assistance at times, I wouldn't recommend for anyone younger, admire from the top instead. 

There is a cool cave that you can watch the dark waves crash against the rocks also.

You must visit Sutro Bath at least once, then you will be hooked!
author: Danielle P.

description:
I really didn't know what all the hype was about regarding this place but for some reason my wife wanted to make it out here.  

I was glad we made it before sunset.

There were tons of people, so be patient if you're trying to capture that one perfect picture where nobody else but your subject is in frame.

This is a historic place that reminds me of Egyptian type ruins that you see on the National Geographic Channel or even History Channel.

You won't want to take a dip or bath here as the water looks quite murky.  Not even a bar of Irish Spring will help you. 

Remember to wear comfortable shoes, sunglasses and pack a jacket, plus your best digital camera.  You can thank me later. 

Ladies, don't wear heels or stilettos. You won't make it very far.
author: Arnel D.

description:
Can I say that it's so weird that this place has a yelp. 

Anyways, the Sutro Baths are super super pretty. It feels historic, calm, and so much more as you walk around the forgotten bath house. It's crazy. It feels like there's a really cool fantasy story that happened. The water is dark and mysterious and it's actually pretty easy to fall in. 

I realized that some things can not be described through words and pictures. This place left my sister and I in awe and it felt like there were so many nooks and crannies that needed to be discovered. 

It's a great place to enjoy nature, the ocean, and see how the earth takes back the landscape. 

Anyways, the people leaving their trash here really need to think twice about their life choices and clean up after themselves. You're not cool, that's pretty disrespectful and you're ruining a lot for the rest of us.
author: Rae A.

description:
TIP: Sutro Baths & Land's End are located right next to each other! As in literally walking distance, so you can cross both off your list with accessible street parking in a seemingly safe, residential area.

It was such an enjoyable experience to explore the historic remnants of what "once was." I believe the name conveys in a literal sense, meaning that this place used to be an indoor aquatic center. The overall contrast of the remains with the vast ocean means BEAUTIFUL photos - straying far from the average beach ones. Don't forget to climb random stairs, explore caves filled with graffiti and breathe in the fresh air! Definitely a noteworthy sightseeing location.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Pros: amazing scenery, fun hike, good amount of parking spots
Cons: not ENOUGH parking haha

I went here on a very nice Sunday around noon, and I got very lucky finding parking. I took the hike to Lands End it was a well 2-3 hours well spent. Although it was fairly hot in SF that day, there was a lot of shade due to the trees along the paths. It is great that the trail is dog friendly. I would recommend keeping your dog on the leash due to the cliffs.
author: Jason F.

description: Nice landmark site seeing area. Good for families and groups. Would recommend. I bit hard for people with knee, leg, hip etc. injuries as you need to go down a lot of stairs and the path once you're by the paths isn't 100% flat.
author: Zoe M.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco, maybe the world, combining the baths with Ocean Beach and Lands End. Such a unique place and full of history. It is a great place to get some fresh air and exercise and explore.
author: Lisa H.

description: It's beautiful here. Not a ton to do, but worth exploring throughout, in combination with a visit to Ocean Beach.
author: Carl B.

description: Landmark area with some nice views! Fun to wander around if you are walking along ocean beach.
author: Sean R.

description: I came here with a friend who was visiting from out of town about a month ago. It was a really great hike with tons of picture opportunities. I definitely recommend bringing a jacket, as it can get windy and cold.
author: Merisenda A.

description: Beautiful historical park. It was built in the 1896 and was destroyed by fire. What's left are concrete. There's tons of beautiful views. Good area to walk your dogs too.
author: Ly L.

description: Such a beautiful scenery in this historical sight to see. The weather was actually perfect and it was such a wonderlust. A perfect place to take professional pictures as well. I saw many couples taking pictures. I recommend this place for people who are intrigued in nature and some hiking and exploring.
author: Adriana P.

description: This was the first place I found out when I was super new in USA. I had migrated here and was living in East bay. I remember I got my licence and few days later when I got my first car, i decided to drive to San Francisco with my big map. ( there was no GPS system at that time ) being from an island I looked for a beach and saw ocean beach on the map. I remember we reached there by asking so many people on the way on how to reach. Finally made it and it was such a beautiful sight. Oh boy ... we hiked to the cave, the sound inside was kinda scary. It's an amazing place and one of my favourite spots.
author: Pritika M.

description: I have had Sutro Baths and Land's End on my SF list for a while now and finally made the attempt to check it out. I wish I knew how close everything was at the time but only discovered how close on the last day of my visit. Learning about the history of this place was pretty interesting. I wish I remembered to check out the labrynth (sp?) while visiting. If I had more time I would've taken a walk down to the baths to get a closer look. It was already a gorgeous view from the Cliffs. Just remember while in SF, carry your water canister everywhere you go. Every walk is just about a steep hill.
author: Pam M.

description:
Sutro Baths. What an amazing place and sight to see in SF. 

I always love coming here and bringing new people here. I would suggest this place as a "Must See" in SF.

What's great is that they have plenty of parking in the parking lot.

Sutro Baths is also close in proximity to Land's End where you can find the Labyrinth Landmark as well. Another great sight to see.

Dress appropriately. Wear comfortable shoes. Bring a light jacket.

As you go down the stairs to the baths, there is a cave you can go in on the far right. Then on your left are the baths and you can walk on that.

You can also go on a nature walk hike back to the parking lot. It is very green and has lots of trees.

There's so many trails and pit stops along the hike you can stop at and take in the gorgeous views of the water and even the bridge!

It's definitely a great photography spot. So many options and abandoned buildings. It's just truly beautiful. I get amazed every time I come here.

Oh yeah, since the Pokemon Go craze is happening. This is a great spot to find Pokemon hahaha

Definitely recommend this place! Try coming for a sunrise or sunset as well. That's always an awesome view.
author: Jasmine N.

description: This is such a beautiful place and it was my last stop before leaving San Fran! But it was so worth it and it's just breathtaking!
author: Ashley P.

description:
Sutro Baths is located within Lands End. I didn't know exactly what I was looking at, but the concrete ruins used to be open to the public as the world's largest indoor swimming pool establishment. There were six saltwater pools and one freshwater pool at various temperatures that could accommodate 10,000 people at one time. Facilities included a museum, amphitheater, and ice skating rink. It burned down in June 1966.

There is a small cave and I enjoyed listening to the crashing waves. After Sutro Baths, enjoy the rest of Lands End.
author: Helen H.

description:
Sutro Baths is a hidden tourist spot that many actually do not know about.  But I have a a funny story for you.  I have this awesome guy-friend who told me one of the most embarrassing stories of his life.  He said he was on a tourist bus with his family and they stopped at the sutro baths.  When parking you have to hike down to the location of where the baths once were located.  Currently only the remains are left.  So he told me he was goofing around and accidentally fell into the muddy water before a very nice dinner.  There were actually many tourists around that started snapping pictures.  That story made me laugh so hard that I just had to see the baths again in person to see where he fell.  Let me tell you, that fall would have been very scary and cold!  Brrr.... 

When you visit the baths, bundle up as it much be very chilly.  Watch your steps and make sure to go through the cave and see the waves crash against the rocks.  Its absolutely beautiful.
author: Mercedes M.

description:
Wow. Breathtakingly serene, at least for me. If it were pouring rain the day I came here, it would've been absolute perfection! I'd imagine for most, it's the opposite. So the day I went, it was perfect for the rest of you normal folks *insert laughing emoji*

So, the story is simply that this used to be a public bath house in the late 19th century. It opened in 1896 as the world's largest swimming pool establishment. It was burned down due to arson while in the middle of being demolished so what's left are the ruins, per Wikipedia ;p 

After parking your car in the free lot, yes free (yippee~) go down the stairs and at the bottom there's a hidden cave to the right! I love exploring random places and things in general so this was an awesome surprise. I would've loved to hike and have a picnic, but due to time constraints I wasn't able to... There's always next time, right friend?! ;)
author: Grace C.

description: Ah I can't help it this is my favorite place!! Went again and blown away by the peace and beauty and uniqueness of this area and literally blown away by wind (pun very much intended!). Read my past review for more information. It's superb. Makes me want to learn French to say a fancy French word to describe this place! As always recommend exploring the caves and bringing a sweater
author: Sarah M.

description:
i SEA you!!!!

Tucked away next to Land's End Trails and right on Ocean Beach is Sutra Bath's.

A small walk down some stairs and your right next to outdoor pools that were used by the public in the 40's. It's a interesting walk into the past.
Pools are surrounded by beautiful pink wild flowers and other beach fauna.

Very reminiscent of a place we have back home in Hawaii, the Duke Kahanamoku pools, that were used for the Olympics back in the day, day.
author: Laurie V.

description:
One of my favorite spots in SF....possibly one of my favorite spots ever. 
Love the way the ruins look with the ocean as a background. 
For a minute, you forget you're in a big city. 
Must see.
author: Claudia Z.

description:
[Out-of-Towner Review]

I'm not sure what the lure of this place is...

Because you cannot bathe in the baths! Anywho, the view, the adventure, the everything -- is why I've always wanted to see what the SB's were all about.

Even though we came on a dreary, slightly drizzling February day -- we still made the best of it. As you pass the Clif house, its glitz and glam, then right by the Look out, you can turn in and park. I didn't realize the Lands' End trail was also nestled right near the SB's too. So it makes it a very convenient sight seeing location and also a place to get active -- walking or running!

You make your way down 135 steps (yes, I counted), then down a slightly steep decline down to the actual baths. There is nothing about this area or things that suggest you should walk on them or explore, BUT everyone does! It's totally fine, just don't think about what would happen if you fell.

I'm sure on a really nice day the view is even better. But I still reveled in the dreary day. The ocean splashing against the rocks, the light rain hitting the water in the baths, and the overall serenity of the area.

There is a small little cave, but at the end of it, it was blocked off -- no clue why, assuming for the safety of everyone. And to note that there was no where to go, other than climb on rocks.

I think this is a great place to go adventuring. It's free, its fun, and there is even some history posted so you can learn about the geographical history of this area. 

There is a sign saying that cars get broken into all the time, so be smart!

Perfect adventuring for a local or an out-of-towner!
author: Steph G.

description: Great spot for photography. There's so many areas to get a variety of shots. Great view for a sunset shot but most of the time it will probably be foggy. Parking isn't too bad either.
author: Jessica D.

description:
A long time ago, I saw a beautiful Instagram post of someone at Sutro Baths and that was all I needed to make me want to come here! So finally after a few years, I made the trip up to SF and got to see this place in person! 

There is a huge parking lot that has a decent amount of spots for both cars and motorcycles. My friend and I first walked around Land's End and took a little walk to see a closer view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Labyrinth as well. Then we walked over to Sutro Baths to watch the sunset. The whole area is so breathtaking. We got lucky and went on a really clear day, so when we looked out, we saw the horizon and a beautiful sunset. There's a cute little cave that you can walk through and see a different view of more rocks and the cliff, however it was too wet to walk over, and apparently there was a drunk man laying on the rocks on the other side!

It's a gorgeous place to catch the sunset and just admire the beauty that is Mother Nature!!
author: Jayleen Y.

description:
These ruins are where the Sutro Baths used to be. You can walk down the hill to get a better view of them next to the ocean. Be careful of your footing and don't walk out beyond the barriers as you could fall and get injured. 

There is a cave that you can walk into that extends for about 40-50 yards to an opening on the other end. Inside of the cave you can see ocean waves below the cave. This is a safe excursion and usually several other people are in the cave. I am not sure if they close this at night. During daylight it is safe. 

Good photo ops here and it's free.
author: Mike M.

description: Hands down one of my favorite landmarks in San Francisco. There are breaktaking views of the ocean, with tons of hiking trails, views of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge, cliffs, trees... if you need a break from the city, come out here and get your dose of nature while still being in close proximity.
author: Ross S.

description: I love Sutrobath. When I came here for the first time, I felt like it looked magical like something that I haven't seen so far. It's nice w stairs and a pretty view that you can see. They also have Hiking trail nearby if you decided to be more adventurous!
author: Phuong N.

description:
This place is beautiful, definitely must see when going to San Francisco.

I prefer scenarios that include mountains and beaches vs the city. 

Parking: There's a private parking lot, but it tends to get full quick when sun is setting. It's also free!

I suggest going when the sun is setting. You have to walk down quite a bit of stairs and then you'll get yourself to an area where you have to be really careful or you'll fall in the water? or whatever it's called. You can also go to the cave area that is a little scary but pretty.
author: Jenny L.

description: Like ancient Greek ruins if you came upon them only a hundred years after they had been abandoned when the technology and stories weren't too far removed yet to feel the ghosts there still. It's just ruins with sweeping view of the ocean. I was lucky enough to be there with a friend who is a storyteller and historian so I had an experience I wish everyone could have of learning about the rollercoaster that used to careen around this rock face, the aquarium, the tide pools, the trains, and the fire that took the baths out just in time for the developers to cash in on the insurance. There is a little gift shop and historical center that gives you a window into the period. Best of all there is a beautiful hike up into battered windswept trees making churchlike domes of quiet as you climb the hill away from the rubble, and the exposed foundations below.
author: Risa D.

description: We didn't have time to walk the entire Lands End area so we just walked down the stairs/pathway to Sutro Baths.  Although it is pretty run down, especially considering it's a National Park, it was an interesting place to explore! The kids loved tiptoeing across the ruins to the sandy beach.  It is quite the incline heading back up to the parking lot so be prepared to take a few breather breaks.
author: Melissa P.

description:
Coming here wowed me away. It was cool, seeing how this place used to be a bathhouse. Now it's filled with water and algae. When I was walking around the bathhouse, I was scared I might trip and fall in. So do be careful of your step, because you don't want to land in that gross water!

There's a lot of parking, but you just have to look out for open spots. Also, there's a cave nearby, and a rocky area where you can see the waves better. Technically, you're not supoose to hop the chain, but I saw people doing it. My boyfriend pushed me to climb over, but I wasn't feeling it. Heck, I could see the waves fine behind the chain. Why did I need to climb over and risk my safety?

If you get tired of the baths, there's always the beach right by. I recommend bringing a sweater because it gets chilly and windy.

My boyfriend and I sat down on a part of the section of the baths. It was relaxing, with the sound of the waves crashing. When we were done, we busted our butt up the stairs, which was a workout.
author: Pretty D.

description:
The more I visit, the more magical this place becomes.  Just to imagine what this place used to be blows my mind.  It's fascinating.  Google pictures!  Do some research before you visit so you understand what you're looking at.  

When visiting- wear good shoes.  It's rocky, sandy, and the ground is uneven.  But it's a great place to explore.  Don't miss the cave, the lookout, walking the cement outline of what used to be a huge bath house.  This place has come a long way from when we used to visit.  The trails are updated, there is better signage, parking has improved a ton, and the gift shop is amazing.  Some seriously great finds in there.
author: Sheryce S.

description: Nice short hike to amazing views and a nice looking cave... great picturesque place. Be ready to go down quite a few stairs to get there. In love with this place.
author: Arlette B.

description: Definitely a must see! It's very to get access to the Sutro Baths, there are several along the trail or by the gift shop by Cliff House. I absolutely love the Baths. You get a great view of the ocean and it's just so much fun exploring around the Baths! There's also a small cave on the far right of the Baths where you can see the rocks!
author: Cathy M.

description:
You'll see the Sutro Baths right as you start the Land End's trail. You can walk down and walk into some caves (as long as the tide is low) and peek out to see the waves hitting the rocks. When the tide is lower, there's more beach but if not, you're restricted to a smaller portion of the area! 

The Sutro Baths are apparently ruins from an 1800s bathhouse that eventually burned down in the 60's. You can still see the outline of the building and parts of the building that stick out. 

Overall, with the right amount of fog and cloud, you can get a pretty amazing photo.
author: Daisy K.

description: I came here for a weekend trip and this was def cool place to explore. Upon arriving you can feel the ocean breeze because it's literally next to the ocean. You can hike down to this area where you can see an outline or foundation of once was a building or some sort. People often walk on it and climb on it. Within the foundation there are pockets of water which is kinda neat. Just don't fall in! When you walk back up there is a tunnel that leads you to the other side. Cool place to take pictures. Lots of people walking their dogs.
author: Sally L.

description:
Building a public pool at the Ocean's footsteps is a fantastic idea. Until you run out of business. Decade over decade, the nature takes back what used be theirs, and leaves you with the ruins of what once was a public bath, a century later. 

Now, it's one of those magical places only San Francisco can offer. The powerful Pacific Ocean craved out caves, and the water makes its way through the rock formations. Peaceful on a calm day, and mystic on a foggy morning.

Great for exploring and starting your coastal hike along the trail towards Land's End. 

Breathtaking!
author: Sebastian F.

description:
What an amazing place to stop by at! Parking is pretty easy to find because you have the parking lot, street parking, and also a parking lot across the street. This place is located far from the Bart, so driving is your best option! This place can get very chill, so please dress warm!!

The sutro bath was an ancient bathhouse in the early 1900s, but was burned down in 1966. You can still see the various pools, but watch your step because it is very easy to fall in.  Theres also some bunkers and cave that you should definitely check out! 

This is definitely a place for tourist to check out!
author: Jennie Q.

description:
This is one of those places that I think to myself, "if Heaven is real, I want this to be it".

I found out about this place via Twitter or all places, I saw some photos and knew the next time I was in the area that I had to go. And thank God I did.

Honestly, words really don't describe it. It's really just breathtaking. He cool air hits you as you're standing on one of the rocks looking out into this enormous body of water. It's one of those places, for me at least, where you can put your entire life into perspective in minutes.

Note: don't be a dummy like me and wear anything else but sneakers- the rocks can be slippery and there are plenty of hills, this is San Francisco after all. And be careful because I don't want you falling off of a rock or ledge and into the water.

I read somewhere in a review that this is a great date place and I couldn't agree more.

Bring your camera! I know that's a duh comment anymore but seriously, you'll want to snap some photos.

There is a cafe and restroom at the upper portion so you're not totally isolated from society when you're there. 

Hike as long as you can to enjoy as much of the area as you can get in. This is one of those great tourist places that you don't realize about SF. There is so much more to the city than urban sprawl. Next time I'm in the area, I am coming back for sure. No matter what the Uber cost is.
author: Andy V.

description: Pretty amazing. I wish I could have seen it at the turn of the century in its hey day.
author: melisa w.

description: I found the beautiful picture from IG. It is such a nice place. So we decided to have our picture taken here. It was very windy and chilly. With all the natural ocean sounds and the relaxing view, it removed all my stress away. We will definitely come back and stay a little longer.?
author: Karmen S.

description:
This place is truly an amazing landmark. In the heights are steady, but aggressive enough to reach your heart rate and make you smile. 

There are also a couple of cafes in case you get there see or feel like a snack. And it's filled with people, as well as a rich history. Definitely worth the visit
author: Dave K.

description: Great place for viewing the sunset. Can get a bit chilly, so bring  a jacket or something. Parking can be found along the slope to cliff house.
author: Kavi T.

description: So beautiful! Hidden gems in San Francisco. Overlooks the beautiful ocean and best part is that it's free! Great little tourisy spot to see when you're visiting SF or if you live in SF and have a friend visiting. Probably not a spot to go to more than once or twice but well worth the visit.
author: Vivian N.

description:
My new found fascination with finding abandoned places has led my best friend and me to the Sutro Baths. Instead of being located on some desolate road in the middle of nowhere, the Sutro Baths is located right on the coast in San Francisco, so you can enjoy the beach as well as explore some ruins. 

To get to the actual ruins you have to climb down a massive set of wooden stairs, perfect for those looking to get some cardio on your visit. Even if you don't make it down to the ruins themselves, there is a splendid view of them from the top of the staircase. 

Before heading all the way down into the ruins I would recommend checking out the upper level first. You get an amazing view of the ocean, a snippet of the Golden Gate Bridge, and another perspective on the ruins below. From this little balcony on the side you can also see the ocean in all its glory, and watch as wave after wave crashes into rocks below. 

Below the balcony is a short cave. Inside the cave is another view of the crashing waves, and at the end yet another.

The ruins of the bathhouse are definitely a sight. You can just visualize what the place used to look like. Everything is all tagged up, but it doesn't take away from how remarkable the place is. I was a little surprised to find parents letting their toddlers climb across the ruins because there is water surrounding everything. 

There is a parking lot for this place; however, you can also park on the street if you can find a spot. One of the best parts about this place is that there is very little to no traffic. 

I would recommend checking this place out if you're looking for something new to see in the city.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
This is an amazing place to visit - I'd never heard of it, but was totally worth going out to the west coast of San Fran to see. You can get the bus here but it might be easier just getting a taxi/uber as you might get dropped off at the wrong spot, like we did. 

The baths are beautiful and there's a tourist information centre/shop which is worth a look. There's also a cafe, and public toilets, as well as the Cliff House restaurant and an easy-ish walk around to see the Golden Gate Bridge. 

A really nice area to spend an afternoon - highly recommended.
author: Briony C.

description:
This place is historic. A little sad to see what this place used to look like. Close to the Cliff House, and next to Ocean Beach this place is beautiful nonetheless and a must see if you're in SF and haven't been here before. Pair this with a hike through Land's End and you have an awesome weekend afternoon. These are ruins right on the oceans edge and there are signs warning of people getting swept off and out to sea. Go visit this beautiful place at sunset or a clear sunny day not good to go when it is foggy because you can't really get a good view.

It's a truly spectacular place to take photos and enjoy the view of both the Golden Gate Bridge and the Endless Pacific ocean. Sutro Baths are a must see if you like urban exploring. It's part of San Francisco's history and you could see the ruins. Surrounding area is great for Easy hiking, running , jogging and just walking. If you keep walking you will eventually find yourself walking through a cave. Hear the ocean waves crash and you might even get a little wet.
author: Maria M.

description:
I would totally swim here if it was clean haha (it was a swimming center back then)
Around 1896, Sutro was considered to be the world's largest indoor swimming pool.
This was on our list when we visited SF.
We parked along Ocean Beach, passed by the Cliff House restaurant and basically hiked down to get to the sutro baths.
Besides the smell, it was fun exploring the ruins and its caves.
You don't have to hike to check this place out; although there is a hiking trail near it.
Perfect of all ages, and great for pic opportunities!
author: Laramae E.

description:
Sooooo glad I finally got to explore around here! :D

I came with a group of friends over Memorial Day Weekend and it was a bit foggy and the weather seemed to be at the cusp of raining. I made the mistake of wearing a very thin shirt under just one hoodie. I was freezing! So wear layers! Good thing I warmed up after walking a bit though.

We parked in the parking lot next to the visitor's center and above the ruins. We came here before a rush of visitors so we found parking easily. The walk down to the ruins is quick and easy, so we checked that out as well as the tunnel out to the rocky side.

We ended up exploring the rest of the area by following the nearby trails. Mild walk, a few stairs that were harder to go up than down on (my thighs were buuurning), lots of pretty stuff to look at! We followed the trail towards the cliff area we had seen earlier from around the USS SF Memorial site. Checked out the labyrinth too before heading down towards the water.

The four of us had packed lunches so we sat down on a log to eat and watched dogs play together in the sand. There were some obvious bonfire pits (like 4 or 5) that had been occupied from the night before. Two of them were still smoking! Smoke was billowing out! We sat around one of the smoky ones and ended up pouring some water over the smoky log. Also the one we were sitting at was LITTERED with beer bottles, half-used lighters and fluid bottles, and miscellaneous trash. It was so frustrating to see. People really need to learn how to clean up after their asses and/or there should be some trash cans installed.

Anyway... after that we explored some less traveled trails and saw a lot of pretty flora! Careful of thorny plants though, I was wearing some thin leggings and had to proceed with much caution.

Had a great (and tiring) hike back to the car. I really enjoyed visiting the Sutro Baths and surrounding Land's End trails. :)
author: Shanise M.

description: The views from this place are stunning no doubt. My review is for the baths in particular. Didn't find them that interesting at all in terms of the history etc. The surrounding trails in and around the Lands End area are fantastic.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
The VIEW is breathtaking !! One of the prettiest views I have ever seen in person and I feel so spoiled to live so close to such a scene . I always feel so calm .. Just sitting at the edge of a cliff and just look out into the sunset. All stress is gone while I'm there . Nothing but calmness and a lovely breeze . 

This place is Very romantic . Great place to go with a special someone or just to come and enjoy the view and take things off your mind .
author: Jenny N.

description:
Definitely a must-see sight lost in time and full of history! The solid remnants of a once thriving bath house is now a prime location for visitors of all kinds willing to do the steep hike down and explore through all the interesting ruins. There is plenty to see in this area, from the climbable walls and rocks to the dark yet inviting cave, people have fun scaling the baths to fill their sense of adventure and get superb photos! 

The location is very accessible and is not a long walk at all from the Cliff House, Land's End, or the base of Ocean Beach! You will spend a while hiking and discovering everything once monumental here! The location itself is clean and usually not overly crowded.

Definitely check out the cave, climb up on the big rock for a view, and walk through the ruins, just be careful of where you step! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description:
Sutro Bath has been bookmarked for a while due to the pictures I've seen a few of my yelp buddies post.   I finally got a chance to see this beautiful place this weekend.   I'm in amazement and also extremely curious of the history of this place so I thought I'd Google it.

Sutro Baths opened to the public on March 14, 1896 and was the world's largest indoor swimming pool.  It was built by Adolf Sutro who was a  former  mayor of San Francisco.   It burnt down in 1967.   Found the details on this site along wt additional pictures.  https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutro_Baths.  

My sister and I spent a few hours here yesterday trying to imagine what this area must have looked like when first built.  I had thought it was an outdoor salt water swimming area but the pictures on the website above show otherwise.   

This location was the highlight of our day yesterday.   If you've never been and have the opportunity to go, you will not be disappointed!   There are also great hiking trails to explore as well.  This was such a fun adventure!
author: Melissa H.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area my entire life and have never actually been here before, well at least until yesterday. Let me tell you, this place is great. 

You feel like you're in the ruins of a post apocalyptic Bay Area. The aliens have lost, but the remains of our former civilization still exist and need to be rebuilt. It's that type of place, filled with majestic beauty and glamor. 

There were a decent amount of people, and parking what a hoot and a half, but this is also a tourist trap, so it makes sense. There are many path ways here, and I'm not sure what the one we took was called, but it was great. The actual ruins themselves are a sight to behold. We even saw some dude trying to do a handstand on the highest peak. Everyone was watching, wondering if he would fall. 

SF is known for its high winds and cold weather, but yesterday was just perfect in almost every way imaginable that the experience was flawless. If you enjoy beauty and great views, this is the place for you.
author: Benny H.

description: I hadn't been here in years but have been wanting to come back! Finally we made it up this past weekend on a gorgeous day. There is a large lot at the top of the hill right above the Sutro Baths as well as a smaller one just across the street. Parking was packed but we were able to snag a spot before too long. There are restrooms and a small visitors center complete with a small cafe at the top of the hill. The path down is pretty easy, but walking shoes would be helpful if you want to explore. There are some rocky areas. There is plenty to explore once you get to the bottom, the ruins of the baths as well as a tunnel through the rocks. I'd love to come back here at sunset, I am sure it'd be spectacular to see the sunset reflecting in the pools. If you've never been, check it out!
author: Michele B.

description:
It's beautiful , it should be on your list.
It's gonna be windy and cold so get pullovers ..
author: Manasa K.

description: The baths are so historic and it is pretty spectacular on the cliffs. There are also cute ducks in the baths! The downside is that the baths are not well maintained, so when there aren't high tides, the stagnant water smells and is filthy. There are also always tons of people at the baths. Ideally, get food at the Cliff House and enjoy the view from afar.
author: Judy S.

description:
Overdue review: 
Great way to get some steps in and see the city in a whole different way. Prefect for a mental health day (day to yourself) if you love the outdoors.
author: Janelle S.

description: This is a beautiful place to visit.  Park at the top and enjoy the views from there or walk down the stairs.  From there you can either take a very, very steep trail down to the ruins or walk around the trails at the top.  If you're planning on visiting the ruins where proper hiking shoes!
author: Jennifer D.

description: A great view of the ocean. Extremely peaceful! Be sure to bring walking shoes since it gets very sandy and wet. Walk up to the view on the right side -- it's worth it!
author: John P.

description: Great for hiking with the fam or enjoying a relaxing day at the beach!
author: Kelsie W.

description:
Sutro Baths were a fun place to climb around and take in the ocean before we went on a coastal hike. We found street parking easily (Friday daytime) and contemplated buying lots of things in the gift shop. Hello, restraint!

Go, explore!
author: Bree M.

description:
Sutro Baths is the most beautiful place in San Francisco. There, I said it. Imagine: Bath house ruins, filled to the brim with water reflecting the sky above. Silhouettes of visitors walking along the stone edge between the baths and the ocean... From where you're standing, it looks like they're walking on water. 

Find a clear day and aim to get here an hour before sunset. There's parking at the Lands End Lookout, but on a nice day it'll most likely be crowded, so you might spend some time circling for parking. If it's packed, you might have better luck up the hill by the residential areas.

There's quite an elevation difference between the parking lot and the actual baths, so as you might expect there are a LOT of stairs... which makes for a tiring walk back up. If you decide to go all the way down, don't be afraid to go into the cave (it's not that great on the other side, but it's something to do). Watch out for wet sand inside, if you're wearing sandals. If you're wearing comfy shoes, I highly advise walking along the baths to the south end of the area, under the Cliff House restaurant. At the end of the ruins, you can climb down to the beach and dig your toes into the (admittedly cold) sand and water. 

If you've already been here at sunset, I'd advise coming in the afternoon and taking the Lands End trail for a great view of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge -- for my fellow lazy peers, don't worry: it's more of a walk than a hike. 

Note: Don't come here if it's a foggy day. You won't see much, and it won't give you any sort of wow factor. I've heard that SF gets foggier in the summer, so you might want to visit during the winter months (when it's not raining, of course). 

There aren't many sights in the world that can take my breath away. Trust me -- if you haven't been here, it's an absolute MUST-SEE in the city.
author: Christine L.

description: One of my favorite spots in SF. Great views, beautiful sunsets and a nice trial for jogging! The sutro baths also has parking, which is a plus.
author: S Z.

description:
Great place to explore! What caught my attention was the pictures of the cave on yelp. So in my head I'm like cool! Let's explore a cave. But once I got here it was more than just a cave. I didn't know any history behind Sutro Baths until I searched it up and found out that it used to be a large swimming center.

Search up on google, 'Sutro Baths Then and Now' it'll give you an idea of this historical landmark. It's amazing to see how much Sutro Baths has completely deteriorate into ruins. Now it's a great place for tourists to explore and walk around. Come here around sunset because it is beyond beautiful! There's not much I can say because everybody that has given this place a five star rating has pretty much covered up everything there needs to be said about this landmark. You'd have to come and see this for yourself.
author: Sophia V.

description: Lovely spot. Been here 2 out of the 3 times we have stayed in the city. Its a really interesting place with some fantastic views of the golden gate bridge and of the ocean. On my list of the top things to do while in the city. If you have time walk from here along the costal path to Crissy fields.
author: Rebeca J.

description:
This place is practically blocks from my parent's old home in SF. 
Never ever stepped foot at this magical place, but better 22 years late than never?

Beautiful! The cool trees and the ocean waves plus the gnarly ruins makes this place perfect for photos and just to listen to waves splash. 

Parking can get packed, but be patient. The actual view is a hike down and the ruins are fun to walk along, but also if you are not careful, you could fall. 

There is a really awesome spot where the big rock formation has a hole in the shape of a heart. kinda cute.
author: Connie J.

description:
I'm from New England. I never knew what the Sutro Baths were, but I was pleased as punch to discover! It's absolutely gorgeous here, and walking around was magnificent. 

Walking on the foundations of the buildings was fun, but it doesn't exactly seem safe for small children. I was admittedly somewhat nervous for some of them running around. 

There are LOTS of stairs. If you're not fit, these will suck. There *is* a path that is not steep and seemingly insurmountable stairs. But, we survived and prevailed to the top with the intention that on our next trip to San Francisco, we won't be horribly out of shape!

The little gift shop at the top was wonderful, and I learned a lot about the Baths there. And the small cafe bar was a blessing as we desperately needed something to drink after traipsing around.
author: Erica T.

description:
PERFECT DATE PLACE. Whether it's a morning sunrise, beach time play time, or enjoying a nice sunset, Sutro Baths is a pretty amazing spot to spend with that special someone. 

- The walk up and down to the beach / ruins can be fairly steep which is great for some hand holding action. 

- If it's a little chilly during the early morning or watching a sunset, you can make the arm around the shoulder move if you're a guy. If you're a girl, you can try the arm grab. 

- A great place for some cutsie pictures or to show off your photo skills. I, personally, lack both of those so hopefully you'll do better than me. ;)

- If this is a first date, you should read the Wiki page so you can come off a little cultured. Knowledge is power, y'all.

- Go into the water or lay on the beach and people watch! It'll make for a really nice day. 

Good luck, ladies and gents. You can do it!
author: Chris W.

description: Must See!!! Almost didn't go.. but so glad I did! Definitely cool for younger adults bc it can get a bit sketchy with the run down buildings you can walk across, but perfect spot for IG photos!! Check it Out! Bathrooms are clean as well!
author: Justine S.

description:
The pictures that Yelpers have provided really do speak thousands of words here. I true local gem and an icon of San Francisco's "local flavor". This place has an interesting and quirky history. There's a great podcast on the history of the Sutro Baths if you're interested:

http://99percentinvisible.org/episode/young-ruin/

It's pretty obvious that this place is disintegrating into the beach and ocean quickly. I was wondering what my grandchildren would see of this place. 

Beautiful, majestic views of the ocean. Quite a gem of San Francisco. It can be a very different environment depending on what time of day or night you are there - dawn, mid-day, sunset, night. All awesome. 

I come here on occasion with my family to enjoy the ruins, the beach, and to hike along the adjoining Lands End trail. My favorite visit so far was when I visited with my son at sunset. The fog was rolling in off the ocean while the sun was setting. Amazing. 

There is a mix of tourist groups, families, groups of teenagers, and photographers. 

Plenty of parking too.  I am sometimes surprised to see how few people are walking the trail, but no complaints ;)
author: David S.

description: Anyone who puts their motorcycle parking at the first row right next to the best areas will automatically get a five star review in my book. Aside from the fact that you've got 500 cars battling and circulating the lot for one of the 100 spaces, and I get to roll right up into my own little nook... Well on top of that, this place is fantastic. It's scenic with an ever-present great breeze, hiking, cypress trees, access to the Land's End trail, and a view of the bay.. This place is perfect.
author: Tim R.

description:
Interesting history!

Hubby and I have a passion for history... actually, it is he who usually gives me the lowdown on the landmarks we visit, he is sort of like my Wikipedia, but this time it was me who gave him a little history of the Sutro Baths (after I did a little research on it).

It was our intent that day to dine at the Cliff House but when seeing the ruins after looking below from the restaurant, we wanted to explore instead. We love visiting ruins and historical buildings and clearly seeing the demolished concrete walls, the blocked off stairs and passageways of where something used to be got me curious about what and how this place looked like before. Turns out that in the late 19th century, Sutro Baths was to be the world's largest indoor public swimming pool built by and named after a former mayor of San Francisco, who was also a rich entrepreneur.  History states that "... the baths struggled for years, mostly due to the very high operating and maintenance costs, and eventually closed." and just as it was to be demolished a fire destroyed the building and was abandoned. Read up more on it on your spare time as it is more interesting to know about the place before you visit.

The ruins was quite interesting to explore as we went over and around rocks and old bricks and even inside a tunnel or cave. The tunnel wasn't very long or deep, Just midway through there's a deep opening leading through the ocean and waves would crash into the cave at high tide. There is no exit at the other end of the tunnel but is said to be haunted, there is just an opening where you can view more rocks and the ocean. This tunnel lies directly to the right of the old sunken building at Sutro Baths. The cliff and surf area can be extremely dangerous and there is actually a sign posted there that people have been swept from the rocks and drowned, so use great caution and watch out for rogue waves! 

There is a hiking trail to the Upper Coastal Trail which is 760 ft. Be careful because it is a steep trail with uneven terrain. Looking towards the ocean you can also see a set of rock formation island, they called this Seal Rocks, because of the history and population of sea lions. Overall, very interesting day and we never did get a chance to eat at the restaurant for some reason. Oh, and bring a jacket, can get windy. Wear layers.

Review #0346
author: May A.

description:
Another San Francisco tourist trap. A beautiful one though.
The history behind is quite interesting. I've seen this place in multiple "Things to do while in SF" lists so I was happy to stumble upon it while walking the Lands End Trail. I didn't even know it was connected.

The stairs going down to it is gravelly & turned into really lose sand in come parts so if you're wearing shoes you don't want to ruin, I would suggest you plan for another day. If you don't care, then TREK on!

There are signed to clearly mark where Sutro Baths is so you won't miss it.
There are multiple places to enjoy the views of this place, there is one on a lightweight cliff then you can go down by the beach there. I went on a foggy day but it still doesn't disappoint :)

A great place to listen to the waves of the ocean & WATCH DOLPHINS, yup, watch dolphins. They play in the little cove between the rocks in the ocean. They're more visible from the Lands End cliffs.
Happy Tourist Trapping!
author: Camille C.

description:
For maximum appreciation, you should know the history. 

Adolph Sutro was a self-made millionaire and a former mayor of San Francisco. He created a public bathhouse that housed seven pools, each with different temperatures, along with entertainment and educational areas at this coastal facility for an inexpensive time out for families.

Here at Sutro Baths, you're looking at what's left of it-- Some of the concrete foundation. The bathhouse wasn't always a bathhouse as it became an ice rink afterward to try and become more profitable after popularity dwindled. That didn't really take off so the property was later slated to be demolished and build high-rise apartments and that never happened due to a fire.
