From then it became apart of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area, landmarked for people to come see what use to be.

I wonder what the ocean floor looks like after failed seawalls have crumbled into it.. It's amazing that it existed and it makes you wonder about that time.

You can take a ton of steps down to the site or view it from the street level. You can walk around the ruins and explore. I recommend wearing, at the least, sneakers if you're going down to the site. There's sand, dirt, and gravel that, personally, I wouldn't want entering my footwear.. There's a nearby cave/tunnel and other hints of the past that'll make Sutro Baths a nice stop for a little exploration.
author: O M G.

description: Beautiful and breathtaking. Pictures really don't do it any justice so you have to see it in person. Always a great spot to visit and definitely hike at the Land's End trail, there's an amazing Labyrinth in the middle of your hike!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
This place is so, so spectacular. My boyfriend took me here unexpectedly and it was a wonderfully surprise. The ruins of the bath were fun to explore (and a bit heart racing!) the sunsets here are picturesque; they look the way sunsets do in paintings... But 10x better. It's very peaceful and memorable. 

With lots and lots of stairs and uneven walking, this place is not friendly to those with physical disabilities, which is unfortunate. Everyone should be able to experience this special place and I hope that will eventually be possible, but it is something to be aware of when visiting. Also, the ruins of the baths are not somewhere you want kids or anyone with poor balance exploring. Take your kids straight to the beach and away from the ruins, because that whole thing screams "did you remember to get your tetanus shot?" My boyfriend fell into a hole here in the dark once and almost broke his leg... But that's a story for another day. 

All in all, beautiful place with an interesting history. I look forward to visiting again and encourage anyone who can to go.
author: Anna M.

description: Love such a wonderful,calming place. Wonderful views. Great place to explore. On the colder side so bring a jacket.
author: Kaitlyn S.

description:
Awesome historic landmark in San Francisco that everyone has to check out! My friends and I parked at Land Ends Lookout parking lot and made our way down to Sutro Baths. Parking can be a little difficult to find but cars are always coming and leaving so I would advise that you wait in an aisle and wait for someone to leave instead of constantly driving around.

After we parked, we trekked down the steps to the ruins and explored the cave first. The sand inside the cave was very soft and black. I was wearing sandals so I could feel it because there was one area where my feet sunk into the soft sand. At the end of the cave, you can sort of see the sea and crashing waves. It is a bit dangerous so explore with caution.

From the entrance of the cave, if you look out to the rock in the water, apparently the hole of that rock forms a heart. I found out about this after so I did not get a chance to see it with my own eyes but I saw a picture of it.

Lots of exploring around the baths and cool photo ops if you don't mind getting a little wet and dirty. I saw people making their way out to the far rock and climbing that thing.

For our way back to the car, we took the adventurous route and it was a bit steep and turned into a teamwork hike. The guys in our group had to pull up the girls because some of the steps were a bit high. That was a little unexpected workout. Definitely wear comfortable shoes around here, no high heels or heeled boots or you will be struggling.
author: Minh-An C.

description:
If I lived in SF, I'd come here to get away from all the hustle and bustle of the city. Super calm and soothing. Great place to just reflect and BREATHE some decent air. I'm from Seattle, so the air here is bomb. But the air at this place was amazing. 

So many places to walk and look.
author: Susan H.

description:
It is really quite beautiful here and an amazing area to walk through. Even if you're not here to hike, I would recommend just stopping by to check it out. It was kind of sad to see graffiti and lots of trash everywhere, but if you're willing to overlook that, it has quite a beautiful view. There's a small parking lot at Land's End which is right above Sutro Baths. If it's full, there's a bit of street parking along the side of Land's End. Or if you're willing to walk you can park a bit further down by the beach and walk over. 

If you walk down into the ruins of Sutro Baths, it's a bit rocky and sandy. At the bottom of the stairs and to the right, there's a cave that is pretty neat to check out. Will definitely be back again to explore more of this area!
author: Angel K.

description: Probably my all time favorite spot in San Francisco and maybe all of the US. I adore this place! When you first arrive you get a beautiful view of the ruins, the sea, flowers all around, and so much more. I felt as if I was in a fairytale. This place is very versatile as it serves as a great spot for photographs as well as an incredible apace for relaxation and tranquility. I enjoyed doing both whilst I was there as did my friends. I feel like this also has a very romantic touch to it, so if you're in the area and are looking for a great date spot you've found the perfect place. This place has parking right in front and Lands End (another incredible spot!) is within walking distance. Overall a beautiful place which is truly a San Francisco gem!
author: Jamie M.

description:
Great place to visit! Breathtaking views and lots to do here.  We parked at the Lands End Lookout parking lot, hiked a few trails, and ended here at Sutro Baths. 

After a long hike, the kids and I continued to explore the ruins.  It was fun to walk around and to imagine what the swimming facility looked like in the 1890s.  My kids were also able to explore the ruins, beach, and the cave.  Just be careful around the baths and hold on to your toddlers!  Mine was super excited and wanted to explore on his own! lol  Our favorite part was the cave.  It was super dark and eerie, but the kids enjoyed the adventure.   

*I don't recommend strollers, lots of stairs! 

Read more about the history of Sutro Baths here 
http://www.nps.gov/goga/learn/historyculture/sutro-baths.htm
author: Erlinda R.

description:
Sutro Baths is in close proximity of Land's End and the Cliff House which completes the trifecta because you can go to all three! What makes it even more convenient is that there's a ton of parking nearby.

If you go here to view the sunset, it's very beautiful.

Make sure to wear proper attire and go down the stairs. Also, there's garden snakes. We randomly saw someone holding it and I kind of freaked out because I hate snakes...

What's really cool with Sutro Baths is that there's also an area on the northern side of the ruins and there's a cave-like location where you can go in and hear the waves crashing on the wall.

Definitely a place to take your friends!
author: Aj C.

description:
Ah, the lovely Sutro Baths...another fascinating FREE sightseeing location in SF.  The area hosts incredible backdrops for photo opportunities....as long as Karl the Fog isn't present.  Heck, if Karl is present, just embrace it-- there's something special about his foggy romance that adds character to SF's outdoor ambiance.  

I've had luck with parking here, so I would say that it's safe to drive to this location if you have a car.  People seem to constantly be coming and going and parking spots become available due to turnover.  

**Wardrobe tip:  Make sure to wear comfy shoes because there are plenty of trails, stairs, and paths to frolic on.  IT IS VERY WINDY on the west side of the peninsula.  Bring a sweatshirt, windbreaker, or light jacket.  

Go ahead and skip the cafes around here-- they have average food at best and are very touristy.  I recommend dipping into the Sunset or Richmond neighborhoods for a bite. 

Make sure to:
*See the baths
*Hike north a bit to see the naval ship monument
*Hike to the north side to see the Golden Gate 
*Look south and see the crazy surfers (brrrrr!)
author: Andrea H.

description:
Gorgeous views.  There are a lot of stairs to get to to the baths so keep that in mind if you are limited physically.

Parking is limited - we had an Uber driver take us to the opposite end of the Lands End trail (close to the bridge) and then we walked over to the Baths.  Both the baths and the trail itself make for great pictures of the coastal scenery.

Theres a giftshop/cafe adjacent to the baths, too.

I went in February and it was about 70 degrees in SF.  The cliffs are probably at least 10 degrees cooler (it is very windy obviously) so I'd recommend a light jacket if you get cold easily like I do and you're not visiting when it's super warm out.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Developed by Adolph Sutro in 1894, the Sutro Baths consisted of an ocean pool aquarium and a massive public bathhouse that covered three acres. Unfortunately they were not commercially successfully and were later converted into an ice-skating rink before getting demolished to be replaced by high-rise apartments. However, when a fire destroyed the remains in 1966, the apartment plans were abandoned and now these concrete ruins are left. They have become a part of the Golden Gate National Recreation area since 1973.

The ruins are beautiful and it's nice to just sit out there and take in the view, especially if it's a nice sunny day. It's cool to imagine what the area must have been like back when the Baths were popular; you can see images of it if you go to Cliff House (also designed by Adolph Sutro), just a short walk from the ruins. It's a good place to walk and there is even a small cave to explore.
author: Esther K.

description: I am so lucky to have been able to see the Sutro Baths in person because no picture could capture the breathtaking view I saw while I was here.  It was a refreshing change of scenery from the busy city of downtown SF.  Definitely a popular spot for tourists as there were a ton of people here.  There are many different view points and they are all equally amazing.  Very cool photo ops! I would definitely say that Sutro Baths is a "must go" while exploring SF.
author: Regina O.

description:
Sutro Baths was one of the places I enjoyed the most on our recent trip to San Francisco. I've heard about them in passing, started to look into them, read the cool history behind it, saw pictures of the place that intrigued me and made me wanna go and see them.

So we did! It's easier to get to Sutro Baths area if you take public transportation than I thought it would be. Just take #38 till the end, get off, you'll see the ocean, walk toward it- less than a minute (it's so close!) and you'll see the Visitor's center ahead. The Visitor's Center is great, you can find more info inside, use their restrooms, warm up at their cafe. There are signs that lead you to the baths. I wouldn't call this a hike, you can take the stairs down, or walk downhill and you'll be there in a minute. If you drive, they have a free parking lot. 

This place is so beautiful, so picturesque that you have to be a moron to not take decent photos of it. Wherever you turn your camera there are wonderful vistas. The views are so dramatic and so San Francisco! It's like the background of a scene in a movie, a great movie. 

The cave is nearby, small, but cool, you can hear the waves hitting its walls and see the ocean at the end of it. The ruins of the old baths are cool and full of poetry if you're into historic sights. Also, you get nice views on your left of the Cliff House restaurant. 

It was sunny, but cold and windy when we visited, but we couldn't care less. We were mesmerized by this place. There are locals strolling around, tourists, but it's the type of place that's not that crowded and everyone coexists in peace and enjoys the majestic views. If you'll visit SF and have some time, definitely check it out. It's nature at its best. Stunning!
author: Jo S.

description: Parking here is plentiful. There are however signs stating that cars are frequently broken into. Anyway, there seem to be an infinite number of steps to make it down to the baths. It can be nerve wracking trying to keep your balance walking on the concrete ruins. One wrong step and you're taking a dip in dirty water. There's also a cave you can go through where you can get an up close look at waves crashing into the rocks. I've been to San Francisco many times by it was my first time here. I'd never heard of this place until recently.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Such a beautiful place in the city! I was lucky enough to visit when the weather was perfect. There was a slight breeze and the sun was setting, but the air was still warm. You get to walk along the ruins of the Sutro Baths, climb some rocks, and sit along the ledge and enjoy the view. You can also climb down to get onto the beach. This is a great spot to come with a special someone to enjoy the view with some good conversation. :)

I used the address on Yelp to get here. There is a free parking lot and there are a lot of spaces, so parking was not an issue for me. Once you park, you walk towards the ocean and you'll see people coming up and down from the stairs. Walk down the stairs and it'll take you down to the Sutro Baths. The walk down is not difficult, but walking back up can be a bit tiring haha.
author: Gina H.

description:
An amazing place to come to when in San Francisco. The Sutro Baths were privately owned saltwater pools for the public, and developed by Adolph Sutro. However, the Baths were hard to keep up economically, so they were to be demolished. During demolition, a fire burned everything down, and the result is what visitors see today.
The Sutro Baths offer breathtaking views. There is also a cave in the side of the small hill that visitors can explore. I highly recommend visiting this place around sunset for amazing views. Also, if you look closely at the rocks in ocean, you can spot a rock with the shape of a heart inscribed in it. Be careful when exploring the ruins because the walls can become very slippery, and one can easily injure them self. Also, make sure to dress appropriately when coming here. It was about 50 degrees when I came, and it was super windy, so I had to dress very warmly. Overall, this place offers one of the best views of San Francisco!
author: Michael Q.

description: Somewhat biased here, because I recently chose this for my engagement spot, but half because I ran out of time to look at other places for a surprise setting. I didn't have time to walk around everywhere here, but I did go down to the main spot. Couple negatives were that the walk down to the beach is really difficult, I would recommend sports attire and the proper shoes. The other thing is that the cool little ledge area where you see all the pics kind of smells from all the standing water. There is a nice breeze from the ocean and the view is really nice. Definitely a good spot to check out though.
author: Richard T.

description: Great place and park! The view is really lovely, and the trails aren't too hard. On a clear day, you can see pretty far out there, and there's so many places for good photo ops. Certainly a hidden gem that everyone should visit at least once in SF! We'll definitely be back on a sunnier day. It was sprinkling and super foggy when we went, but we want to get a chance for a longer walk and a clearer view!
author: Evonne L.

description:
Been living by the Bay for 4 years now, with countless visitors. Sadly this was my first visit here and the views are spectacular. One thing to note are the 48 steps to descend into this place. And right after that, you get a SFesque steep hill to traverse down before you actually get to the pools.

Also, Wiki this place before you come. Its tons more interesting that way. Maybe i missed it but they should have info signs about this place.

Also, keep your kids close. It can get pretty hairy moving around this place and heading to the beach. One wrong step and youre falling about 8 feet to the shallow pool.

Theres also a rock formation thats surrounded by water on three sides that could be accessed via the beach. We saw two boys on the rock on this day. I hate to be a kill joy but dont do it. The waves were creeping up and can easily sweep you off. Once you get caught in the rip current, youre off to meet your maker.
author: Kris P.

description: Sutro baths, the cliff house, and lands end are all accessible from the same parking lot. Luckily sutro baths is literally just a walk down the flight of stairs from the busy lots, and you can get a view from above. Once you reach the bottom, there are a number of things to take in. There are the waves crashing against the walls of the baths and the rocks. There is a small tunnel/cave that you can go through to the other side. There are a few abandon buildings you can take great photos of...there is a lot. One of the small ruins has a little window to peer inside and my friend and I freaked out because there's actually food and orange juice and milk you can see. We thought it was abandoned but as we looked closer there's a bed and blankets and I think hobos live in there so don't get too close and definitely do not squeeze yourself through the window to go inside their dwelling. Anyway, if you're lucky, this place is beautiful at sunset because of the reflections in he different areas of water. If not, it's still beautiful on a clear day!
author: Maleah M.

description:
Def go here, all! 
Amazing view. Fun rocks/ruins/caves to climb, play hide and seek, and capture in your camera. Super windy and bright. The weather was nice when I came, but usually it is cloudy in the morning and possibly clears in the afternoon. Don't wear heels. Some graduating students in nice clothes had the misfortune of discovering that Sutro Baths is an unforgiving place for heels. Make sure to watch your step when scaling the ruins. Uneven terrain with pits filled with water.. and some with rocks. Thrilling hike!

There is a museum by the bathrooms showing the history of this place.
author: Judge F.

description:
What a beautiful historical landmark! It's pretty crazy to imagine that the place used to be a real, huge bathhouse. Some disclaimers:

- There are a lot of stairs to get from the parking lot to the ruins.
- You can walk on the eroded walls of the bathhouse, but there are pieces missing and holes in the infrastructure, so make sure you have good footwear.
- If you choose to walk on the walls, make sure there are not a lot of other people on there too! The path is quite narrow and it'd be easy to fall 5 feet into the shallow water.
- The cave next to the bath house is very dark, so make sure you're comfortable with that (the views are worth it at the end of the tunnel, I promise!).
author: Lauren V.

description:
It's kind of amazing that this use to be some kind of community pool. Now all there is left is the ruins. To be honest, there is not much left except for a couple of walls that people walk on and around, but it's in a beautiful location right next to the beach and the view from the top of the stairs is really nice. 

Overall, it's a cool landmark to see, and it's right near the beach and Land's End where there is plenty to explore.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Walk through the ruins of the bath houses is like talking a walk through history.  They are an exquisite historical landmark.  There is a small cave to explore on the side as well.  Be warned, there are a lot of stairs to ascend and descend when coming here.  During low tide, you can just lie there and relax on the beach.  There is a nice little giftshop and bathrooms at the top.  Parking is very easy on the weekdays, but hell on the weekends.
author: Dang L.

description: Really cool place to visit.  Back in 1896, this was the city's largest public pool.  It eventually closed down, it sustained damage from the 1901 earthquake then eventually burned down in 1966.  Now, you can explore the ruins.  Even better are the caves.  Come at either high or low tides to see magnificent tidal pools or amazing waves crashing on the shore.  Just note to dress warm.  It's in the coldest and foggiest part of town.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Amazing view, unique sightseeing trip.

The bf surprised me one day and took me here. (I kept expressing to the bf about how badly I wanted to visit!) When we got there, we took pictures right away because the view is just breathtaking. Parking is plentiful, by the way, so you don't have to worry about that!

We went down the sandy steps and got to the bath ruins. There's this ledge that everyone was walking on (maybe a little over 2 feet wide) but I was way too scared. On one side, there's this huuuuge marsh pit filled with algae and God-knows-what. And on the other side of the ledge, there are jagged rocks with the waves fiercely crashing into it. One little misstep and you can fall over and DIE, so be careful!

They also have a cave you can check out. It has an opening at the end and has another view of the waters.

Overall, I give this place an A+! I am a sucker for great views :)
author: Nari C.

description: Breathtaking view right before the Lands' End Trail. Went on a Saturday and it wasn't overly crowded. Seems like a popular spot for both locals and tourists. There's not much to say except go experience it yourself. It's spectacular.
author: Elysse P.

description: This place is STUNNING. Get to Cliff House and follow the paths to walk down to the ocean and sutra baths. There'll be tons of people going the various paths so just pick one and walk around. It is insanely windy out here regardless of what the weather is like around the rest of SF so bring layers and a windbreaker if you have one. This is also the start of the land's end trail. After you go to the ditto baths, if you follow the paths and stairs back up to street level, you'll find the signs for the coastal trail which is the land's end. I wish I could sit here and watch the ocean waves all day.
author: Susie C.

description:
There's really no other place like Sutro Baths in the city or anywhere else in the Bay Area. Yes, it is touristy but you can count on finding locals around Ocean Beach and Lands End enjoying a nice day out too. It's a very popular destination especially on the weekends. 

Can you imagine what the swimming pool complex used to be like circa 1890's? Wouldn't it have been amazing? Well, the ruins of the infinity pool/baths are still amazing but in a historical way. It's definitely an SF landmark to be admired. 

Great place to just hang out and chill at the beach. Take a walk with friends or a date. Bring the family and the kids will have a fun time exploring the ruins and the cave nearby. If you're feeling adventurous, walk along the edges of the ruins. Be careful though, falling into the dirty water would not be ideal. Also, a great place for photo ops. There's always people there shooting the sunset on their tripods or others doing photo shoots. I guarantee it's a hot spot for couples to take their engagement pics. It's a unique backdrop and something that everyone can appreciate when it comes to photography. If you can tell, I have had my share of people watching at Sutros.

There's free parking lot by the visitors center but you can also park down by Ocean Beach or Cliff House and walk over. Always bring a jacket because it gets windy!
author: Liv A.

description:
The ocean has taken its toll on the Sutro Baths. The ruins are slowing crumbling away, what a shame. First opened in 1896 the complex contained 7 glass enclosed pools, a museum, a concert hall. My mom told me it was wonderful place to spend a day. It still is a great place.You can see the ruins and the cave that the water came through to fill the pools. The ruins is now the home of San Francisco's only sea otter.  

To see the way it was check these websites. 

photos
http://www.cliffhouseproject.com/environs/sutrobaths/sutro_baths.htm

Short documentary, It includes film clips from the 1890 to the present time.
http://www.cliffhouseproject.com/environs/sutrobaths/sutro_baths.htm
author: Terry T.

description: The roman ruins of San Francisco! I heard that normally is very cold and foggy, but my friend and I enjoyed a not super sunny yet not so bad Sunday morning golden rays! I never heard about these baths until a colleague mentioned she went after living in the Bay Area for several years. Looks like is the usual place to visit during your first times in SF, but totally worth it. I would like to watch a sunset from there. It was full of visitors trying to take a pic in front of those rocks that have a heart shaped hole. Very nice spot, romantic if you are in the mood for it!
author: Carmen V.

description:
Literally the coolest place ever. I can't believe that I'm from California and never been here! It's always been on my to do list. Anyways brief history lesson from what my friend learned on his podcast--some really rich dude once wanted to build a bath house for his guests in his apartment complexes. Unfortunately, he mispredicted the rate at which SF would grow and by the time he was done with the bath house, SF hadn't sprawled into what it is today and so no one could even get to his bath house. As a result, it tarnished and is what it is today--a really fun rock climbing adventure right by the sea with some amazing views.

My friend and I came the weekend after #hellastorm and we were extremely fortunate to get some amazing weather. I love this place. I'm kind of a dork and really enjoy jumping around and climbing rocks and that's basically what the ruins are. The ruins are more or less the perimeter of the bath house area. You can walk on them and walk seaside. It's lovely. Get your iPhone/Instagram/VSCO game on because it is literally so stunning. You have the lovely Pacific Ocean juxtaposed with ancient ruins... does that not just scream all the likes on your social media posts? It's quite a number of steps down to get to the ruins (and hence obv quite a hike back up) but it's so much fun. Some people fish in the area which is interesting. Honestly I'd be pretty content to just sit here. It's not like the beach where winds can sometimes be really, really strong when you're next to the ocean. I was in a light sweater and found it to be fine. It's because there's a pretty solid buffer of rocks in between the ruins and the ocean so maybe that lowers the effect of the wind?

tldr; coolest place ever, a must-go if you're only in SF for a short time. try to come during sunset, it's gorgeous
author: Jasmine X.

description: Amazing views and incredible trails. This was one of my favorite spots on my trip. I went on a foggy and somewhat rainy day but it was actually better this way in my eyes because less people were there and we could still see the Golden Gate.
author: Gabe C.

description:
Just up the road or down the cliff face from the Cliff House lies Sutro Baths. Holding down the last vestiges of coastline is this scenic view and stunning structure which was once grand in stature. Just up the way, you can see an old illustration of Sutro back in 1900 -- a family swimming hole and amusement center. It looked absolutely stunning and the remnants of this historic site are still just as breathtaking, given the lack of structure. 

You can get great views of this historic site from the Lands End parking lot and you can walk down a few sets of steps or a few trails down to the baths themselves. Plenty of places for great photos. 

This was one of the most breathtaking sites we had the pleasure of seeing while we walked from Outer Sunset up to the Lands End. I'd highly recommend checking it out if you've heard about it. It's rather remarkable.
author: Benjamin G.

description: Sutro Baths is lockated in Lands End and it is such a cool site to visit. It is far west of SF so right along the coast. It is absolutely beautiful here as you see the waves crashing against the rocks. A lot of people walk along the baths and just sit and stare into the sunset. There is a small cave nearby that you can explore and a trail if you have the time and energy. What a cute treasure in sf and I am sure there are more places like these in SF that I have yet to discover. It is just beautifulllll walking to your destination and just getting that nice breeze. It is soo windy over there so make sure to dress warmly and wear a beanie since your hair will fly all over. You can spend an hour just walking around the bath area but definitely more time needs to be allocated if you go to the trail. There are parking spots but you can also take the bus to get here.
author: Amy H.

description: Loved coming here as a kid to explore, run around, go into the cave and just be near the ocean. I was so lucky to grow up in the city during the 80s. And as an adult I still love going here to see the sunset. Sutro Baths below, Cliff House and Seal Rock in the distance. Quintessential San Franisco coastline... Nice little hike but be prepared for blustery winds in the evening no matter what time of year. It's so nice to take in the view from the cliffs, you feel the wind, you see the waves, you hear the waves... Go to Land's End. Just Go... Get to Geary and head for the ocean. Park at the lot. Soak it all in and enjoy the view. Dont be afraid to get your feet a little sandy...Thank me later.
author: Chuck D.

description:
Parking can be found across the street or at Lands End Lookout. What an incredible view though! You can take the long dreaded stairs down to Sutro Baths from the Lands End Lookout. But stop and take in all the things while walking down. It's pretty amazing!

Okay, you'll probably noticed a weird smell just because the water has probably been there since forever. I think it used to be an indoor pool and I guess they took it over and left it. But it left a cool landmark or what I would call the "waffles" because they definitely look like waffles when you look down from above. 

There's a cave to your right when you get down and it's super cool! You can definitely see the waters from the cave. Do walk all the way down and you'll see the rocks and waves clashing into the rocks on the other side. It's pretty cool! You can also walk up to the front of Sutro Baths, by the waters. We didn't have the opportunity to do so since there were quite a lot of people that day. So it does get crowded! 

It's a nice landmark here in San Francisco and I definitely recommend coming here and enjoying that beautiful view. It's definitely worth the drive up to San Francisco to get an unforgettable view!
author: Wendy Y.

description: A Must See when you are in San Francisco. Lots of Parking at Land's end so not hard to get to, Go on a sunny day to enjoy the breathtaking views, if you go when the fog rolls in you won't see much. Close to Ocean Beach and the Cliff house. Used to be a large, privately owned public saltwater swimming pool complex. From what I read, it burned down in 1966 hence the ruins. You get a great view of the ruins that are Left. The Trails are great, bring your dogs or go on a hike. Heard there is also a cave but didn't get to explore that, maybe next time.
author: Tina M.

description:
I don't understand how it has taken me so long to actually come here. I've seen it on my friends' instagrams, I've seen it on a few lists, and some very creative photographers have made it look amazing ... and yet it's taken me probably 3-4 years since I found out about this place to come.

It was definitely 3-4 years too long. This place is amazing. I have to say it's better to come during sunrise or sunset because the colors of the sky and the sun really reflect well in the calm standing waters of the sutro baths, and the changing of the tides is always more interesting than during the day ... but anyway you can make it here is a good time.

There is a lot more to this place than just the ruins of the baths, but the cave was ... mediocre. It really is an amazing photography spot if you're into taking some epic views in SF. Highly, HIGHLY recommended.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
What's left is interesting. NOT RECOMMENDED FOR PHYSICALLY-LIMITED NOR WHEELCHAIRS. We had been told by the Park Rep that it was ADA. BUT there's a HUGH change in elevation and no one could help us to avoid it.
If you ok with mobility then the area where it's located is next to a beach. Then it's 5-stars for beach.
author: Ray H.

description:
I really love the seaside however I feel like the Sutro baths are completely overrated. Once you walk down the steps it kind of looks like a miniature sewage processing plant, not very attractive or comforting. It looks much better if you just stay upstairs next to the Cliffhouse restaurant and don't bother going down.

I really feel like coming here is a waste of your time and really, with stunning views and beaches all over San Francisco, you're so much better off spending your time elsewhere. I don't think it's the must-see everyone makes it out to be and just do not understand the attraction.
author: Bekkah R.

description:
Great place to explore, take pictures, and spend time with family! Took the lands end trail and went all the way here. 

Best time to go is during the sunset or sunrise! Gorgeous view of the beach! The site are remains of swimming center back in the 1800s. Some of the remains are still there and you can see where the pool was! There's also a cave where u can take nice pics and see the waves! 

Great place to take pictures!
author: Abigael M.

description:
Super cool, kind of creepy, and the cave right next to it is a wonderful little gem in the city.

I made a day of going to Louis' Restaurant, The Sutro Baths, and the Legion of Honor as well as the awesome wooded paths between them. It was a great way to check out the area.
author: Ryan H.

description: Nice place to look at the water there's also a good gift shop to look at things bc to me looking at things is good and essential for being a person. Unless you're blind I'm so sorry if you are. Anyway yes pretty good place to me
author: Cecilia H.

description: Beautiful and peaceful place. Pretty cool spot to check out. Definitely different from a typical touristy spot.
author: Kathy T.

description:
I'm so in love with the Sutro Baths!  I wish that I could have been blessed to experience what it was like when it was in full production.  Since I can't, my imagination takes charge.  Plus the pictures of the facility help fill in the blanks.  My passion is swimming, Sutro Baths and the Plunge in Santa Cruz have been my historical wet dreams.  

For some reason being this close to the waves, makes me feel very helpless and weak as a human being.  It is kind of nice to be reminded that there is something else out there that can so beautiful and powerful all at once.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite places in the city.

Love coming here for afternoon walks from the sutro baths to the scenic views of the golden gate bridge.

Their is a very strong smell in the air, but that's what reminds you of old SF.

Parking is easy and their are plenty of spaces available. Dress in layers and comfy shoes since some of the stairs can be tricky to walk on. 

Great place for an amazing sunset! Of course without the fog...
author: Nika K.

description:
If you so happen to find yourself on the west side, Sutro baths is absolutely worth a trip.  The ocean view and ambiance is breathtaking: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nS8Mlt5NRvjLiIHd2RBGDw?select=z-7CFZrKx-ZQnQQAghJS8g#1dFHd8kHsiMvFzIJa8jeLQ

Explore the ruins and when you're done find a comfortable spot to watch, listen, and breath in that sweet ocean air.  This is why I live in CA.  The best goram state there is and will ever be.  

Special thanks to Nick and Ashley O. for their incessant assurances that the hike across town was worth the trip.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
If you're not willing to make the hike to Sutro's Bath from Land's End, there is a parking lot relatively close to Sutro's.  In fact, if you've been to the Cliffhouse you can see the baths from their balcony!  

I started out from Land's End and hiked my way to S.B. which only took like a half an hour.  Be careful 'cause getting down to the baths, the hill gets pretty steep so I suggest wearing shoes with good gripping soles.  

The walls of the original baths have now become the little walk way for tourists to see a lovely view of the ocean.  That or, the fisherman can get to the large rock across the way with the tide is low.  Try not to get into the waters though, it's disgusting and wreaks of filth and trash (so sad).  

Also, there's a cave down younder that doesn't really take you anywhere.  However, you can see the tides crashing against the rocks.   

In all it's beautiful, the history behind this place is rich.  I just wish that people would be more mindful of the baths instead of throwing their trash around.
author: Lea M.

description:
I didn't think I would like this place as much as I did! I'm giving it five stars because it's such a unique site and you can get really interesting photos with what's left of the foundation and the Pacific Ocean in the background. I was taking pictures left and right! 

There's also this neat little cave tunnel where you can go in and watch the waves crash against the rocks below you. At the end of the tunnel, you can get a neat view of the cliff and the ocean.
author: Fiana L.

description:
Sutro Baths , a weird mix of Nature & History ,  
Its hard to imagine that back in 1896 this site held 7 Pools, and an Amphitheater & Club Room that could host 5,000, plus 500+ dressing rooms for guests, and on top of all that an Ice Skating Rink,  

Now of course its a Spectacular Ruin by the Sea, its a great place to explore, but do make sure you are wearing shoes with good gripping soles, and clothes that can get dirty. and if your here early and wanting Breakfast consider the nearby Seal Rock Inn, which I even as a local love to visit on Sundays for a Stack & and order of Scramble
author: Joseph A.

description:
Sutro Baths is a great place to take out-of-town guests, but also a nice place to take in the nice coastal scenery as a local. There is a free parking lot that gets very crowded during peak hours. You can always park in the other lot across the street or along Point Lobos Ave. Restrooms are relatively clean for a public area and next door is a gift shop/cafe to get your memorabilia and hot cocoa for those chilly SF days. It's a great spot for photos. Don't forget to check out the cave to the right.

Best part is it's a free attraction!

*Tip: Wear comfy shoes if you plan on going down. The stairs are not steep, but it's still not suitable for heels or platforms.
author: Mindy D.

description: Must see. My 10 and 8 year old absolutely loved it! They were playing in the ruins and near the baths. My younger one almost fell in! They had the best time. The hike was easy and there was plenty of free parking. The caves were easy access & the view were absolutely breathtaking. No filters needed for my photos.
author: Lexie B.

description:
Walked down from Cliff House for the very first time. In disbelief I have never walked through the tunnel, or around the remaining structures of the bath house.

The wonderful pools of water, the swirly waves and heady ocean... The scenic rock outcropping just a few hundred feet away....

Fun and warm, historic, and gorgeous.

Sutro himself was a German engineer who hailed from Aachen. He blasted and built his way to the modern equivalent of $120 million dollars in assets!

Crazy gorgeous views everywhere. Lovely tie-in to lands End area.

The lookout building has clean restrooms and if one parks downhill along Ocean beach, the hill walk is perfectly primed for the glutes ;)!
author: Jana C.

description: I woke up early and went during the week before having breakfast at Cliff House. I was the only one there. Chilly and somewhat eerie but a really cool experience. I highly recommend going into the cave and walking through to the other side. The waves crash around and below...it's pretty creepy but awesome!
author: Lisa P.

description:
Be sure to check out the little visitor center before going down to the baths.  Yes, there is a huge parking lot.  Inside, you will find some displays and not to mention books about the city's history.  Of course there are restrooms and even a little cafe with snacks.  

Once you took the time to get to know the area, head on down and explore the ruins from the former baths.  Its a beautiful area to imagine the days of yesteryear.   Just imagine people coming here from the city by rail, and diving into the warm baths to enjoy themselves. 

And don't forget to explore the pad where the famous Harold and Maude scene was filmed.   Remember?   Where Maude was protesting the war and fell into a hole as a ploy to help Harold evade military service.  Yes, that scene.  

And what a view!  Great place to enjoy Your National Park.
author: Marcus K.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city.
Sutro Baths provides a scenic view of SF, which is a nice change from the hustle and bustle.

Parking is usually not a problem, unless you come on a holiday or a busy weekend. Restrooms at the top by the visitor center.

The view here is serene and a little bit eerie.. in a good way.
From the bottom of the stairs you can access the shore or a couple of caves, and there are also nearby trails to Lands End.
author: Steven C.

description: SUTRO BATHS IS MY FAVORITE SCENIC PLACE IN SAN FRANCISCO! :D This place is really breathtaking because the combination of history, ocean, and land formations give this place personality! I can definitely spend hours here watching the ocean waves and admiring the scenery. I also love the cave in the area because it makes me feel like I'm in Indiana Jones, and it leads to this amazing prehistoric-looking scenic area. Man, I need to visit this place again because it just gives me the feels :')
author: Nicole B.

description:
I only found out about this place after seeing a picture on Instagram and I knew immediately I had to see it for myself. This beautiful ruin used to be a bath house/ indoor swimming pool before it got destroyed. Just try to quietly take it all in, and imagine this place in its glory.

This was one of my favorite places in San Francisco. The views, the sunset, the ambiance - amazing. A must for those who like history and/or photography.
author: Helen D.

description:
Such a beautiful gem tucked away on the coast. If you're looking for a family day of exploring, climbing the rocks, and coast views, then this is the trip to take.

Our family is always looking for new adventures and Sutro Baths is a definite is you're a resident of the Bay. 

The views and surrounding trails are immediately easy for anyone to do. I know most people find hikes exhaustingly hard, but this is more of a walking hike with some stair and rock climbing at your leisure. For the most part, starting from the top near the cafe, you can determine how far you want to trek.

Along the way is a labyrinth, sitting areas with amazing views, rocks for climbing, and shoreline stops.

After you're done, indulge in a warm beverage at the cafe and relax in the calm busy-ness around you filled with tourists, locals, and kids alike. Wonderful fun that we are sure to experience again.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Looks like everyone on here has the same thought as me. GO! One of the most beautiful sights I've seen.. Just wow. 

I also saw running trails, pets, benches, and etc when we walked around here. I may not be from SF, but I will for sure be back when I visit. I keep looking at my trip pictures and I look at these longer haha.

I could tell parking is tight, I would carpool. Sutro also has all kinds of steps to go on... so bring sneakers/shoes you don't mind getting dirty/getting sand in. :) I can also detect this place being an amazing date place. Lol. Proposal place :P 

Anyyyyywayyyy, I am jealous of Cali folks who live here and have this near them. Atlanta is great and all, but Sutro beats them all.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Sutro Baths, one of several places to go in San Francisco's Land's End, was on my bucket list for months before I finally made it. I kept canceling plans  because I worried about being cold, being too tired to hike, waking up too late, forgetting my DSLR and other things. Here's what I learned:

--- There'a parking lot right by the entrance staircase. Park there, hang out at the baths for a while, and if you want more exercise follow the trails to the right for amazing views of the golden gate and Pacific Ocean. 

--- Wear layers, don't carry a bag. I carried a huge purse with a sweater and my DSLR, but it just got in the way of climbing the rocks around the baths. If you really want to explore the nooks and crannies of the caves and structures, you'll need as much balance and agility as possible. Next time I'll tie a sweater around my waist and carry just my camera phone in my pocket, maybeee my DSLR around my neck.

--- It's not really a hike. You can walk to the baths and walk and/or jog the trails around Land's End; they aren't very strenuous and there are stairs at most of the steep parts. Easy enough for all ages. There were a number of people walking their dogs around here.

--- I probably would have enjoyed going alone with a camera, but I'm glad I went with someone else. Its a great family or date place if you're looking to do something outdoors. Scenic, lots of people but still some semi-private areas to talk in, not much fitness required, beautiful and fun.
author: Varsha S.

description: Beautiful place to explore. There's so much to do in this area- Go down to the baths, walk through the tunnels, touch the Pacific Ocean, hike Lands End, go around the cliff house, visit the tourist shop and learn about the history, walk down to Ocean Beach, hike around Sutro Heights Park. Place can be chilly with the fog. Sunset is stunning. Definitely a great place to bring visitors, and you're usually able to find parking.
author: Joanna L.

description: Sutro baths is hands down amazing! Coming here for the first time I wish that I lived in the 1900s when this place was booming. Besides the plentiful abundance of bird poop and the nasty water, I absolutely loved the area. It reminds me a playground designed for adults. When you're here, make sure to explore every inch and check out the caves too! It makes for epic pictures though :) lands end is around the corner so hit that up too
author: Bryan W.

description: Great free place to site see while you are in San Francisco. I find it interesting to see how people lived a century ago. It's nothing but ruins now but with the pictures you can see what once was. You can also walk 1/4 mile past it on the trails that used to be the rail lines and get a great view of the Golden Gate.
author: Chad W.

description:
I thought it was pretty cool to see the sutro baths & read up on some of the history as to why they are now pretty much desolate. . . there's graffiti on some of the concrete, but it's still a cool find. 

definitely check it out if you have time, but if you're only here for a little while then make sure you check out the painted ladies and definitely check out the golden gate heights stair cases on moraga street :) -MUST SEE!!
author: Brooke W.

description: Absolutely breathtaking to see, esp since it is part of Land's End. The views are spectacular and my dog loved running around the beach area. The rocks and the cave are absolutely beautiful. The stairs going down can be a little but much for some people, many steps and the downhill to go furhter down to the beach is very steep and has a caution sign so be careful. The only bathrooms are at the top at Lands End Outlook so you will have to hold it. Dogs are supposed to be on leash until the beached area which is connected to Ocean Beach. Great photo opportunities and great place to relax.
author: Christine V.

description:
Whenever friends visit San Francisco and ask me for something unique to do, I send them to Sutro Baths. It's not at the top of many tourist lists (probably because it's a little far from flashy Fisherman's Wharf), but it's well worth the trip.

Who:  Sutro Baths

What:  Ruins from a 19th century privately-owned swimming pool complex

When:  On sunny days, it's wonderful. On gross days, it's incredibly eerie. Personally, I think you win in both situations

Where:  A rugged piece of coast on the Pacific Ocean just north of Cliff House. Park in the lot or walk from the restaurant or Ocean Beach. Or, if you're feeling outdoorsy, walk from the Land's End Trail 

Why:  It's bizarre and beautiful

As a bonus, if the weather is nice, check out Camera Obscura behind the Cliff House. It's another strange artifact from yesteryear.
author: Nick K.

description: really beautiful! i went around 10:30am just as the fog was rolling away. definitely worth a visit.
author: Suzanne G.

description:
This place is an absolute gem in San Francisco and a perfect place to be on a sunny, clear day. I did some online researching about the Sutro Baths before coming here, and was so excited by the idea that this used to be a large indoor swimming arena less than 50 years ago. Upon arriving, I was definitely not disappointed. Maybe it was my active imagination in play, but I loved seeing the ruins: the old, mossed-over stairs down to the pool, the wrecked walls, the random pipe lines etc. Walking along the paths between the pools really made me wonder how/what it was like back when the pools were functioning. The views out to the ocean are incredibly mesmerizing.

If you are braver and make it closer to the edge, be wary of occasional ocean sprays! The water that is now in the pools is quite gross and green, but otherwise, this historic landmark is very scenic. If you climb up the stairs, you there is an even more breathtaking view of the city itself and the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Hurnan V.

description: There's really not much to say...Beautiful sight to see if you're around the area on a sunny Day! Whether you're here as part of a hike around Land's end or looking for a great photo op, this is a fun playground for an adventurer who appreciates natural beauty.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Adolph Sutro opened the world's largest indoor natatorium in 1896 on edge of the Pacific ocean in San Francisco. I marvel what it would have been like to visit during its heyday with its seven separate pools of fresh and salt waters. A glazed roof with thousands of panes of glass allowed sunlight to filter in and patrons could dive into the waters in a myriad of ways including slides, diving boards, and trampolines!

In the mid-60s, the baths burned and what remains are the ruins of one man's vision. I have visited multiple times since I was a kid and each time, love the views and the feel of the environs. As an adult, a long constitutional after a meal is absolutely the best way to spend an hour or two. But take care, some of the paths can get slippery and there are signs warning of high tide knocking visitors into the water.
author: Kristine H.

description:
Why are we not rebuilding this?! Such a beautiful ruin of an old bathhouse right on the edge of the sea. I've done the Sutro Baths two ways:

1. Park in the parking lot right by the visitor's center and Cliff House and walk like 10 yards to the trail at the top of the baths. This is quick, easy, and perfect for those without a lot of time.

2. Park in the same parking lot, but take the Land's End hiking trail. The walk is 20 min or so and leads to a path that takes you down to the bottom of the baths. It's a pretty walk and gets you to part of the bath you might have missed if you do #1.

I suggest going in the late afternoon for the glowing light; it's gorgeous. Casual attire (I even wore flip-flops and had no problem walking down there).
author: Ashley E.

description: This "bath" or the olden days swimming pool has some history behind it. If you are interested in SF history, or exploring the cave down here, or photography this would be an interesting spot to check out. The Cliff House is right up there with two restaurants in it. We checked out the menu and it contains pretty typical stuff; just add $5 to every dish that you can find elsewhere, for the great ocean view...
author: Claire W.

description:
Be careful when you come here!  I hurt my knee trying to step up on this section there.  
This is a really cool site.  Made me do my research before deciding to check it out.  It's really cool to check out and explore.   It's disappointing to see the graffiti and trash but the scenery and beach will make up for it.  It's breathtaking.  I liked walking in the cave also.  Really nice place to hike and explore.
author: Chrissie O.

description: I finally hiked down to Sutro Baths after hiking the Land's End trail.  I'd been near here so many times in the past and never bothered.  I now know why my inner intuition never told me to explore earlier.  There's really not a whole lot to see/explore.  Sure, you can imagine what was there 100 years ago.  I'm glad I got this out of the way always wondering before if it was worthwhile.  Don't waste your time.
author: Tim L.

description: Nice views. Way less to "explore" than expected. Not worth making the trip over if this is all you plan on doing on this side of the city. My friends and I hiked the lands end trail after to cover up the disappointment that was the sutro baths.
author: Trang B.

description:
Such a BEAUTIFUL place to come when it's SUNNY in San Francisco!! They have a Visitor's Center (aka Land's End Lookout) so there is FREE PARKING AVAILABLE PLUS RESTROOMS (they were pretty darn clean too)!!!! Don't get too happy though, on weekends it's usually HARD to find a spot and I ended up stalking people as they left to grab their space! (We came around 1PM on a Sunday) There is also a Lookout Cafe inside the visitor's center which offers coffee, espressos, sandwiches, salads, and soups! (Open daily 9AM-5PM) 

There is a hiking trail--so wear comfortable clothes and tennis shoes with a GRIP-- that takes you down towards the Sutro baths ruins (I even saw some people walking ON the narrow walls of these old baths!! If you're brave enough you can join them!) and also through a neat cave (VERY SANDY so again wear TENNIS SHOES!) where you can walk towards the Golden Gate Bridge! Perfect place for pictures!! The views are so breathtaking I literally couldn't put my camera down because I wanted to capture EVERYTHING!!! They even have a rock with a heart shaped cutout! So cute.. and ROMANTIC!!! Since one of my girlfriends came in flip flops we didn't hike too far but just enough to get a spectacular view of the bridge and the ocean! Don't worry, I saw plenty of small children AND pets complete this hike so it is very FAMILY/PET FRIENDLY! I would definitely recommend coming back here during a sunrise/sunset! I can only imagine how magnificent it would be to watch all the different color changes! 

Overall, a MUST SEE when you visit San Francisco! I can't believe I never knew about this place before! The drive here isn't bad and you get to see all the beautifully built houses along the way! They even have a restaurant nearby, The Cliff House ($$$), that overlooks the ocean!
author: Steph M.

description:
Since I made my old review, this place has been "reworked". There is now a building nearby offer gifts, there is now a good parking lot  and trails.

Still a great place to check out and see.
author: Roger A.

description: I love this place! I've been here before a longgg time ago, but recently came again. Lots to explore with several different trails you can take. I took my puppy here as soon as he got all his puppy shots, so this hike was basically his first ever "walk" haha. We came across so many other dogs (all friendly, yay!) and the hike was a breeze, which was good because I was hoping for a more relaxing hike for the pup and I. There were great little sneak peaks/views of the Golden Gate along the way too! I come from South Bay and I think it's worth the drive (which isn't too far) but if this isn't your destination and you just happen to be looking for something to do in the city, I also think it's worth making a pit stop for.
author: Justine V.

description: Went to the city for a lax day with some co workers hiked the coastal trail. We got a beautiful day though even stormy days turn out just as gorgeous any time I'm in SF. Easy hike, beautiful views friendly atmosphere.
author: Lily A.

description:
Sutro Baths is one of my favorite place to visit in San Francisco. 
By walking there and thinking of its glorious history makes me feel great. 
It is definitely a nice place to take a short walk and explore the ocean view during weekends or evenings.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Awesome historical spot in SF. It's just past the cliff house and there's plenty of parking in the lots. The monument above has a spot to fill up your water bottle. You take these long stairs down and can explore the dark cave avoiding the puddles. 

The actual ruins are an adventure because you can get an adrenaline rush walking on top of them. A little sketch along the edges near the water but you wouldn't hurt your self if you jumped back in between the walls. Very cool spot and the good weather, sea salt smell, and sound of waves crashing is epic.
author: Marty J.

description:
Sutro baths is fun, especially during the night. Dont' worry, the Zodiac isn't there during the night, hopefully. Make sure to bring a flashlight or download a flashlight app.

I went at 12AM with my friends. We entered this cave and then when we exited the baths, there was this silhouette waiting for us atop of the stairs. The dude asked in a high pitched voice, "d0 u like LAZER LIGHTS?!?" My friend answered "yes." Dude replied back to us in his normal voice, "Good answer." I don't know what would happen if we didn't give him a good answer, but that was fun!

There's a lot of bums there.
author: Hina W.

description:
The famous Sutro Baths: such an amazing sight to behold.

My fellow Yelper and BFF drove me to the Sutro Baths one morning saying it was just something I had to see... and she was right. After hiking down the hill to the ruins we walked on top of the old walls and explored. I felt like such a child on a grand adventure. I'm with her in saying that SF should renovate and reopen these amazing bath houses that once were. 

It's such a beautiful thing, to stand on top of ruins next to the ocean. The waves were crashing and the wind was in my hair. Such peace. Such bliss. Everyone should make it out here at least once in their lives. 

Random note, but when we were there someone (or aliens!?) had put out giant frozen cubes of ice and arranged them around the skeletal walls. Just look at my photos!!! I have no idea why they were put there but judging by the rate at which they were melting, I would say earlier that morning. Random but fun.
author: Leslie D.

description: very amazing place to go alone or with a group , it's very relaxing and not to difficult to get to . highly recommended .
author: Aliza W.

description: This place is breathtaking! I come here every chance I get and I recommend it to all my friends. It's a great place to take a walk, enjoy the view and just relax.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Absolutely AMAZING! Every time I discover a SF gem, i am so thankful for being able to live in one of the most enchanting cities.  It makes you appreciate San Francisco so much more :)

This is a beautiful location to get some photoshoot on! I have seen my friends get their engagement sessions done here. The weather is definitely a hit or miss. It can get super windy in this area since it is pretty much located right next to the ocean!

There is something mysterious and enchanting about the Sutro Bath Ruins.  Mr. MC and I actually came here after a hike on Land's End Trail.  It is definitely a spot for a daytime date, or just to stroll around and take pictures.  If you are interested in neither, than you can simply pick your spot, sit down and enjoy the ocean breeze.  Or be like me :) http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=d3PoKXEvQPC9JCuLtnrtJA&userid=gmaWUt02_ixItBN2gQsMGQ

I absolutely love climbing around the ruins. Just be careful not to fall into the water and cracks in between! :)
author: Stephy L.

description: Best. Day. Ever.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
Love
Hiking
And the views.
Good history
Too but signs don't tell as well as they could.
author: Justin L.

description: What once was the site of the historic Sutro Baths is now a decrepit reminder of the Guilded Age in San Francisco. There's really not much to see. It looks dilapidated and war-torn. There's garbage, weeds, and dirty water. They probably should have built something nice over the old site. Have you seen the movie Harold and Maude? There's a good scene where Harold is visiting the Sutro Baths. This is near Land's End, the ocean, and the Cliff House restaurant. There's a fun tunnel to visit near the rocks.
author: Denise C.

description:
As a native I take a lot for granted including this wonderful landmark. Yesterday hubby and I came over in our quest to spot a river otter who has been named Sutro Sam frolicking in the fresh water pond.  He was first spotted back in September 2012 by some bird watchers.

We parked in the newly improved Lands End parking lot and took the Sutro Baths trail down.

We didn't spot Sam, but what a beautiful wintry sunny day it was.  Watching the low tide, the waves, and the Pacific Ocean and reflecting on life.  

You can explore the Sutro Baths ruins and attempt to get a sense of what it was like when it was an enclosed bath house right along the Pacific Ocean.
author: Shirley N.

description: Great to see the ocean, a piece of history, get your exercise and climb around.  Cliffs, Ocean, Views, Caves, what else could you ask for? Parking wasn't bad, bathrooms are mmmeh there.
author: Meena N.

description:
It is a pretty sight :) make sure to go when there's sun. My friends and I made a mistake going when it was really cloudy, cold, windy and sprinkled a bit. I think it would have been prettier if there was sun and I'm sure sunsets/sunrise here are amazing. 
It's a pretty nice walk/hike. It gave me a work out going up those stairs lol! There are many trails to choose from. Since I had my toddler with me, we went the easier/safer route. However we couldn't go all the way down to the beach because the pathway were rocks. If you really want to explore the place I wouldn't recommend bringing young children. It's too risky for them.
The cave was also pretty cool. It was pretty small/ short and understand how it could get crowded quick if there's a lot of people. Be careful when you walk, it's pretty slippery due to the moist from the ocean water.
Overall, I'm glad I came :) i heard its a place to visit in SF and understand why. Next time I will come back when the weather is a little better.
author: Janneane J.

description: What an awesome place! It offers abandoned ruins, the beach, numerous hiking trails, sea caves and great views of the Golden Gate!! FREE parking and clean bathrooms!
author: Michael S.

description:
This place is quite awesome despite it being the remnants of what once was a great local bath house from the earlier part of the last century. I'm going to have to channel my geekery here and say that the Sutro Ruins reminded me of Zanarkand from Final Fantasy X, particularly on the days I come here when the fog is rolling in. 

Creepy, yet beautiful.
author: Jaye C.

description:
Hard to believe that this was once the site of seven large pools - one fresh and six saltwater - and tons of history! Once opened in 1896, it mysteriously burned down in 1966. My great uncle used to go swimming here too! 

Located close to the Cliff House, you can access this area from a side trail from the Cliff House parking area or at the top of the parking lot before you wind down the road. 

Great views from here and I only recently found the cave at the bottom! Totally reminded me of a scene from Pirates of the Carribean. If you go in the cave, you can actually see the water rush in from the sea through a little rock window. It sounds awesome but prepared to get wet if you get a large wave coming through. 

Nice to get a touch of nature in the big city.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
SUCH A BEAUTY OF A PLACE. My friend who likes to go hiking showed me this place on a random exploration day, and she said she uses it if ever she needs to get her thoughts together :) 

This place has many different viewpoints on the gorgeous waves below. You can easily slip and die if you climb into places you're not supposed to go, but life is too short to worry about that. The coolest views are in the dangerous places P:

If you don't think the view is pretty, go into Instagram and up the saturation on your pictures. The true underlying colors of the ocean are insane, gorgeous, better than sapphires, better than all the jewels in the world.
author: JoAnn C.

description:
Neat little place located at Lands End

Not sure the history since nothing was really posted but I enjoyed the visit. There is a cave you can walk through and of course the ruins to explore. You aren't supposed to climb any of the walls but everyone of course was. Made you feel like a little kid who stumbled upon some ancient lost city. It was fun just to walk around and climb and such. Little bit of innocence in the grown-up world

Only ding is it is sort of dirty. Old socks, trash. shoes. Shame really. Needs a bit of a clean up in that respect

Othe that that the baths is a great picture opportunity and something different then the usual fare
author: Rachael C.

description:
On a blustery afternoon, as the sky glows from the afternoon sunlight, clouds coming in from the Pacific, the ambiance at Sutro Baths was sublime!

Whether you're stopping by during the day or as the sun drops over the horizon, the Sutro Baths are a fun time! There's a decent sized parking lot adjacent to the visitors center, and with a bit of patience, you're just a hop, skip, and a jump away from exploring a piece of history!

The view of the ocean is a refreshing change of pace from the urban hustle and bustle of Downtown SF. You can't really sink your toes in the water, but you can get pretty close. You can explore what remains of the Sutro baths, climbing in and out of the craggy walls. There's a small cave you can walk through, watching the waves as they come crashing beneath, and at the end admire the rocky formations and the waves that beat down on them.

Walking up another path, you're able to look from above towards the baths, the ocean, and the west side of the Golden Gate bridge. A really enjoyable spot to relax, despite the crowds. Not as noisy as you might think, so make sure to stop by on your next visit in town!
author: Kevin J.

description: I haven't been here since I was a kid when I used to run around and stuff. and I heard from my cousin and a few people when they went into the caves it's haunted in because I guess all the Native American people have died. if you take photos you could see the orbs in your pictures they might want to check it out I don't like that part that's too scary, other than that you should come and check it out I love the old photos I remember seeing when they had the pool there that was a time when my mom is around in the 30's and 40's that was cool.I remember Playland too I think in 1970 I'm not sure when they destroyed it that was fun.
author: Lizzie G.

description:
This is a beautiful location that makes you wonder what life was like back then.  Considering all you see are the ruins of what used to be, one would hope for a revamp of earlier days.

The weather can be hit or miss but this is a fun place to walk around on short hikes and play on the rocks as the waves come crashing in next to you.  Just be careful to watch your step as it would be easy to slip off and fall.  Not recommended for young kids or clumsy adults.  Stay on the path!
author: Kevin J.

description: I've lived in the Bay Area for most of my life and haven't been here until this past weekend. I didn't know what I was missing. It was a beautiful day to see the Sutro bath ruins and cave. Since Monday was President's day holiday, there was a good number of people and there was no parking at any of the lots. Had to drive down further and park in the beach parking lot after the Cliff House restaurant.  There is a little walking to do but not much. This place is good for adults, kids, and your pets. Definitely a place to check out on a beautiful sunny day. The fog did move in as we were leaving and it did get a little cold. Suggest bringing a light jacket just in case. Highly recommend!
author: S L.

description:
I was a bit sceptical when I was told that the ruins of a 19th century swimming pool was a San Francisco must-see. I have to admit that Sutro Baths is worth a visit though. It's a beautiful area, and the remains of the Baths just add to the beauty. 

There's plenty to see and do nearby, almost all of it connected to the Bath's namesake Adolph Sutro. Sutro Heights Park, Land's End Lookout and the Camera Obscura are all within a short distance of Sutro Bath.
author: Dave H.

description:
I can only imagine how awesome it must have been to swim and simply relax in a bath house adjacent to the vast ocean. This place is absolutely abundant in history and one of my favorite things to do whenever I'm here is to compare and contrast the old pictures to what remains of it. It's like a puzzle and each time I visit this place, I make a new discovery - the cave, the remains of a waterfall spewing water down to the pool closest to the ocean, the set of stairs that once led down to the saltwater pool, etc.

This is also a nice place to take your significant other. Grab a couple of light snacks and maybe even some libations, hike up the stairs past the cave and have a little picnic while enjoying the sunset and gorgeous view.
author: May D.

description: Cool to see the ruins.  Not hard to get to.  Difficult to find parking though.
author: J W.

description:
I love Sutro Baths.

Came here with the boy on one of SF's gorgeous days. I swear, the view of the ocean on a sunny day from the top area of the ruins took my breath away. It was so gorgeous, I could hardly believe how uncrowded it was. Sure, there were people there, but they weren't the touristy types, you know? They were more local people, who either went there regularly, or had heard of the place through friends, and decided to come out.

Decided to walk along the ruins, pretending I was on a balance beam [what can I say - I'm such a little kid sometimes :P], and just wandered around for a bit. The cave is pretty cool, although I was wearing sandals, and the gravel going underneath my feet was... not cool -_- There's a spot where you can see the waves crashing underneath the ruins, which was really trippy, too.

I definitely want to come back here on a stormy day, because as beautiful as this place is in the sunshine, I bet it's a totally different kind of beautiful on a cloudy, gray day.

And how many other places can say the same?
author: Amy L.

description: My friends and I started our Lands End hike at the Sutro Baths. What you see is basically the ruins of a now defunct public swimming area that wasn't making enough money and was left to ruin over time. What you see almost look like ancient ruins in a European city. The ruins look out onto the water and I can only imagine how beautiful this sunset would be.
author: Joanna V.

description: Went here on a sunny Friday! It was so beautiful and the skies were clear but of course it was a little windy. Make sure to check out the inside of the tunnel! So cool! I would recommend wearing good walking shoes and bringing a camera! Great place to take beautiful pictures
author: Angelica V.

description:
My friend took me here years ago, on the start of my long love affair with San Francisco. And oh, this made me fall in love with this city like an over-eager teenager. 

The view of the ruins is spectacular, with grand pools of reflecting water leading to the ocean. It's really like something out of a dream. And so majestic and beautiful on a sunny SF day.

As a tourist, it's something not to be missed, for sure. And I'm pretty sure this would be my go-to thinking spot if I lived in the city. It's peaceful, grand...and somehow intimate all at once. It's a little out of the way, all the way at the northwest peak of SF, but worth every minute of out-of-the-way travel to get here.
author: Ellie W.

description: Absolutely gorgeous. Such a fun spot to check out. Great views and fun hikes! Came here with my boyfriend and we had a really nice time! Recommend bringing anyone here, it's beautiful
author: Victoria G.

description: So romantic! I was shocked as soon as I arrived there. I lived half of year in SF.,I didn't know there has such a wonderful place until my friend show its photo to me. I think it's one of my favorite places in U.S. The view is great , and the ruins of bath looks like it's telling some story to you. I also recommend if you go there, please not to wear dress and high heel, it would be terrible, I swear!
author: Li S.

description:
Reading some other reviews from locals I'm a little less ashamed that as a SF native I visited this famous spot for the first time last weekend. Now that I know about it it's going to be one of the first places I suggest to visiting friends and family. It's a truly unique spot, with lots of cool nooks and crannies that you're completely free to roam around, and of course that breathtaking ocean view. On most days of the year you'll need to be bundled up as that beach air can get quite nippy, and wear comfy shoes as you'll be climbing lots of stairs and hills. Bring a camera because there are beautiful vistas wherever you turn. You'll feel like you're in the Mediterranean!!

After you're done if you're in a fancy mood you can have a meal at the historic Cliff House or just down the beach a little at Beach Chalet. Or just go into the Sunset and get some Chinese food on the cheap!
author: Christina P.

description:
When you think of landmarks and tourist attractions, a lot of them seem boring and the kind of place you look at for a minute then say to yourself, "is that it?". 
The sutro baths is nothing from that.
You can get there by public transit or drive. It's below lands end, and there's the park before you reach the pools. 
This place is amazing. A must see for locals and tourist.
The pools are stagnant bodies of water in concrete. They're pretty disgusting and seagulls congregate there but they're so amazing to look at (despite the pounds of bird poo). 
There's also a bunch of history regarding the area. They do free walking tours there weekly where they talk about the historical significance of the sutro baths. Unfortunately I couldn't attend one but just google search San Francisco free walking tours and the website should come up.
Bring a jacket because it may get chilly since it's by the water. 
Just simply put, a must visit and worth the trip and walk up hill (yes... It's up hill).
author: Julia S.

description:
I actually stumbled across the Sutro Baths by accident and when I did, I was struck with complete awe. The ruins of the Sutro Baths lie in haunting stillness as its skeleton reveals the once thriving history of its past. What was once an eccentric, popular bathhouse, is now an open stony labyrinth alongside some of the most forceful, unruly waves. It was really wonderful being able to walk up to the Sutro Baths and explore this piece of history at face value.

The caves in this location are another thing of beauty. To the side of the cave, you can peer over the cliff and just stare out into the ocean for hours. Such a gorgeous view.

Most definitely a great place to visit.
author: Ann S.

description:
Sutro Baths is part of Lands End, and in my opinion is the highlight of the entire area. The site is actually the remains of a former indoor swimming center from the late 1800s. Most of the walls are gone but you can see where the pool was. As you walk around the area, you can find some of the old pipework too.

You can find it at the bottom of the cliff, with a path and staircase from the major parking lot. The walk down can get a little steep, but it's manageable. Some sections will have stairs to make it easier. There are also some terraced areas so that you can see the site from above.

You can walk along the former walls right next to the water. Usually they aren't slippery but do be careful not to fall into the water. The paths are really narrow around the pool, but you should have enough room to walk past people if you're careful.

There are great photo opportunities all over this area. From above at the terrace, along the hills, right next to the former pools, or down on the rocks right against the ocean.. Despite being a destroyed building, it's an amazing sight to see.
author: Allen C.

description:
This place lets you escape from the daily hustle and bustle of our busy lives albeit for a moment - but it's still a good escape.

You get instantly transformed to another era of the glory of yesteryears - similar to visiting the ruins of old Rome. Although its ruins are beautifully carved by the hands of Father Time. 

You can feel like a 10 year old kid exploring this place and letting your imagination run wild. The cave draws you in with the curiosity of a cat. Even if you've been here before, you still find something new to marvel at.

Enjoy a hike with your dogs on the trails or head to the beach to cool off. Just be careful climbing those cliffs, a wrong step might land you a trip to the hospital. But you will enjoy the view, and maybe have a romantic moment as you watch the sun set over the Pacific.
author: John G.

description:
The Sutro Baths are situated in a beautiful location and the width of the ruins makes it easy to walk around and explore the baths without worrying about falling into the water or rocks. But the baths themselves...I'm sorry, I just didn't find them all that appealing. They were far too modern and industrial-looking, with uniform slabs of concrete surrounded by the type of debris you'd find at a construction site. The dirty, stagnant water (rife with mosquitos and other bugs) is a huge turn-off too. 

I've been to Bath, England and I wasn't expecting these to look like those baths, but even on their own merits, I didn't see much to recommend them. It's still worth making the somewhat steep trek down though, if only to get closer to the water.
author: Josephine L.

description:
One of my favorite places in San Francisco! So unique and such a fun place to explore. Good for dates, group outings, kids, grandparents, everyone!

PRO TIP: Don't wear nice shoes. RIP my Tory Burches :(
author: Sophia V.

description: This place is absolutely beautiful. It was a wonderful place for my shutterbug friend to take out engagement photos as the backgrounds of the ruins with the backdrop of the ocean is absolutely phenomenal.
