The only reason I give it 4 stars is accessibility for those of us who have mobility issues. It was a good day for me health wise but I paid dearly for climbing those hills they are no joke! If you are a hiker or an outdoorsy type this place was made for you!!! There are paths for the disabled but the grades are still very steep.
author: April M.

description:
I heard about Sutro Baths online before our trip out to San Francisco, so I made it a priority to stop there.  What a great idea!!  It was way more amazing than I imagined, and the weather was perfect (we were there in late September).  

We had a wonderful time climbing around on the ruins.  I appreciate that you don't have to follow the paths, which are arduous enough in their own right.  Great views here, and the ocean breeze was lovely.  You can't take a bad photo at this place.
author: Johanna K.

description:
A great day trip destination and a good starting point to hike and discover SF! 

Apparently San Francisco has ruins. Sutro baths (or what's left of it) used to be a large enclosed bath house that was built in the late 1800s.  It sits right on the beach and is tucked in between small cliffs.  It's also a great place see Point Lobos or start a hike along the Lands End Trail. The Land's end trail is great because you're surrounded by nature and it follows along the bay and beach areas. The trail also leads to the Legion of Honor, which is a totally amazing museum. 

If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of SF, this is a great place to get a way- Nature. Views. Serenity!
author: Nadiyah S.

description: Lived in the Bay Area my whole life and finally visited the Sutro Baths. Place is pretty cool, with lots of great views and trails to walk. Will come again and do more exploring.
author: Ryan G.

description:
It's hard not to give this place 5 stars. It's freaking gorgeous. My favorite place in the City actually. The best part? It faces west. Therefore, it's ideal for sunset photos.

My suggestion: check up the sunset time. Get there at least 30 min beforehand. Find a free parking spot somewhere close to Sutro Heights Park (rather than deal with street parking along the Great Highway or the limited spots near the Cliffhouse). Walk over (5min).

Soak in all the wonders of life. :)
author: Sharon J.

description: We came here during sunset and the view was gorgeous! You can walk up the hill or walk down directly to the ruins.  I tried to do the former but my boyfriend wanted to exploit my fear of heights and watch me suffer so we went down to the ruins.  Be careful as you can a) slip and fall into murky, dirty, smelly water, filled with God knows what or b) tumble down shore towards a rocky death.  All kidding aside, the ruins were beautiful and it wasn't as dangerous as I thought. The view was well worth it.  Also, no sightings of Sutro Sam while we were there :(
author: Grace S.

description: Came here once and it was pretty cool. It's right near the ocean so it's even nicer. It does get really windy and cold so make sure to bring a wind breaker! Photos here are great - bring a tripod for even better pictures! :)
author: Anne R.

description: Beautiful place! So many places to take pictures, too. There's a slight breeze, a beach, a cave, and ruins! Must see! :)
author: Linda T.

description: Interesting area.  Tons of free parking at ocean beach or right by the visitor center for the sutro baths.  We got there around 11 on a Sunday and had no issues at all finding parking.  We parked the bottom of the hill so we could walk up and see a view of ocean beach as well.  Overall this is an easy hike with great views of the ocean.  I went a little further to point lobos and the upper sutro trails, again not far at all.  If you get the map from nps the distance looks far but its really not.  In the future I wouldn't mind hiking further down to eagles point or somewhere like that.  This place was crowded with tourists but its such a big area it didn't bother me too much.  Check out the visitor center to get the whole story of the sutro baths.
author: Kate F.

description:
I'm so sad that it took me so long to discover this place.  After living in SF for several years, I couldn't believe I never visited Sutro Baths before.  Makes me quite sad.  

God, this place is amazing.  Honestly.  GO NOW.  You're welcome.
author: Criselle O.

description:
Could I be, was I there?
It felt so crystal....in the air
I still want to drown, whenever you leave
Please teach me gently, how to breathe

And I'll cross oceans, like never before
So you can feel...the way I feel it too
And I'll mirror images back at you
So you can see...the way I feel it too

[This pretty much sums up the sutro baths for me]

*drops mic*
author: Lydia L.

description:
Oh the Outer Richmond. You are so far, so very far from anywhere I want to be in the city. 

But how I love your Sutro Baths. The Sutro Baths went the ways of Playland, and stand as relics of a San Francisco that I will never know.

Making the trek out to the avenues on a sunny day is glorious, climb over the ruins next to the beach. Take in your scenery. Appreciate the city, the area which Hunter S. Thompson admired from the near by Seal Rock Inn and exclaimed:

"out here at the far end of Geary Street: this is the end of the line, for buses and everything else, the western edge of America."

This might be the most hipster review I've ever written, but I don't care.
author: Jenny U.

description: Such a unique place to visit. I'be visited the Bay Area many times but this visit I decided to check out the baths. It's beautiful during sunset. I highly recommend exploring if you're ever in San Francisco.
author: Mare V.

description: What a beautiful spot! The ruins are really cool and the views are unreal. A must visit for all ages.
author: Kim K.

description:
I read about the history of the Sutro Baths before visiting and learned that less than a century ago, it was a bustling busy bath house that had great views of the ocean and was powered by the waves - with freshwater pools and saltwater pools. Sadly, it was burned down and left as ruins.

Today, those pools are still filled with water, obviously not filtered or water for bathing, but during sunset, the reflection of the pools make this place perfect for photos. There's actually a small cave on the beach where the generator used to be - you can walk into it.

There is a trail that wraps along the coast for a while and has spectacular views of the Pacific ocean!
author: Kevin L.

description: The Sutro Bath Ruins are so cool! It's a really easy stop if you're hiking Land's End, so make sure you take the time to trek downward and enjoy the view.
author: Kelly R.

description: Beautiful sunset and then a walk to the beach. good evening to spend around the area and an easy trek to the Baths.
author: Rachiyta R.

description: Great coastline stroll. Definitely a great for walking around old ruins which make this a great stop on a long bike ride, or for photo shoots.
author: Regina D.

description: Awesome place to wander around and take in the majesty of the ocean =) There is a convenient parking lot nearby which is right next to a visitor center that has some pretty interesting exhibits. Restrooms are also located in the building. The BF and I had a lot of fun wandering around the ruins and checking out the old remnants of the baths. There was even a cave/tunnel on the far right side that was fun to explore.
author: Sam F.

description: Such a great place to visit in the city!  Beautiful view of the ocean and the bath ruins are really interesting to check out too!  The parking wasn't bad when I went here and there was a little hike to get down to the baths.  Really nice place to come to relax and enjoy the scenery.
author: Kylie S.

description:
I've been coming to this spot for years my brother use to live right next to ocean beach in the late 90s but every time I'm in the city we stop by to see the changes and just relax in the area.

Sutro baths is a great place to vist and it's even more amazing to know how much history has been there and it's also been left alone since the Sutro Bath diaster. It's an awesome spot to walk around and just hang out and/or take some pictures. Just becareful if it's foggy and wet you might slip somewhere. There are also a few caves that you can go down through, once again don't go during high tide. On sunny days its great. It's awesome because you can tell by the ruins were a few things were. Like left over stairs, pipes, and balconies. 

The old cliff house to use house a lot of the arcades that are no located at Musée Mécanique , the cliff house then and now over look the area where Sutro baths once stood. Also the cliff house use to hold a lof of articles and photos of what the Sutro Baths use to look like, some of the history about it and photos of the damage the fires had had on the place and the reason why it is not longer standing. 

A great place to take a walk and also you can walk through Sutro Heights park, located at Ocean Beach and another close landmark is Queen Wilhelmina Tulip Garden which is at the end Golden Gate park. Many things to see in close distance. Check it out and have an adventure!
author: Steph S.

description: Love this place. Pictures don't do justice. It's  place you have to go to when you're in SF!
author: Rachel A.

description:
The Sutro Baths are the remnants of a lost age.  I imagine that in a post-Apocalyptic world many cities will look like this.  The Sutro Baths were large baths destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and were never rebuilt.  All that's left is the foundation with pools of water on a cliff overlooking the Pacific.  You can stand on top of the cliffs and look down upon the ruins and the great view or you can take stairs down to the ruins themselves.  You can walk on the concrete foundation.

The baths are part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area.  There are adjacent parks with trees and trails to explore.  Just south of the baths is the Cliff House, then the sandy shore of Ocean Beach stretching down the coast.

As to be expected, the crowds are much larger on weekends especially when there is nice weather.
author: Ryan L.

description:
When I come here, somehow I feel I should have a handlebar mustache, a body-covering bathing suit and a ukulele as I sing "By the Sea, By the Sea, By the Beautiful Sea". But then I would imagine the police would tell me I already missed the Castro Halloween party and detain me for public indecency.

It seems a shame that you're not given much to read about the grand history of the baths originally built here at the turn of the last century - seven pools, an ice skating rink, a museum and a concert hall all encased in beautifully crafted glass and iron. Apparently it went to hell in a hand basket as the owners lost money hand to fist, so much so that it was in complete disrepair by the time a suspicious fire completely destroyed what was left of it in 1966. If you've ever been to the elaborate baths in Budapest, you can get some idea of what the Sutro Baths were about in the gilded age.

Now what you see are water-swept ruins of the foundation, nothing more. But it is worth perusing on a brisk day just to fantasize what a glorious attraction it must have been. Kind of like that scene where old Rose recalls the splendor of the Titanic from the barnacle-encrusted remains of the rusted shipwreck in that Leonardo movie I can't stand.

You should also take a stroll in the very moist cave tunnel to the right just to see the waves crashing on the rocks at the end, and there is a wide-open concrete terrace where if you cock your head, you can actually see one of the towers of the Golden Gate. Make sure to bundle up because that ocean wind will sneak up on you, and have a little breakfast nosh at the Seal Rock Inn beforehand.
author: Ed U.

description:
Super cool spot - you can still see the outlines of the old buildings that used to be the Sutro Baths.  Now: its a breezy ghost yard of old rubble.  Nice to walk around and imagine what used to be here. 

Lots of wildlife: the last couple times I've seen dolphins, herons, and even an otter playing in one of the pools. 

Wear some good shoes - it can be muddy, sandy and wet in and around the stairs and trails. 

Pop in to the gift store/museum at the top of the hill for a cup of hot chocolate or to get a souvenir or two.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I love hiking around here.  It's hard to imagine an elegant bathhouse existed in this area because the pools look disgusting.  SF critters have today made Sutro Baths their home.

Easter Egg:  If you're here when tides are very low, you can access and climb that rock hill.  Pretty awesome, huh?
author: Sam K.

description: Very pretty spot to view the ocean and hills along the shore. This is an easy, must-see stop for anybody into urban exploring. Make sure to walk through the old tram tunnel heading north from the cove. These are ruins and could be dangerous for young children (or clumsy adults). The climb back up the the parking area is more tiring than it appears.
author: Keith A.

description: It's quite a sight to behold, old ruins. I like coming here and walking around the ruins, enjoying the view, feeling the cold breeze.. It also leads to a new hiking trail. One of my favorite sites in SF :)
author: Stephen C.

description:
Good memories ... 

Relaxing, with the sun in your face, cool ocean breeze, and a million dollar view .. 

Great place to take friends from out of town and show them a quick glimpse of SF beauty..

Also a killer spot to medicate, then go right up Geary and your in food heaven. :)
author: Anthony S.

description:
I can't believe in the 8 years I've been living here, I only discovered Sutro Baths now! It's such a beautiful, scenic area.

You can walk through the caves. There are many flat paths to go hiking and biking, all the way to Baker Beach & Lands End. 

There are even a few cute restaurants nearby (Cliffhouse, Beach Chalet, & Louie's). 

So calm & relaxing. Definitely a must if you're visiting or just wanna get away!
author: Alysha K.

description:
History. Real history.

Try to imagine what must have here, when the Baths were in full swing. 

There were giants in those days.
author: George T.

description: I squeezed this place in on the last day of my trip to SF, and I'm so glad that I did. Great place to explore and enjoy the beauty of nature. I also walked up to the USS SF memorial which has great views of the bay and is a great place to watch the sunset. Would definitely return!
author: Simone C.

description:
Nature lovers, this is the spot to see! 

Living in HI, I'll admit that I'm surrounded by beautiful scenery and this place made me feel right at home. I'm not too sure of the history and details of the existence of this place, but if you're just looking to walk around, sit down, relax, you must visit here!

Also, a GREAT place to take gorgeous photos! There's also a cave that you can walk through as well (make sure you bring shoes that you don't mind getting sandy and wet!)
author: Sammie T.

description:
This is a very easy trail. Most is actually paved. I went down to the baths to try to see 'Sutro Sam" the otter but there were some disrespectful dog owners with their dogs right next to the baths and digging in the dirt next to the signs which say "dogs not allowed in this area and be quiet there is an endangered otter in the area" 

There is a cool cave you can check out and see the waves crash into the rocks and feel the salt spray. It's pretty intense. The wave action is quite strong. The wild flowers and the new visitor center are great!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Sutro Baths is definitely one of my favorite places to visit when I'm in the area, and honestly ... I'm not entirely sure why. 

It might be because this was one of the filming sites for "Harold and Maude," one of the greatest movies EVER made. When I realized this, my first time there, I was geeking out like you wouldn't believe. Sadly, though, the place where Bud Cort, Ruth Gordon, and Charles Tyner stood is closed to the public. The steps above the cave do look fairly dilapidated. 

Anyway, for anyone else who's just interested in some light hiking, Sutro Baths is as pleasant as any other walk. It's a relatively short walk downhill to the flooded bathhouse ruins and into the cave that used to house the water pump. You can take the steps through the little woodland area or hike back up the slope from whence you came. 

It's hit and miss with the tourists. Some days there'll be no one else there, other days there are crowds -- tons of people walking on the ruins while the cave is clogged with people waiting for the guy who's taking 20 minutes to photograph the view at the far end to move so they can get a chance to look and take forever with their own pictures.
author: Christine A.

description:
Some kind of nice ruins in San Francisco.  They're neat to look at for a few minutes, but then they get kind of gross due to all the trash, algae, and other grossness surrounded by them.  Yes, they're ruins, but a little maintenance would make the experience way better...particularly in terms of trash collecting, etc (or, more appropriately, if people would pick up after themselves and not trash the ruins...).

In any case, the hiking surrounding the ruins is great, and if you ignore all the trash and filth, the ruins can be quite a nice place to check out during a visit to San Francisco.
author: Brian B.

description: When the weather is nice, the views are amazing.  The trees, cliffs, ocean, etc.  There are trails you can walk and there's even a pretty big parking area.
author: Daniel B.

description: Beautiful place, we saw whales! Easy parking and gorgeous views. A little bit too much trash, I think they need to do a better job of cleaning the property, which is the only thing keeping it from perfection!
author: Mac S.

description: I love coming here because it's a beautiful combination of the historical remnants of the baths, a great walk, and wonderful view of Ocean Beach. We adore taking the dog out here for a quick walk or just coming out to see the sunset.
author: Shauna S.

description:
I think the hardest part of getting out of towners to visit the Sutro Baths is convincing them these baths have NOTHING to do with some of the other "happy ending" type places in SF.

Once you get past that, you're golden.  

It was a fantastic day that was accented by this unique attraction.

(You can tell when I run out of shit to talk about when I start using terms like "unique attraction")

Cmon, I'm 600+ reviews in and my job sucks the life out of me, what do you expect?

Ok, going back to the topic at hand....

The only negative about this place is the fact that the trails just keep going.  We ended up walking all the way to the Golden Gate and back.  

Given the fact that every activity in SF either involves the fattening of my ass and/or the slimming of my wallet, Sutro Baths is a nice change of pace that reverses the former and keeps the latter in check.

Pace.
author: Archie R.

description: Lovely spot. It was pretty cold but I didn't mind. Great views and very interesting. I'd like it if they'd open up some more of the ruins and cave to the public so that I'd be able to explore more of it. Obviously a place with a lot of history. Nice spot to go hiking or picture-taking.
author: Allison S.

description:
Ever since a BF took me here, back when I was in 8th grade, I've been coming here for the views and taking a walk. But since I moved to Las Vegas in the summer of 1991, of course the visits were less frequent. Rest assured, whenever I am in town, this is one of my must-visits. I also walk along Ocean Beach (my favorite beach in SF).

It could be dangerous if it was super foggy; one could slip down the steep hillside. You really need some good shoes here, no flip flops. It's cold and windy- bring a sweater or jacket depending on the time of day you visit. If you park in the parking lot above, you can use the steps to go down. If you go into the caves, know that is really dark. Pictures will only come out if you have the right flash setting. Beware, people (maybe homeless people, I don't know) leave some weird stuff in here. Check out Seal Rock- yup, that white is bird poop, years of bird poop. And if you walk on the ruins, be very careful. 

This used to be a huge enclosed bath house but the earthquake of 1906 destroyed it. The photographs were in the Cliff House, the former home of the Musee Mechanique.
author: Margret C.

description:
This is one of my most favorite places.

Its beautiful, its romantic, its history, its an adventure, its nature, its mystery and its unique.

The air smells of salt water and the waves crash up against the rocks as you hike and explore the ruins and surrounding caves.  You can explore a small cave next to the crumbled foundations which lets you see tide pools and underground water tunnels.

The ruins itself can be walked, bu be careful of the uneven surfaces and holes as to not trip and fall, especially onto the rocks or gross, stagnant water on either side.  Its a wonderful place for a date, I just love the lookout area above the ruins.  Just hold on to your date, cuddle and watch the ocean.  Take your camera and you're sure to get some beautiful captures.
author: Jen K.

description: A nice place on a sunny day. The actual baths are long gone but you can pretty much climb over the remaining structure and enjoy the beach and view of Seal Rocks. There's also a pretty cool tunnel that leads to the other side of the cliff. Don't expect to see too much or spend too much time here, but it's a worthwhile stop while exploring Ocean Beach, Cliff House, or Lands End.
author: Madhu P.

description: Discovered this on a morning jog along the great highway/beach. Great view of the ocean and the ruins. It leads into land end's trail. Awesome treat at the end of a jog
author: Angela L.

description: Sutra Baths is beautiful. Its defiantly worth blocking out a few hours to explore this spot and the places around it!
author: Moran G.

description:
I love visiting this historical landmark, the Sutro Baths.  As being a person who really is fascinated by history, this is truly one of my favorite places to visit.  Amazing that these ruins were once large swimming pools that in their heyday were a major draw for tourists who came to San Francisco. This place is full of history. 

Sadly, a suspicious fire in the 1960s burned down most of the building.  Some of the cement pools are still intact but have now full of marine life growing in them.  You can walk all throughout this area but it is somewhat dangerous. There is some vandalism that is evident on some of the ruins such as graffiti which is saddening to see. Anyhow, if you plan to go to see the Sutro Bath ruins be prepared to walk down a lot of stairs to see it.  It is good to be fit if you plan to do so.  

Overlooking the Sutro Baths is the Cliff House which also is rich in history.  It is apparently a great place to eat as well.  Also, near by where there are condominiums now, was where the beachfront amusement park, Playland at the Beach was once located that closed down in the 1970s.

Pros:
-a great place to visit if you love history and adventure
-the famous Cliff House overlooks the Sutro Baths
-great scenic view of SF Bay

Cons:
-if you are not fit, the stairs are a long way down to the ruins and can take its toll on you
-the ruins are exposed and if you are not steady on your feet this may not be a good place to go as you could fall into one of the existing pools I could imagine 
-not a safe place for children
-some vandalism is evident
author: Irene S.

description: One of the most beautiful spots in SF. You can spend hours here -- it's so serene, and when Karl the fog's not visiting, you have some of the most amazing views, and forget that you're in the city. You can walk down to the baths, sit on the ledges, walk into the cave, and see the waves crashing into the rocks. It is touristy, but not overwhelmingly so. It is by the water, so it can get windy. I am not sure there are historic baths like these anywhere else in the Bay Area. It's very accessible -- you can run to it (via Lands End trail/GG park, even Chrissie Field), drive to it (lots of free parking), or bus to it (38 Geary right there all the way from downtown).
author: Cynthia W.

description: If you're from out of town, avoid the piers and instead spend some time exploring here. It's always beautiful. Can be crowded at times. I heard they recently improved the parking. Once you're done with the baths take a drive across the golden gate and hit up the Marin headlands.
author: Nathan M.

description: My husband I came it for a hike and stayed to watch the sunset. Incredible but very busy- lots of people and lots of stairs! Bring water, sneakers and a camera. We also enjoyed the camera obscura- I think it was $3/person, cash only. Bathrooms are clean and there's a cafe inside. We rode the bus which worked out swimmingly. The Rangers are awesome- they helped me pick out a great book of local flora and fauna.
author: Katie B.

description: Nice to be over there for the ocean and cliff views but the baths themselves are nothing too much. Try to go on a clear day and catch the sunset.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I'm so glad I got to go here and see the beautiful sight! I'm surprised they still let you walk around the ruins, which most places they don't let you - I guess it's not too unsafe yet! There is something so beautiful about the force of nature-the fire that took the baths down and the powerful water crashing against the rocks. The history of the place is quite an interesting one too. Just staring out at the ocean while perched on those rocks takes you to another place.

There are so many places to explore just by the baths. There is a cave (very crowded but I went on the weekend) and a path that leads up to some trees and Sutro Heights Park. We didn't have a chance to explore there or Land's End since it was getting dark, but now I'm even more excited to go back!

We even got to see Sutro Sam, the river otter. I was talking to a local nature photographer who was there to photograph him and she said Sam is building a nest underneath the platform that juts out from the right if you are looking out at the ocean. Then he'll try to attract a female otter to come live with him! He also, unfortunately but naturally, eats the ducks. The photographer was also saying that there used to be a flock that lived there but he's eaten most of them. :(

I highly recommend going earlier or on a weekday if you can. It get's crowded and full of people during the weekends, but nonetheless it is a gem among the Golden Gate parks.
author: Catie T.

description:
The fog clear up, so actually went down to check out the old Sutro Baths remains..

It's interesting to see so many years ago's big swimming pool!  

I will have to add this to the list to take my out of town guests :)
author: Coco L.

description:
Raw wind. Raw ocean. Raw rocks. Raw moves. Tai chi among the Sutro Bath ruins. That is what I come here for. Some quiet time with rugged nature as it reclaims the cliffs. Although, due to the wind, waves and gull-cries, it's not quiet, so much as it is restful. 

The history of the Sutro Baths is quite interesting. According to Wiki,  "On March 14, 1896, the Sutro Baths were opened to the public as the world's largest indoor swimming pool establishment."


The Baths were innovative for their time (Industrial Age-Victorian Era) . For comparison's sake, Sutro Baths opened not long after Darwin's "Origin of the Species" was published and merely years after Jack the Ripper's murder spree ended. The Baths featured pools of different temperatures, as well as salt or freshwater bathing. It's a shame there is nothing like it these days.
author: Jane A.

description:
"Dad.  Dad.  DAD!  you're not watching!!"

When i was a kid my dad would take me to the beach with our dogs and we would make our way up to the Cliff House (when it was still cool with all the old amusement park games) and the Baths.  I was a total tomboy who liked to play in the sand, get dirty, climb trees, skin my knees and get back up, run around, and do daredevil cartwheels along the baths, getting as close to edge as possible without falling in.  This caused my dad to yell at me saying that if i fell in he was going to leave me there and that sharks would eat me.  Because apparently the baths have sharks in them.  Riiiiiight.  *raises eyebrow*

When i come back here now as an adult, as much as i would love to, i dont do my daredevil cartwheels for fear of falling into the green goop abyss.  Im accident prone, not stupid.  Im also not looking to grow a third eye any time soon.  Instead i like to walk and sit along the edge and stare out at the ocean while my hair gets all sexy messy from the salt water in the air.  I hope i get to take my offspring here one day.  

Ahhhhhh, SF landmarks, pure nostalgia.  Home is definitely where the heart is.
author: Juv C.

description:
New world ruins, SF's hommage to ancient Rome, I love it. Some interesting displays at the park station up top of what it used to be back in the day, and then free rein over the ruins below. It's pretty unfenced and untouched, so you can pretty much climb on whatever...some homeless guy has clearly discovered this (halfway up the hill you might find some sleeping bag in a little enclosed ruin. 

The 38 bus takes you right there, worth the trek.
author: Dan C.

description: Awesome place to see another side of SF that I didn't know existed. Read about it, it's pretty cool. Makes for some awesome photos. A must see!
author: Jennifer G.

description:
the ruins are interesting to see right by the ocean, the tunnel was cool as well
parking is really hard to find though because people can spend hours hiking from here
author: Peter W.

description:
I loooove the Sutro Baths. This is the best beach to visit at night that I've found - although, I'd recommend not going alone. Not only are there no signs posted prohibiting hanging out at night (which is unusual), but the Cliff House lights everything up with an eerie glow.

One of my favorite things to do in SF is to carefully make my way across the ruins to the left side, where there's a sandy area that overlooks the ocean and is the perfect spot for a picnic at sunset. Make sure to check out the cave...but it's super spooky at night.

The Lands End trails are right next to it, which is a big plus.
author: Jenice C.

description: Cool and really windy. Great exercise and awesome views. Nice visitors center.
author: Andrew K.

description:
If you're visiting San Francisco, you definitely should check out this place.  Don't limit yourself to just the golden gate bridge and alcatraz.

My boo brought me here after recommendation from her roomie.  Make sure you wear comfortable shoes because you'll walk all over the place and some surfaces you walk on are gonna be rough and full of gravel.  This is kinda off the beaten path, but it is a cool place to explore.  There is some amazing scenery here.  It can be really romantic here, so come here when it's close to sunset.    

You can walk down the road and have a cliche'd long walk on the beach too.  This place is amazing, but it's even more amazing when you're here with the one you love.
author: Richard D.

description:
I absolutely love this place and only recently found out about it (you'll have to excuse me since I was raised in the suburbs outside of SF). It is a moderate walk to get up and down, but worth the effort. The views are fantastic and on most days the area is fairly secluded with the exception of a handful of tourists and dog walkers.

I have also taken photos here on several occasions and it photographs beautifully, especially inside the cave. I recommend this spot to all my friends and family.
author: James D.

description: This is one of the spots I would recommend someone visiting San Francisco to go to. The cave is short but a unique site, and the view at the sutro baths is very pretty. You can walk around the ruin (don't fall in the water) and just chill on the wall by the waves :).
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
There is something eerily beautiful about the Sutro Baths. When there, you feel like you've been transported to another time.  The ruins don't look like they're only 100 years old. They might as well be ancient (nevermind that the ruins are of concrete and steel, not stone). Add that to a backdrop of endless ocean, and you have something almost majestic-looking.

Moving on to the facts: The best time to come here is *not* on the weekend, because the large crowd factor does take away from the experience a bit. I suggest coming right around twilight on a sunny day. 

You can walk among the ruins, so obviously, your shoes should be good ones, as there are large gaps and the surface is uneven. And lastly, there are little coves and caves around the ruins that are worth checking out, too. And I feel like a mom saying this, but use common sense when exploring, because high tide can cause you to get stuck. Anyway, the Baths are definitely worth a visit.
author: Sonia M.

description:
I went here because I am a photographer and was looking for interesting places to take pictures. The sutro baths are absolutely beautiful ruins that are directly on the edge of the coast and surrounded by cliffs, cypress trees, and offshore rocks which are home to lots of cormorants. I love nature photography so I was excited to also see a hawk, a great blue heron, and some ducks while I was at the baths. 
I went early in the morning while no one was there and it was still very overcast but then returned later in the day when the sun came out. The photos that I took when it was overcast are almost better because you are better able to see the suble colors of old bath tiled. 
This place is a real treasure tucked away in western SF. It's very close to Ocean Beach and one of the windmills of GG Park (to the south) and if you walk a bit North on the path, there are great views of the golden gate bridge.
author: Holly C.

description:
There's something altogether arresting about Sutro Baths. The views of the ocean are of course, gorgeous, and Fort Miley, The Legion of Honor, The Presidio, and numerous beaches are all relatively nearby. But as I see it, the real beauty of the site is the connection one can find to history and a long ago, much different world than the one we now live in. With a little imagination you can see what a bold and dramatic structure it must have been, challenging the elements as it faced out toward the Pacific. It's a shame that it didn't survive to today.

I like to come here and sit and stare off into the distance, thoughts drifting, taking in the view. Having the ruins of a once proud and daring monument to human will on the scenic outreaches of a beautiful city, at the precipice of the largest body of water in the world at your feet, it's easy to get lost in thought. Whether you're interested in its history or the natural beauty of the area, Sutro Baths is a place to come to connect with something larger than yourself.

Just remember to bring a jacket! And be careful while walking close to the water, because waves have been known to knock people in.
author: Don W.

description: It's places like the Sutro Baths which make you realize that San Francisco truly is the historic jewel of the Pacific Coast.  You can view them from both the Cliffhouse and the Lands End trail, and you can really imagine yourself back in the late 1800s and what that scene must have been like.  A real SF treat.
author: Mel G.

description: Beautiful! The Cliffhouse view is awesome. Well worth the climb up and down the hill to the beach. The old building structure is a cool sight to see as well.
author: Christina C.

description: Kind of cool to see the ruins of the old bath house. The main attraction, however, is the nice ocean views. A great jump off point, for a Land's End walk.
author: Michael S.

description: Great view, though keep in mind it's not much of a hike. It's more of a destination, and you can walk around and explore once you get here. Also it can get VERY windy and cold in this area.
author: Jenny J.

description: A lovely romantic spot below the cliffs in gloomy San Francisco is bound to make you take a deep breath and forget all your worries. Sutro Baths is a fantastic place for a stroll or even a strenuous hike. Just make sure to be careful when walking through the stoney pathways; you don't want to fall into an ancient bath!
author: Allison M.

description: OMG. This place is amazing. So much scenery to take in and such a great space to walk and wander for a couple hours. I'm surprised I've never heard of this place before from Bay natives but trust me this place is a "must visit." On a clear warm day, the view of the water off this place is beyond words. Even if you are not into hiking or nature, you can even appreciate the beauty of this place from the benches at the top by the parking lot.
author: Stephie D.

description:
I'm ashamed to admit that I have been living in SF for 11 years and it's only now that I find out what this really is.  

We used to have the largest indoor swimming pool in the world?  People who came to enjoy this facility rented their bathing suits and my co-worker said his grandma still has hers with Sutro Baths written across it.  So cool.  There's a picture of the bath's former glory outside Louis Restaurant's window, check it out.

I've been to the Cliff house where across it, up the hill, are the ruins of Adolph Sutro's residence.  Those castle like structure seen from anywhere in the great highway (which I have never notice before - geez what's wrong with me?).  Heard about Sutro heights?  

If you dig solitude or just admire great views and the sound of the ocean - this is a good spot.  Learn about SF history, it's rich!
author: Pam S.

description: Pretty awesome stuff. If you read the wiki you'll be amazed at what was here, and what remains. The ruins are fun to explore, but you got to be sure to watch your step!
author: Christophe C.

description:
I love this place.  Nice, free, tourist spot to bring people.  Great view of the Pacific Ocean.  It's a good walk if you're willing to go all the way down the trail but for people that can't walk well, you can just park and overlook if you want.
I love this place so much I think I'm taking my engagement photos here (one day).
author: Grace P.

description:
Who says you have to go to Greece or Rome to see cool ruins?  We have them right here in San Francisco, with our Sutro Baths.  Known to some (but not all), loved by many, a visit to the Sutro Baths is a truly unique experience.

As Ed U. mentions, they do a poor job of educating the public about the history of the baths (in fact, Wikepedia even mentions this - how embarrassing) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutro_Baths   So do yourself a favor and read a little about it before you go.  

Then just follow the path down (it's not too steep) and explore.  You can go up to a concrete walkway and get a glimpse of the GG Bridge, walk through a cave, or just wander around the ruins.  So beautiful, interesting, and fun!  The seals have returned to Seal Rock, and their cries can sound downright eerie as you navigate around the hills and crumbling structures.

The grounds are dog-friendly, but because there are no fences, your pup should be kept on a leash.

I think that people should be careful with kids here.  There are no guard rails and all sorts of opportunities to tumble downhill.  Also there is some broken glass from beer bottles - it's not terrible, but it's there.  Older kids should be fine, just watch the little ones.

And the wind...seriously strong.  Layer up and wear sunglasses if you are there during the day.  

OK, my camp counselor speech is over...just go, and enjoy!  Wonderful way to spend an hour or so viewing Seal Rock with the waves crashing against it.
author: Liz S.

description:
Beautiful spot to take in the sights, except on a super windy day. It was worse than a visit to the Pali Lookout on Oahu! The history of the building of the baths, the fire that destroyed it, the business deals that were made in there and of course some of the eerie stories that live on.
It was very family friendly, as the trails were easy to walk. Perfect place to chill out.
author: Lana H.

description: Pretty neato place.  Kinda weird and there were a lot of dead birds lying around.  Saw the river otter in the pool.  Pretty freaking cool.
author: David P.

description:
Awesome place! Lots of birds and greenery, with a little cave on the side. The ruins are really cool looking, but stinky. Come with sneakers or boots.

The downside for me is that it is so cloudy in this area--really hard to catch a sunset.
author: K W.

description: This place is amazing! I visited this place as a tourist (I live in LA) and I went just in time for the sunset. Not many people were around because it was superbowl sunday so I don't know if it's usually crowded or not. Bring your camera, bring a warm sweater, and enjoy!
author: Jason L.

description:
I wish I had a tour guide with me so they could have explained it all to me while I was there, It is okay though because I have wiki.

Amazing views, just be careful because anyone can fall off the cliff or fall in general and die.... :)
author: Eric A.

description:
A total escape within the city! 

I love this place! Anytime I want a bit of nature and fresh air Sutro Baths is always here for me! It is incredibly peaceful to sit on the rocks and watch the waves come in. It's always a great place to take tourists and locals a like. It's a historical landmark, but half of the  fun is climbing through the tunnel to catch the view on the other side! But beware you should be wearing decent shoes it gets a bit muddy!
author: Marissa P.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in all of San Francisco.  There are challenging climbs and hikes to be had (granted - the climbs are not "official" or monitored, so go at your own risk.)  It is steeped with history, mystery and romance.  The views are spectacular and there is nothing more amazing than standing on the overlook at sunset and watching that big ball of orange sink into the Pacific Ocean.

I make it a point to take everybody who visits me in SF there at least for a few moments - it is the best of the best of San Francisco.  Beautiful, rich with history and completely inspirational.

Check it out.
author: Kate R.

description:
LOVE the Sutro Baths. After you hump through the really fluffy sand under the tunnel to the rocks on the other side you literally get away from it all.

Climb up a little ways for the easy stuff, but go just a little further and things get all the better. Poke around the cliff side under the Cliff House restaurant. Just watch out for high tide.

definition
hump: to hike whilst carrying a lot of gear, although you might not have a lot of gear in this situation, you should have a beer or two on hand :)
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I've been to San Francisco a lot, but never had my adventures taken me towards Land's End before this summer.  And do I ever regret that!
This summer I'd challenged myself to do all things I'd never done before (be it mainstream touristy like Coit Tower or geeky-local like going to a yarn shop or two). And the Sutro Baths was at the top of my list.
Go on a weekday and you'll find a fair share of solitude. Walk around, photograph, watch your step(!), and imagine what it would have been like to go to this place. It's well worth the trip.
author: Leigh G.

description: Really cool historic spot. Although I was unprepared wearing my flip flops and the road down there can be pretty steep. There's even a sign that says to be careful because people have been swooped into the ocean and drowned... not very reassuring. But if you stand by the cliff, you can see a gorgeous view of the ocean and city.
author: Christine C.

description:
There is a chance that my uncle burned this place down the last and final time it burned down.  I am not sure what part he took in it or if the rumor is true, but my mom says it's possible.  My uncle killed himself, so i guess we'll never know.  The place was going to be torn down anyways, so I guess it didn't matter.

Anyways, it is a cool place to go and look at now.  It falls apart more and more every year.  It looked much different when I first saw it as a kid compared to how it looks now.  It is disintegrating fast.  Go take pics of it at sunset some day.

If you ever saw a photo of how it looked originally then you will be sad and wish it was still there.  What a shame that it is gone.  It used to be so royal when it was first opened.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Beautiful and slightly haunting. A shame that fires destroyed the original structure in the 60s.  

J and I visited on an incredibly windy day. I would've liked to walk around the rocks more, but it seriously felt like the wind could send me into the water (baths or ocean) at any moment. The baths themselves no longer seem to be a secret-- there were quite a few tourists wandering around the area. It ruined the magic of the site for me... hopefully I'll have the place to myself on a return trip.
author: Susanna W.

description: If you come here at night, you have an eerily beautiful scene around you, as well as the sound of waves crashing against the rocks around you. You can scale the actual ruins, or walk among the little caves tucked around the area. If you do happen to walk along the ruins, look down at the ocean below you-  the foam buildup makes it looks like you're engulfed in an ocean-sized latte.
author: Drew P.

description:
Holy cow!  They actually allow people in this place?  Broken, crumbling concrete, rusting rebar and bolts, open pools of water, and all with a stunning view of the ocean with GREAT waves.  These ruins are an adventure to wander through and just marvel at (bring your camera!)

Especially interesting is a cave in the adjoining cliff with incredible views of waves inside.  The acoustics and sound in that cave is. . .indescribable.  Head through to the other side and you get more big rocks and surf.

Just watch your step--the concrete can get slippery and falling in the water WON'T be fun.  With a little caution in some areas, a visit here will be a time to remember.
author: Matthew D.

description:
This is a must-see landmark in San Francisco, in my opinion.  It is located near Ocean Beach, the Cliff House, and Camera Obscura, all of which are worth seeing.

Wear good hiking shoes if you plan to trek around.  A camera would also be a good accessory.  There is one place where you can walk through a tunnel and come out on an isolated rocky beach where the waves crash.  Very nice.
author: Ryan W.

description: Nice area, great if you love taking pictures!
author: Andrea M.

description: Finally after wanting to come here forever we finally made it. The day was beautiful with bright blue skies. I loved the location. I wish it wasn't all tagged up with graffiti because the ruins are pretty interesting. Maybe I'm just an un-athletic fatty but the walk up & down that hill KILLED me. I'm glad we walked through the tunnel, too. A great view on the other side of the water & rocks. I didn't see the resident otter but maybe another time.
author: Katie R.

description: When I first saw the black and white photos a friend took of this place I fell in love. I needed to check out this historic place. Talking with a few other San Franciscans, I got the impression that there wasn't much left to see. But finally I did make the trek out here, before I had to leave the bay area, and it was entirely worth it. Luck would have it, it would be one of the most gorgeous sunny days (absolute rarity this summer!) along the coast. It is a magnificent place with remains that could only have been relics from an ancient splendor. This is the kind of place you sit and absorb and ponder what it was like in its former state. There's lots to imagine. Of course having a beautiful ocean sunset also helps and if the wind isn't too gusty, its fun to walk along the upper paths (that have all been nicely redone.) Of course the day isn't complete without a bite to eat the Cliff house.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Actually one of the more fascinating sites of San Francisco.
Illicits imagination as you attempt to recreate in your mind what the site was like formerly.
Makes for good outdoorsy activity that can be rewarded by either eating at the Cliff House or Lou's.
Parking is difficult to find along the road, but you can park at the beach at the base of the hill (the walk is deceptive here, it's very doable). Also, people of all ages can make the walk and explore the ruins/cave (it is not necessary to run around the edges of the actual ruins). Shoes are recommended.
My only gripe? A real lack of information anywhere on site about the Sutro Baths. Either that, or we couldn't find it. Go low tide, because the beach over here is just gorgeous.
author: Jan P.

description: Pretty overlook. When you walk down to it on the trail, you can actually go to a tunnel. My friend Ryan, who's a local, showed me this back in the day when we were kids :)
author: Angela L.

description:
What a great start to my day!

It's winter, but the weather was great! High tides today--GOOD THIING, because the waves were miraculous. The tunnel/cave was also more exciting. My fellow adventurers and I went through the tunnel to get to the other end. In the middle of the tunnel, there is an opening=ultimate splash zone. We didn't expect a splash, so we took our time to get across...avoiding the puddles to keep our suede boots clean. HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA....since we took so long trying to get passed the splash zone, we were attacked. I was a little before the splash zone when I heard WHOOOOOOOOOOOOOoooooooooooOOo and felt strong air coming our way..I turned around and RANNNNNNNNNNNNN...too late. I was soaked up to my waist. As for my one fellow adventurer...she just stood at the splash zone and was soaked from chest to toe. The other fellow adventurers just stared at us like WTH JUST HAPPENED? Since our boots were already ruined, and jeans already wet, we decided to just go through to the other side. It was pretty. On my way back I was very cautious. I made sure the waves weren't coming in...the other fellow adventurers took their time to get across....I think they were waiting for us at the splash zone, assuming there wouldn't be another big wave coming in. SHAAAAAA BANGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. My girl friend and I just stared and thought WTH, IT HAPPENED AGAIN. I GUESS THAT'S WHAT IT LOOKED LIKE WHEN THE WAVES ATTACKED US. Except one of my fellow adventurers had it bad, he got knocked over by the wave, got up immediately and exited the tunnel. He was soaked from head to toe. I mean knocked over as in I saw the wave, I saw him, I saw the wave and no him, I saw him, and I saw no wave.  Another fellow adventurer was also half soaked, like me, trying to escape the waves. After that, we didn't seem to see the waves attack anyone..the waves either hated us, or loved us and gave us a great experience.

We wanted to go buy I Heart SF tshirts and flipflops for the rest of the day, but we just tolerated wetness through lunch and 3 hours of Walt Disney Museum. Troopers--not. FYI, the tunnel isn't that long, go check it out for yourself!

There was a blocked no-go zone, but we went through anyways. We wanted to take pictures and get a better view of the waves&rocks. You could also see a part of the golden gate bridge if you go up the hill, opposite of the Cliff House. 

Yes. Fun place. Beautiful place. Only because we played with the waves, or errr the waves played with us.
author: Anna S.

description: Great place to enjoy the Pacific Ocean scenery here. Also it's unique that they have here what kind be described as "historical ruins" since what's here are "footprints" of the pools of the former public Sutro Baths. It (along with paintings seen today) stirs up the imagination of what it must be line when this building did exist and was in operatiion until the mid 1960's from a fire brought down the place.
author: H K.

description: It'd be so fun to play here when the waves are huge; the constant threat of being swept out to sea would be exciting.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Back in the 80s, Lowell had this insane modular system of scheduling.  Instead of periods, we had mods.  1 mod = 20 minutes and most classes were 2 mods long; do the math, 40 minutes (see how handy that Lowell education comes when doing basic math?)  By the time I reached my senior year, I was able to schedule myself for a 730 AM swim class, a couple classes then 4 mods for lunch and one last class--Ceramics--that ended at 220.

I made it to Ceramics 2 1/2 times that semester with a barely passing grade of a D+.

My friend and I spent the better part of lunch frequenting Ocean Beach and hanging out at Sutro Baths.  Two crazy girls with nothing better to do than to speed down Great Highway in an Oldsmobile Omega clunker blaring Bobby Brown's 'Every Little Step I Take.'  

Good times.
author: Joc V.

description:
Sutro Baths is beautiful.  I've been here many times although my check-ins don't show it.  There are ruins of the former bath house that you can walk on and explore.  Be very careful though because it is really a 'explore at your own risk' area.  Most of the ruins are ok to climb on but there is an area that is roped off for good reason (tides and undertows).  There is a tunnel that is supposedly haunted near the ruins if that sparks anyones interest.  There are newly constructed paths that lead through the Fort Miley area.  
I love walking around Sutro baths and taking photos because its a nostalgic place.  My first visit was 15 years ago when I was 8.


The nature there is beautiful and unique.
author: Jesse C.

description:
Sutro Baths...I did my AP Environmental Science field-study project here...I took one of my very first pictures of you using my new DSLR...you would be my friend if you were a person. 

On a warm sunny day with blue skies and a gentle breeze...this is probably one of the nicest places to spend the afternoon in San Francisco. You can see the waters glistening from the old bathhouse pools while listening to the waves as they crash onto the rocks nearby. Perfect place to escape and get away from the hustle and bustle of the city life. 

To its left is Cliff House and a grand view of Ocean Beach and the Pacific Ocean. The its right is the park with walking trails where you'll see a great view of the Golden Gate.

The one thing that kind of kills it (maybe I'm just picky) is that there are always a lot of people there on a nice day. I like places where it's peaceful and quiet with NO ONE THERE EXCEPT MYSELF, but I should stop complaining. 

But come here if you want to escape. Just escape life.
author: David W.

description:
The website does an excellent job of describing this place, so I won't over-do it. But, I will say that there's nothing quite like swimming pool ruins from the late 1800s. 

If you're brave enough to venture down into the tide's potentially very dangerous path, you can navigate your way between these old pools to see old wooden ladders and colorful lines that mark previous water levels. I can't imagine swimming in them (especially because it was absolutely freezing when I was there) but hey... I guess things were different back then. 

Make sure to go up the stairs to climb atop the adjacent cliffs... from here, there are unbelievably beautiful 180-degree views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the ocean. San Francisco is such a hauntingly gorgeous city.
author: Julie U.

description: This is by far my favorite place in San Francisco. The cliffs are a beauty. The hike down with the wind blowing and scent of the seas salt. Walking into the cave is a gem once you get to the end of cave and see the waves crashing onto rocks. I grew up in HI and falling in love with beaches can be a bit of a challenge since I was surrounded by the majestic ocean. This place...by far with it's history and stamina leave me breathless. Once you've managed to hike back up from the cliffs take the journey north of the path and you'll have an amazing view of the San Francisco Golden Gate bridge.
author: B M.

description: This was so pretty! I was here as a tourist but if I actually lived in the area, I can see myself bringing my dogs here everyday! Just so pretty!
author: KT E.

description:
I never manage to find myself in the Outer Richmond. It's relatively inaccessible and the area doesn't have much of a draw other than a cold ocean with too many riptides.

But this past weekend, I found myself in the Outer Richmond at Sutros Baths with an out of town friend. Neither of us had been to the area previously and we walked among the ruins while listening to the crashing sounds of the ocean in the caves. We escaped the hustle and bustle of the city and decided to be different people for a short amount of time. We ran away from everything else in our lives to dig our toes in the sand, let the churning water lap hungrily at our ankles and marvel and the destructive beauty of nature.

Overall, there's not much there. It's a pile of rocks with a trail that really is a lot more spectacular. However, it was nice to visit, to get away and find oneself at the edge of everything.
author: Stephanie H.

description: If there's a day in SF when the fog decides not to visit- this is a must do. Its a great place to do a leisurely walk. After a nice walk stop off at the cliff house for drinks.
author: Komal B.

description: If you're in to the history of San Francisco, the Sutro Baths and nearby Cliff House are a don't miss.  Before coming, check out the WikiPedia page http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutro_Baths and just imagine what this place was like 110 years ago in its heyday.  Also while in the area, be sure and stroll through Sutro Park overlooking Ocean Beach or walk the first 1/4th mile of the Land's End trail for a spectacular view of the bridge.
author: John H.

description: I was somewhat disappointed when I came here.  Yeah, there is some historical significance about the Sutro Baths, but it did not impress me much.  They do a great job warning people about the cliffs.  This place could be a great stair workout, if you are into plyometrics.
author: Carlene R.

description:
My bf and I finally ventured out to Sutro Baths today after talking about it for the past 3 weekends. As per usual SF fashion, it was cold and windy, but being residents, we knew what to expect and brought extra coats and hoodies. The views were excellent even though it was cloudy. I think my favorite part was the cave tunnel where you can hear the waves crashing. It reminded me of Disneyland a little bit, and when I heard someone behind me say "This is totally like Splash Mountain!", I knew I was right!

We also ventured just up the hill a little to the south and found the ruins of what was called The Parapet. It's a kind of lookout place that was also built by Adoloph Sutro, the same person who built the Baths.
author: Jenna H.

description: The history behind these ruins are a little interesting, but nothing more than that. These days it's nothing more than small walls of the what used to be Sutro Bath. Not one of my top 10 things to see in SF, but interesting enough to taking a look at if you happen to be in the area.
author: Mike P.

description:
This is usually the half-way point during my beach runs. I always enjoy stopping here to enjoy the nice fresh air. I can see why some people would find Sutro Baths creepy..I don't want to enter the cave, even in broad daylight. 

But..the ruins are a nice portal to San Francisco's past. It's a great place for quiet contemplation and solitary walks (during the daytime of course). Wandering around the ruins might also lead you to some neat photo ops of crumbling brick walls. Just make sure you don't fall into the water.
author: Liz L.

description:
We haven't visited the Sutro Baths area since they remodeled the dirt section and paved 2 parking lots. There's a staircase from the parking lot which leads you down to the remains of Sutro Baths and off to the right a tunnel which ends at the cliffs on the other side.  You can ascend further up to a huge platform area to admire the views and another staircase leads onto the coastal trail.

I was enthralled by a pair of raptors (looked like Peregrine falcons but could've been hawks) hunting against the background of the dimming blue-gray evening sky. They would hover against the wind up above like kites, flying tandem, juxtaposed or one above the other, searching for prey in the ground cover below.  Occassionally, they would dive slovly down and hover closer to the ground or fly behind us near the Cypress trees and then ascend upwards and hover over the costal plants again.

We decided to take a hike the next morning along the coastal trail and end near Eagle's Point. Parts of this trail was actually a railroad line that rich Mr. Sutro had built to bring people from the Downtown area to enjoy the baths.  He created a resort area until a landslide shut down the rail line permanently in 1925.  
We've hiked this trail before from the other end and it was our first time from the Land's End direction. The Coastal Conservancy, a group of volunteers have done a marvelous ongoing job of replanting California natives in the ground.  Little colored blue and yellow flags dot the hills showing where baby plants have been planted.  The trail is an easy walk and ample runners and walkers are on the trail.  

Bring binoculars to see items in the ocean waters (saw the Radisson Silver Sea cruise ship coming in).  As you near the Painted Rock, you can see fragments of a sunken ship in the water.  It's mostly covered by brown moss but the long rectangular shape is definitely not a rock.  A hummingbird hovered nearby a small flower and you can hear the caw cawing of the large black birds in the trees.  

We took another flight of wooden stairs up to the USS SF Memorial.  There's a fragment of the ship there, in memorial of the 107 marines who died during WW II and one of 2 rear admirals who have ever been killed during wartime.  The view of the GG Bridge to the distant right and the ocean is spectacular from this parking lot view.  I've been here before on a sunny, clear day.  It's breathtaking.  

Not much I can say about the Sutro Baths ruins. They sort of remind me of the Roman Baths in Bath, England, but worse.  Old photos in the Cliff House giftshop further down the hill gives you an idea how spacious, luxurious and decadent this place used to be.  The new Cliff House is home to 2 restaurants and quite pricey.  $11 for a bowl of homemade granola is an example of a breakfast item.  There was a crowd waiting for seating and willing to pay the price for an ocean view.  

It's a great way to spend a day outdoors and take in some nature, ocean breezes and to learn about a piece of our city's history.  The old Clift House and Playland are long gone now but you can be proud of what's in place and how it's been all fixed up.
author: Ry T.

description: I had no idea the Sutro Baths existed until I was scouring the interwebs for ideas of interesting places to visit in SF. I am always fascinated by ruins, so how could I not be slightly intrigued? I was trying to figure out where in my 3 days I would actually get to the far West side of the city, but was more than pleasantly surprised when a tour I booked for my first day took us directly to the baths! I got to climb down the steps a little over halfway to really get a feel for the place. Really pretty area! I would love to have gone all the way down, but we were only allotted so much time before we had to get back on the bus. I wouldn't mind going back again to poke around a little more thoroughly.
author: Renee E.

description:
I remember going to the Sutro Baths growing up in SF. This was my STOMPING ground!

A bit of adventure, every time I'm there, even 20 years later, I feel as if I was in the middle of Goonies or something. 

If you go for what it is---it's still beautiful. the view is amazing. If you read up on the history, it makes the trip even more worthwhile and impressive. 

Now go check it out!
author: Shy A.

description: I thought getting to the baths would be a hiking adventure but it wasn't. There's plenty of free parking which is magically delicious. The views before your descent are great and only get better once you arrive. There's lots of tall grass and ducks there. The ruins themselves are big and creepy. I didn't walk out on them cuz I'm a big chicken. I did however enjoy taking pictures of them. The cave was really neat to hang out in. Watching and hearing the water come in was kinda scary but nice. The area around the baths is gorgeous. Having a picnic amongst the creepy ruins would be a nice idea as long as you clean up :)
author: Laura L.

description: So enchanting! I didn't even know this place existed until I drove by on my way to the Cliff House. Beautiful place to stroll, take photos, and marvel at the scenery. I even saw a couple being photographed in wedding attire. Great date spot too.
author: Jenny T.

description:
God I love this place.  It's a favorite of mine to come down and walk around by myself. walk along the ruins of the baths, and look at all the different areas.  You can feel a little bit of always down here.

Lately i've been taking others with me, they love it too. Recently I took the BF's kids.  We went and saw photos of how the baths and pools used to look, and then walked around so they could see how they looked today. It was such a learning experience for them, and to see how their minds worked.  

Awesomeness.
author: Samanta V.

description: great hike, and fun to see the ruins of something so special. if you are looking for a nice hike then definitely take the stairs and go into the cave areas to feel the spray of the ocean on your face. To just catch a birds eye view of it then head over to the cliff house. There's a viewing area in the back.
author: Yennie N.

description: Sutro baths is my happy place. I have to stop here every time im in SF. It's an enchanting view of the pacific, especially at sunset.
author: A B.

description:
Come here for the views. Watch and listen for the sounds of the ocean crashing against the rocks. Walk into the cave and feel the vibrations of waves crashing through an opening.

Be careful, don't get swept away!

And bring a flashlight after dark!
author: Eric C.

description: Where Maude (in Harold and Maude) fell through the hole that has since been filled in.  This is where Harold flipped out against the "commie b*&^ard" which was played by Maude.  All this was to get him labeled as insane so he did not have to go to war.
author: Lesley R.

description: I biked here from golden gate park, it was a tough bike at the end, but if you aren't a set gear you will be golden. It isn't that fun walking your bike down and up and if i had a bike lock i would have utilized it here. Really beautiful place, it would be fun to have a small picnic and watch the sunset. walking down the hiking path as well is pretty fun
author: Barnabas L.

description:
A great place to hike and explore.  The views aren't the best, but there's a duck pond area and a few spots that would make for a nice romantic picnic spot.

It's never too crowded, and there are multiple paths and entry/exit points.  I ended up bushwhacking until I found the path up the hill to Louie's family restaurant.

There's a sketchy looking tunnel that I went halfway into.  I didn't make it to the other side because I can get a bit claustrophobic sometimes, but perhaps next time when I bring my flashlight and cheese knife, I'll give it a go.

Bring comfortable shoes suitable for the occasionally wet and muddy trail.
author: Justin C.

description:
I love this place! I used to come here all the time with my friends last summer. We would go inside the cave and get all freaked out because the waves made a loud sound when it crashes into the rocks.

I think it is pretty awesome that the remains of the bath house is still here! The waves still provide water for what is left of it. I never knew how interesting this place was before, but due to some further research and a talk that a Ranger lead, I have learned a lot more. 

Adolph Sutro is a very interesting man. I wished I lived during the time where the bath house was still here and Playland was still on Ocean Beach.

The only thing I hate about the walk down is that very steep hill!
author: Janet Z.

description:
Hands down my favorite SF landmark. 

We always bring family and friends who are visiting the Bay Area to Sutro Baths. We've been here at least 10 times and it still takes my breath away each time we come. I love walking down all the steps to the actual ruins and imagining what it was like 100 years ago. Being so close to the ocean makes me feel so calm. I love climbing and walking on all the rocks. The cave is also fun to explore. The abandoned railroad track at the end of it is so cool. 

Sutro Baths has so much history behind it. If you ever go, make sure to go to the Cliff House to use their restroom downstairs. They have a lot of old posters, photographs, & even ticket stubs that are worth checking out.
author: Connie W.

description:
Another view to see and place to explore.  My roomie told me to check this place out when the man of my dreams comes to visit.  And so I saved the date for that fateful day.  It was super windy when we went, so this place would be nice to go to over the summer.  Although, the wind blowing through my hair produced an added effect to the dramatic pictures we took together.

There's a little cave you can go through, tons of rocks and mini islands to walk around and explore, etc.  There's plenty of warning signs to be careful since people have drowned and died here, so keep it chill.  I wore my mini heeled sexy boots while venturing and was okay (plus it helped keep the water out), but it's better to wear some sneakers.  Keep it comfy!

On the other side there's multiple trails to follow or not follow.  Take in the forest and capture some sunset pictures.  Yes, this is definitely the place to be sappy and take pictures at sunset.  Nature being your backdrop, the wind rustling through your hair, holding hands with your honey, mmmm.  Could it get any better than this?  I suppose other yelp reviews would let me know if so ;)
author: Lili K.

description: Hard to imagine by looking at these ruins that Sutro Baths once boasted seven different pools,( one fresh water and six salt water), a museum, a concert hall which seated 8,000 and even an ice rink! It had 517 dressing rooms, elevators, promenades, and grand staircases. All for $1 million which, in 1886, was a lot of money. Thanks to Adolph Sutro, the baths became a reality although short-lived. It never did that well because of the cost to upkeep it and it gradually fell into disrepair until 1966, while they were in the middle of demolishing it, Sutro Baths burned down. Now it;s just a crumbling, Roman-like relic at the very end of the world.
author: michael s.

description: This place is pretty kewl, there's a tunnel where you can watch the tide pool come in and out and the adjacent parks/hiking trails offer beautiful views of the bay. If you're a photographer this must be a great place to hone your skills 'cause I see lots of people practicing here.
author: Jesse G.

description: The Sutro Bath ruins are fascinating to see. If you look at them from the road above, near the Cliff House, you can really get a sense of what they would have looked like in their prime. The gift shop at the Cliff House has pictures and history books on them if you want more information. You can hike down to really look at them and take the miles of hiking trails. The most unique thing to me about the Sutro Baths is looking at the freezing water, the rough waves, and the beautiful scenery and really admire someones awesome idea to put in indoor pools so that you could swim and enjoy the beauty of the location, without freezing your butt off.
author: Kari G.

description:
I love the sutro bath ruins, the ocean breeze makes me feel alive.

This is a great place to make your move.
author: Manny F.

description:
Great place to take kids, relatives, visitors or even for natives to explore SF. Very steep, short hike, definitely worth it. Especially on a nice day. 

My brother, sis in law, 2 nephews, and niece came into town Saturday and this was probably their favorite place we saw. The 6 year old had the best time climbing up the hills and through the caves. It felt like we had landed in sacred ancient roman ruins. 

Despite it being the biggest tourist month in SF there weren't a ton of people here. Try to come at high tide so you can see the waves crashing against the rocks and the ruins. Be sure to head into the Cliff House and check out the 'before' pics. Very cool. A must see.
author: Ali R.

description:
I may be the one Bay Area resident who has never visited, or even really known about the Sutro Baths, which makes me a little more than half retarded, but now that I've seen them, I want to travel back in time to actually experience them.

The ladies and I decided to treat ourselves to a day of touron goodness. A trip to Golden Gate Park, where we happily paddle boated around Stow Lake, eating sandwiches and saving turtles from the deadly clutches of the seagulls, a drive along the beach, where the "historian" of the group told us that the bushes along the shore are very popular place for some gay head...then off to the Cliff House for some R&R.

There was an hour wait to be seated for lunch at the Cliff House, so we put our name in and headed down to check out the Sutro Baths.

As two of my friends soldiered forward and started leaping around on the ruins, balancing like they've been secretly working as tight-rope walkers, my other friend and I acted like major idiots, practically laying down on the long cement wall for fear of being knocked into the water by the strong wind.

The actual space where the baths were located is so huge and surreal. It's insane that in addition to the pools, there was a theater, an Egyptian artifacts display and numerous eateries. I loved the painting displayed all over the Cliff House of men in swimming costumes hanging from those Olympic gymnast rings, or sliding down those large slides into the heated ocean water.

If you've never seen this phenomenon, make sure to head over and check it out on the next sunny day San Francisco sees.
author: Sammy S.

description: When I get shot down by yet another potential employer and my life turns to complete shit, I'm going to "accidentally" get swept into the waves at the Sutro Baths.  There are worse ways to go, right?
author: Alissa K.

description:
We wandered, and came upon a great foundation. The cement lines formed shapes within larger rectangles, mirrored and repeating. The tide washed over the walls, filling the areas with dark. We walked along the top, arms outstretched at our sides, feeling the blustery winds hit the cliffs alongside, hearing the crash of the waves, and the rays pushing away the mist. We mused, trekked into the nearby caves.

Shreds of the baths' history playing through our thoughts, the mystery of what came before us. That people visited to taste the salty spray and view the expanse of the relentless water. And soak, surrendering to the fog. And now we leash our dogs, and come tumbling down the hillside to walk amongst the relics of a languid era gone by.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
There really is something special about this place.  Upon first looks, you think you've stumbled onto ancient ruins.

There is SO MUCH history here.  I've read the entire Wikipedia page on it!

It's incredible to think about how huge the bath house that was once here used to be.  Bath house/theatre/museum!!!

Anyhow, the grounds are open for you to climb and explore, and it makes for a great photo subject.  Try to come when it isn't windy.

The rocks and ocean surrounding the ruins top off the entire experience.

A truly beautiful place, quiet and serene, especially if you want to get away from downtown!!!
author: Jess R.

description:
A crystal-clear, warm June afternoon brought me and Favorite Guy to the ruins. We found plenty of parking near Merrie Way. Did you know there was a ferris wheel there? (http://outsidelands.org/merrie-way.php). This is an ideal stop-off before a drive south on Highway 1.

It's hard to piece together how exactly the Baths were set up in its hey-day, based on the weather-beaten, fire-ravaged ruins that have been in roughly their current state here for the last 40 years. But there's a stairway here, a stairway there. Some remnants of a wrought-iron, pool ladder every now and then. A wide, open space that's still filled with water during high tide, now filled with sea gulls instead of fun-seeking swimmers. The skeletal structures had me trying to fit the puzzle pieces together, but part of the allure is the mystery of the now ghostly locale.

A nearby cave provides plenty of exploration opportunities. It reminded me of the last Harry Potter book, and I know you HP freaks know what I'm talking about. A rounded vista overlooking the ocean also offers a barely there view of the north tower of the Golden Gate Bridge, as well as the relaxation you might be looking for.
author: Tara R.

description:
The hole that Ruth Gordon fell into (see Harold and Maude) is no longer there, but you can still throw on a bonnet and petition for peace in the same spot if you'd like!  I've been obsessed with Harold and Maude for ages, and out of all of the Bay Area locations it was filmed at, the Sutro Baths is the best.

A jaunt to the Sutro Baths feels like one big flirt with danger.  There are so many ways I can see myself plunging to my death here!  This just adds to the thrill of spending an afternoon climbing over the ruins of this once grand bath house.  Nowadays it's all bath and no house, though in its prime I'm sure it would give Steamworks a run for its money.  Kidding.  I hope.

But really.  You're on the edge of the continent here.  You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Marin Headlands, and a hell of a lot of ocean.  Add to that some spectacular waves crashing against the rocks and it's almost more stimulus than my little brain can handle at once!
author: Eric E.

description:
A few years ago, my parents and I spent a gorgeous May afternoon at the Sutro Baths.  It was a week day, so we had the site to ourselves, except for a couple of locals with their dog . . .  and a motherfucking mama fox and her two baby foxes.  Mom was sunning on a grassy patch and the two babies wrestled, rolled around, tumbled down the hills, and were all around cute as shit. 

For realz nature abounds!

How magical is that? So magical, I'm gonna spell it 'Magyckal.' Everyday is a gift, dudes.
author: Chloe S.

description:
outstanding view by the ocean. there's also this cave on the side of the ruin and it makes you feel like you're in pirates of the caribbean movie because the sound the water makes when it hits the rocks inside the cave is very humbling.

will definitely come back here again when the weather is even nicer(went on a cloudy day randomly)
author: Joyce C.
