description: A beautiful spot to wander on a sunny afternoon. Grab yourself a cup of coffee, bring your camera and explore.
author: Hannah A.

description:
I can only imagine the roaring 20's in San Francisco...bootleggin' liquor & afternoons at Sutro Baths. I would have been rubbing shoulders with San Francisco elite, taking off my zoot suit & jumping in the pool with some lovely betties...after a day at the boardwalk hustlin' with my mobster cronies. 

Unfortunate reality makes it 2007, and I'm neither a mobster nor a bootlegger. Hell...I'm not even sure where to find a pool in San Francisco. And damn, I don't even own a zoot suit. 

My favorite part about the Sutro Bath ruins is the ajdacent tunnel/cave. If you can catch it at high tide, the water rushing up & down a smaller ajdacent tunnel makes one of the most amazing and peaceful sounds I have ever heard.

Great place for personal solace, or to bring a date with a bottle of wine & watch the sunset.

Seriously, though. It's all about high tide in that cave.
author: matt m.

description: The Sutro Baths are so pretty! Another one of my backyard wonders. This is absolutely the best spot in the city to come watch the sunset. Before the sun goes down you must hike down to the ruins and get a closer look. There's even a cave! I was a bit skeptical about the dark ominous cave at first, but once I saw a 5 year old child walk out of it not crying in fear I figured it was safe for me! Really kool spot! There are old train tracks at the end that I wish were not broken to bits. I SOOOO want to take a ride on the Sutro train along the shore! While you're waiting for a seat at Louis enjoy the baths and all it's destroyed beauty!
author: Casi C.

description:
When I went here I felt that it was either going to be really awesome or I would get stuck in a cave and would have to live off of hermit crabs and stuff growing on the rocks. Luckily it was really awesome. 

I went to Rome and saw the baths there, but our version isn't too shabby. 

The only downside of my day was me not figuring out when to get away from the tides, and ended up with socks minus climbing a top a rock.
author: Pearl R.

description:
You can park on the street near the cliff house or you can park in the parking lot across the street that is for Sutro Heights Park. Crossing the street is relatively safe since there is a crosswalk provided. 

I don't know where the main-main entrance to the Sutro baths area is, but I go via the trail that is to the left of the restaurant Louie's or Louis' (?) I forget. After you descend to the Sutro bath ruins, make sure you go to the cave, b/c that part is probably the coolest part of this area. 

As for the actual ruins itself, it was just AITE, probably worth going to once in your life, and that's about it. It'll probably be a little hard for wheelchair access since its kind of steep to get down there, so beware. What's left over of the ruins is cool, kind of scared to climb around it, because I don't feel like plunging to my death in that water that's been collecting, or having the waves crash on me and pull me to my other doom. 

There is also an outlook area at the very top. Nice view of the ocean. But I prefer the view from Land's End. Take note of that rock in the ocean with the hole that's in a shape of a HEART!!! (For the lovers out there.)

So when I heard about the cave area, I got all excited thinking that it was going to be huge and different, but its more like a cave-tunnel. Which was underwhelming, but I found it cooler than the ruins. The cave-tunnel, has some sand in it, it's pretty dark when you get to the middle of it, but there is light at both ends of the tunnel, so it should be ok. There are a whole bunch of jagged rocks and water at the end of the tunnel and it's roped off, I saw a dude trying to navigate to see if he could go beyond, but I don't think he had much luck, and it's pretty dangerous.  

This might not be in my top ten san Francisco landmarks, but def worth stopping by if you're going to the cliff house/ocean beach/seal rock. Well, it would have been nice to see the Sutro baths if it still was there.... Sounds like it would have been pretty cool.

you can read up on the history here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutro_Baths
author: Irene C.

description:
This may be a wildly unpopular stance, but what the hell: rebuild these!  Well, let me clarify: don't build a crappy, modern swimming pool.  Build a non-functioning replica of the original baths that acts as a museum (and not just of the baths--of all the kick-ass stuff from the Sutro glory days).

Don't get me wrong, I love ruins.  There's nothing like a ruined abbey in the Irish mist (especially when your ancestors are buried there).  But Sutro Baths does not have the cool "ruins" atmosphere.  Sure, the caves here are great and all, but the actual foundations that are now little more than a concrete pool...well, it simply doesn't do justice to the former grandeur of the place.  The baths aren't the only landmark with this problem, either; I don't think the average visitor (or resident, for that matter) really comprehends the magnitude of some of the city's lost wonders.  I mean, there was a railroad at Lands End!  How cool is that?  

Now maybe there's some museum elsewhere in the city that I've overlooked that covers this stuff, but if you ask me, the baths would be perfect, especially if the architecture of the place was a history lesson in and of itself.  I know, I know, it would make the Cliff House even more of a tourist draw, but still.
author: Wes M.

description:
How can you justify giving a historical landmark anything less than 5 stars? Yes it was crazy muddy. Yes at one point I thought I would plummet to my death... well not really. I'm being a little overdramatic - but I am REALLY clumsy and that hill is steep!

Ok, drama aside, I thought the Sutro Baths were fantastic. I didn't even know this was here in our wonderful San Francisco until we decided to hike around Cliff House to explore what was beyond. I'm positive my friends knew this was here... in fact they were full of the factoids. 

I felt like I was in a European country, hiking through forgotten trails, just, with lots of other people. Very pretty sights to see; it's also fun to imagine men and women in their Victorian Era bathing wear frolicking in what now are the muddy waters of what remains of the baths. Definitely worth checking out, and don't forget your camera (or iPhone)!
author: Tatiana J.

description: This place is amazing!  I felt at complete peace here - sun shining down, wind blowing, sounds of the ocean (& it wasn't crowded) - just perfect! Gorgeous view.  Great photo opportunities. Easy Parking. Highly Recommend!
author: Kat R.

description: This place is GORGEOUS! So many places to wander off and take photographs. Parking is free, and taking a look around is free. I love it.
author: Jay A.

description:
So Sutro Baths epitomizes the always-disappointed-when-you-actually-get-there vibe of so many things.  I love the story behind the Sutro Baths.  I've read it in a bunch of places, including the parking lot above the Baths themselves.  I also saw a documentary on KQED about the heyday of the Sutro Baths and the many iterations of the Cliff House.  (There used to be this weird castle there.)  But when you walk down to the Baths themselves, you can't really spend very much time here--unless you want to get really freaked out by the concept of taking a dip.

So I guess I would recommend the Sutro Baths to people into old stuff that's been abandoned and left to rot.  And it might be a good place to write a poem.  But beyond that, you're better off walking a little ways and finding the cave that goes through the nearby rocks.
author: John S.

description:
Not just worth 5 stars, also worth my 200th review.  One of my favorite memories ever is hanging out on the Palatine Hill in Rome after closing time but before security could find us to kick us out.  No other tourists--just three of us, some rocks, and a sunset.

Sutro Baths is basically the same thing except reinterpreted through the lens of San Francisco--exposed piping replaces aqueducts, crumbling fifty-year-old reinforced concrete replaces crumbling two-thousand-year old stones.  It's possibly the most bizarre set of ruins you'll ever see and it's 30 minutes out of downtown SF on the 38.  You owe it to yourself to visit.

Seriously, read these other reviews.  There's something poetic here in the decaying seagulls and the exposed piping, the beer bottles and graffiti and the obscenities carved into sandstone.  It's inspirational and it's very, very special.

I have to disagree with Manny F, though--unless the object of your desire lacks a sense of smell, the faint smell of poo mingling with the ocean breeze disqualifies Sutro Baths as a "great place to make your move."  Also, I don't know why people drink beer here, because if you fall in the water you're gonna need to get some shots.
author: Sam M.

description:
There was nothing poetic in how I took Anne to Sutro, right after she admitted feeling haunted by that last relationship. Anne said he could've been, the great love. 

I tend to think simply. I thought of Anne-- her tempers, taste in men, willingness to fall in love so many times-- as a last attempt at romance.  It made her emotional. 

Anne claims to admire my cool exterior. If she only knew my demons. 

At Sutro, the uneven ground put pressure on the ankles. Our wrists, knees, hips were tense and wobbly. My keys-- hitched to a clasp of my skirt-- made noise as we moved. 

I was overdressed for the outdoor walk. Anne isn't one to tease me for it.

Anne's ultimate dare, it felt like we were in the 5th grade again: she wanted me to go into the thicket we saw ahead, alone. 

It looked like tall standing trees, too closely together. We stood on a lane-- a dirt path that probably went through the trees and full of bobbie traps. 

That was the last I heard of Anne's old beau. 

The mood at Sutro was calm. Also it was late, dark. Sutro is a large pan of water, a hovel for leftover rain. 

"There's too many easy metaphors in life," I said. I was tired, put no effort in explaining.
"That sounds like a bunch of shit. Is this about your writing?" Anne asked.

We left, it was still cold. That air from the ocean.
author: Jenny T.

description:
The Sutro Baths are worth checking out. It's a nice little escape when you need a change in scenery, but it's not as beautiful as I expected it to be. 

I know this sounds really chicken of me, but when I'm exploring, i keep getting this small fear of accidentally falling into the water and oh gosh, it sure looks extremely dirty and green. It's kinda kool to look at but I don't wanna fall in nor stare at the water for too long. 

The history is pretty interesting! Check out a photograph of how the Sutro Baths looked like in the past! It's amazing! 

Also, this is a neat place to come to if you were to film a movie or something!
author: Bets Y.

description:
It's OK for what it is - the crumbling foundation of a once proud place and on a recent visit I realized that the Sutro Baths are such a metaphor for the City of San Francisco as it crumbles into an upscale sea of posh and privilege devoid of any grandeur or usefulness...

If you hate your kids please let them climb around out here - you can tell the authorities how much you loved the film Harold & Maude and how you think she was the pre-cougar template for inter-generational love.
author: Quartknee K.

description:
One of the most magical and haunted places in the city. Good at 2 in the morning, 2 in the afternoon, or right after dinner. Great with 5 friends, or your lover, or just you. Lovely and sparkling place to have a good romantic cry, with a view of (what seems like) the entire oceans of the earth at your fingertips. Plus you are only a couple blocks from cozy warmth and bites to eat and people-voices, at the famous old Cliff House.

The cliffside sprawl of cement at the end of the walk makes me think that a very nice dance party, or something, could happen out here. Just got to hook up a giant wireless P.A in the sky! The caves are beautiful, the ocean is beautiful, the fringe of San Francisco here is the perfectly cut border to the vast expanse that is God's own creation.

A great place to take a first-timer to the city.
author: Adrienne S.

description: I took five of my kids here last summer, ages 16 to 8.  I couldn't believe everyone is just free to roam around and climb on and over all those ruins.  I wonder how many people have fallen in the water?  Naturally my kids were in heaven, exploring the area.  We loved the cave, with the loud roaring of the water rushing in.  We definitely want to come back and hike further.  We never even made it very far, having too much fun.  I also found it fascinating to read about the history of the baths.  And plenty of free parking--how can you beat it?
author: Susanne B.

description: Beautiful and romantic place. I used to live not far from here. Walking here was a treat and a great way to escape the City. Ruins? The sea? Sky? Cliffs? What's not to love? The ruins are of an old bath house. Great hiking and gorgeous views of the North Bay as well as Seal Rocks. There is also a neat cave near the ruins which opens onto some picturesque rocks and more views of the sea. Just be careful when you are walking on the remains of the bathhouse, I imagine falling into the dark murky water would be scary/unsanitary and who knows what's down there!
author: Helena H.

description:
Great piece of SF history.  Beware of mosquitoes in the evening, though, as all the standing water makes for quite the breeding ground.
There are some really cool caves through the rock around the northern edges of the baths to explore that really make you wish you could have seen them back when the baths were functioning.  Looking at all the foundations around the rocky points makes great fodder for your imagination.  They also make for some great tidepools down by the water when the tide is low - plenty of little crabs and other ocean-side life.
Spectacular at sunset.
author: Don H.

description:
Both times i have been to Sutro Baths it has been late at night so i havent seen what they look like in the day .... but WOW ! Sat on the ledge watching the waves.... the moon bright and reflecting on the water and the stars shining gloriously ... how bloody beautiful! When im sat watching the sea ... maybe taking a mini climb through the caves to get to the other side .... it total awe and admiration of the furious sea below, crashing against the rocks ... i remember how beautiful this city is and how many wonderful places there are to go and just be. 

My only moan is that its so bloody far from where i live ...i have to do with fishermans wharf ..... Damn !
author: Amy W.

description:
Phenomenal spot! Definitely a place to take folks visiting from out of town to see an old piece of San Francisco history...you can then head over to the Cliff House for more views and a yummy bowl of soup, or continue on the Land's End Trail for some spectacular views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands.

The husband and I really enjoyed being able to walk around/climb up the various ruins of the baths and got some great photos out of the adventure. (I'm amazed that they let folks freely roam wherever they like, with the exception of certain perilous areas right where the ocean and the rocks meet.) But, you can get quite close to some of the rocks at the edge by the water, but tread with caution because the current is strong! Probably my favorite part was the cave to the side where you can watch the waves crashing inside. As my husband put it, "Places like this are what inspire places like Disneyland." In other words, this particular spot was just too perfect and so lovely - so cool to watch the tide! At the end of the cave, I noticed a piece of railroad track, which apparently is a relic from when the railroad used to run along the SF coast.

The Sutro Baths and the surrounding area are further proof that San Francisco is truly the most beautiful city in the U.S.!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Pretty awesome place to go and explore if you're into checking out ruins. Coming from the South Bay to reach this part of SF was a PITA since you have to drive so far local through SF, but the free parking kind of made up for it haha...

The cave off to the side was probably the best part. Ya it's not too long or deep, but it's kind of neat that you can see the waves crashing from underneath.

Excellent place for photos! Only challenge is that there's a good long set of stairs you need to take to get back up to the street and parking. *PHEW* just thinking about it makes me tired.
author: Stephen W.

description: I have this odd fascination with the Sutro Baths...not what it is now, but what it was in its heyday. I've studied the photographs and even a few videos of this massive indoor pool complex, and I still have a hard time picturing the original building by looking at the ruins. I grew up seeing these ruins, never knowing what they were. Now, knowing how it once was, revisiting the site itself was anticlimactic, only because I so desperately want to see and touch more. The ruins aren't much to see anymore, but the site is still worth visiting. There's a cave onsite that you can walk through. It rumbles as the waves of the Pacific Ocean crash onto its exterior. If ruins aren't your thing, Ocean Beach, Land's End, and other nature preserve sites are all within walking distance. Amazing views galore! I do suggest going off trail if you do explore the area, but be careful of the cliffs and drops. Read the signs, they're there for a reason.
author: Helen L.

description:
I have been here a bunch of times through out my life in San Francisco and Nothern California. Not only is it beautiful but so muhc fun to run around and climb on.

When I'm in places like this I turn into my 5th grade self again. The kid whos not afriad to get dirty and likes to climb on things. My girlfriend and I were all over this place. Climbing on pretty much anything we could and taking some interesting trails up and down the cliff side. 

Our other two friends were not as ballsy as we were so they chose to do the easier route of the stairs... me balls to the wall scaling the very steep dirt trail back up to the real world.

One word of advice... a thin shirt and light pants not exactly the way to dress when you go. Make sure you have good shoes and a warm cozy sweatshirt.
author: Nancy B.

description: Definitely a fascinating place to visit if you are in the city. Not sure I would go out of my way to specifically see Sutro Baths, but hopefully you get a chance to explore Ocean Beach and the Coastal Trail and wind up spending a moment or two here. As a history nerd I really enjoyed the eery, desolate air of the place and felt almost as if I could see a day at the baths prior to the fire, people running amuck in their one pieces and goggles. I recommend reading about its history before you go, it really made the sight that much more powerful and interesting. An excellent place to take photos (especially black and white) and creep around. There is a large cave where you can catch the waves crashing into the cliffs and if you are brave enough (and have good enough balance!) you can walk across the ruins. I recommend checking it out *if* you are in the area, otherwise there are way cooler things to *experience* in San Francisco.
author: Leigh W.

description:
Maybe it's the salty air that takes me back to the days when my dad would drag me to this place, and makes me feel like I'm eight years old again.

Year after year, I got a heavy dose of Cliff House/Sutro Bath history when my family and I would just randomly visit the cliff side. I guess that's what I get for being born in San Francisco...

If it weren't for the hoards of tourists, the Sutro Baths almost take you back to a time when there was virtually nothing in Ocean Beach except Playland, the Cliff House, and the baths, which are now in ruins. There is a certain peace that flows through your veins when you're exploring the funny little square baths where at one time people would lounge.
author: Catherine H.

description:
Great place to take photos
Great place to take a girl / guy (whatever you're into)
Great place to take your mind off your life

be careful around the standing water, It's probably pretty toxic.
author: Garrett C.

description:
I hope they never EVER tear this place down.  This is the kind of place that should be hidden away and for the public not to be educated about.  I love how people learn about this place, and its always a surprise.  I like the fact that most of the time there are no tourists here because its off the beaten path enough for peeps with fanny packs not to explore.  And the cave!  Water up and down with sometimes muddy tracks left.  

This place has always had a haunted mystique here like something strange happened here.  My dad tells me he watched it burn down 40 years ago on his bike and I can't help but think of the movie Stand By Me.
author: patrick o.

description:
There are thousands of reasons why I love San Francisco, and this is one of them.

This place is great.  You can take the 38 all the way to the end of the line and then it's just a short walk to the ruins.

You can climb around on the concrete foundations of the old bath house, you can watch the sunset up on the viewing platform, you can walk through this neat man-made tunnel / cave to get to some cliffs to climb around on...

Great place to kill time and look out at the ocean.
author: Mike S.

description:
This is one of the most interesting and photogenic public "parks" that I've ever visited. The hike down the hill is not appropriate for anyone with a physical limitiation (i.e., bad knees!). But, otherwise, this place is spectacular, even in crappy weather.

For more information, please read my Open Source Photo Guide to Sutro Baths that I wrote for the OSPG project last year: http://knol.google.com/k/andy-frazer/a-photographer-s-guide-to-sutro-baths/3spf5isjes9jl/1
author: Andy F.

description:
My favorite part of the SF coast, if only because there are so many places to explore. I recommend ignoring the safety ropes at the ends of the caves; as long as you're game, keep climbing! I've had really wonderful experiences that way -- but it does get a bit nerve-wracking when the tide starts coming in. 

The huge rocks in the water get more dynamic the more you climb around. Every angle is different and beautiful.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Such an incredible place for a budding photographer (me!)  Parking is easy to find, and you can just wander through the park for an entire afternoon.  We topped the evening off with a trip to the Cliff House for dinner and the sunset.

I highly recommend to anyone who wants to go somewhere off the beaten path in San Francisco.
author: Katherine A.

description: I can't believe this place used to actually be a bathhouse. Those must have been some pretty cold baths. There's really not much to see here, since the buildings themselves have largely been destroyed over the years. But the views nearby are awesome. Walk around the corner and you get some great views of the Golden Gate Bridge, and try coming here at sunset. Very nice. There's usually ample parking in the lot or along the streets nearby, and you can also come here to walk off that brunch you had at the Cliffhouse.
author: Saunders C.

description:
What used to be the Sutro Baths needs to be turned into a natural habitat. Those stagnate old pools need to be dismantled and the area cleaned up. It is an eyesore.

Sutro Park on the hillside over-looking the ocean needs to be better cared for. As does much of Golden Gate Park. 

San Francisco is not as fun and as beautiful as it used to be. People need to realize that all these attractions need better care and attention or they will fall apart and fade away.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Oh how I wish this place still stood. I see pictures of this place when it was operational and wish I could go back in time. It would have been so sweet.

However the ruins are just as fun to go explore in and its a great hike to do on a nice day. Note to self: it is quite steep in parts and to fully enjoy the ruins you must be able to jump and climb and have some balance. So if you aren't that stable on your feet you might want to enjoy this site from above through the telescopes. 

The cave down here is also spectacular. Something about a big, dark cave going through the cliff makes me feel like I'm a pirate. And I love pirates. Cool view inside (but very muddy) and coming out the otherside offers a great view of the ocean......but watch your step or you will be in the ocean.

Great scenery, good exercise, and free.
author: Josh J.

description: Be sure to check out the cave. Great place to take some photos. Quick 15 min stop will be good enough, then head over to take pics at the giant camera.
author: Tay T.

description:
Breathtakingly gorgeous! 

I LOVE ruins of old buildings and the like, so seeing this was a huge adventure for me. But besides that, the cave is so wonderful. You can walk through and hear the waves crashing around you, and even see a little cove where they wash up beneath you! Once you get to the other side, you're rewarded with a spectacular view of the rocks and water. 

I don't think Sutro Baths is something that everyone would necessarily be into... it's really best for either urban exploration junkies or nature lovers. I can see why this isn't a huge tourist trap or anything. But I adore the Sutro Baths and it means a lot to me. (It's also very significant for me due to my wedding proposal, but that's another story! ;) )

So if you love old relics or the ocean, I'd definitely recommend The Baths!
author: Angie B.

description:
One of the very first 'landmarks' I visited when I moved here in '93. It's beautiful here, you can really let your mind wander back tot he time when the baths were in tact and saw a lot of action.
Good spot to go alone for 'quiet reflection', but just as much fun to go at dusk for 'romance' or for an afternoon picnic. Just be careful if you have drunk friends with poor equilibrium, I have seen more than one friend take an accidental swim here!
author: Colleen B.

description:
Just imagine the art deco splendor that must have resonated from within the brilliance of these walls.  High ceilings and stylized doorways filled to the brim with one piece bathing suits and matching swim caps.  The Sutro Baths must have been quite a sight.

Everyday, as I jog up Point Lobos to El Camino Del Mar, I try to picture what they must have been like.  The area seems quaint and nicely untouched by time, so it's difficult to imagine that it was once a thriving social destination.  The ruins look as if transplanted from the Roman country side.  Like a piece of the classical world washed up somewhere along the coast of the Pacific.  Buried by the turf is a lifestyle long since abandoned, a way of life from another era only recalled by those too young to remember it and those too old to forget it.
author: Philip W.

description:
Are you serious? Salt water baths on the edge of the city that the residents used to enjoy? And now we get to walk all around them? Awesome.

Bonus points for the most freakish fog wave rolling in as we were leaving. Apparently this is where fog begins. Fortunately our 38 Geary outran it home.
author: Jason B.

description: A hidden gem in the city with breath taking views.  It is also the perfect spot to watch the sunset and to just enjoy the natural beauty of San Francisco.
author: Brian H.

description:
This is a great activity during the weekend especially when the weather is nice. You can climb all over the baths, walk through the ruins, hike through the trails, and hang out watching the waves crash on the rocks and just soak up the view.

Next to the baths there's also a cave with this really cool black sand and you can see the waves crash underneath. Take off your shoes for a really cool feeling on your feet!

If you come here for a date I'd recommend spending some time here exploring everything and then heading over to Ocean Beach to grab a drink at the Beach Chalet
author: Brianna H.

description:
How cool are ruins?

Four stars cool!  I love exploring this spot -- climbing in and out of the strange, ethereal concrete structures left behind from god knows what.  Strange depths of standing water, crashing waves, hills and paths stretching off into the distance.

Its a gorgeous place, I love it.  So worth visiting!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Ok, I have to admit that when I arrived at the ruins of the Sutro Baths I wasn't too impressed. It's basically some old chunks of concrete with water floating around in it. And this isn't just any water, it was more like a cesspool brimming with some of the most disgusting, foul smelling, bird shit filled water I have come across in quite a while. 

However, when I got down around over by the cliffs and I saw the huge waves majestically crashing and frothing around the rocks, I didn't even notice the bird shit water anymore and I just sat there thinking, "Damn that's awesome." 

I headed into the cave and I saw ocean spray coming out of the side of the cave. I walked over to the safety railing placed around the hole to keep the throngs of tourists from falling in, looked down as a wave crashed in and sprayed my face a salty mist. The sound and intensity of the crashing waves was magnified by the fact the the waves turned the cave into a natural drum and it made my ears pop with each crash. Once again I was thinking, "Damn that's awesome." 

Finally, the secret to the the Sutro Baths is to walk to the end of the cave, and when you approach the rope with the two signs, one with a little guy falling off a cliff and another with a little guy getting swept out to ocean, just keep walking right over the rope. Once over the rope, climb along the cliff and there is a nice little spot to sit, smoke, and check out the crashing waves away from all of the annoying tourists. Oh and if you do go over to my little sitting spot on the wrong side of the rope, please grab my white water bottle I left over there--thanks.
author: Pirate B.

description: Beautiful!
author: Jordan N.

description: So I never owuld have come here if it hadn't been for my bf at the time. It was a freezing cold winter evening, the sun was setting, and I only had a sweatshirt on. I decided to brave the cold, and soon forgot about it wandering around. The sunset was beautiful. The trees surrounding the baths are very eerie looking, very picturesque.
author: AL S.

description: yup 5 stars.... lots of good stuff here.... little noooks and creepy caves to explore... found this little bay just by following my expert nautical instincts.... or maybe i was just hung over and kept turning right but either way i found this cool old bathing pools that are  crumbling and falling apart from years of pounding surf salt water and time.... we pulled in the parking lot went on a lil hike and found some pretty cool places that you dont see all the time. definitely worth disregarding anything i wrote and taking a look for yourself ........ only thing is it would be nice if they picked up the rubbish lots a beer cans everywhere haha... but really if your visiting like us..... its much more fun than just going to the touristy places that just have little trinkits for sale..... and the trail isnt very far to get to the ponds ..... you can see them from the top of the trail.
author: Scott S.

description:
This place is a must see for those who haven't yet.

Not filled with tourists (at least when we went it was empty), the mystique transcends through the whole area.  The steps were a bit tricky going down (maybe because its closed to the public at night and that's when we went?).

And the caves were eerily quiet as the moon casted its shadows.

This is the place you want to take your date after a perfect evening together.
author: Rebecca Y.

description:
Coming here always makes me long for ye olde times of San Francisco.  Handlebar mustaches, one-piece swimming suits, spats and bowler caps.  Alas, all what's left are the ruins.  Still, it's a beautiful spot to visit on a clear day.

I hear the Cliff House restaurant is nice too, have yet to try it though.
author: Jonathan B.

description: A must see when in SF - not that the bath ruins itself is soo fantastic, but the area is incredible, and its the gateway to Lands End and many other trails. So pretty on a sunny day!!
author: Carol L.

description:
Simply the most awesome place in all of San Francisco.  I like simple things that can nevertheless transport awe.  The tunnel is very spooky at night.  I once saw about a dozen Frat Boys in underwear, blindfolded, with two other clothed Frats shining flashlights at them.  They told me I saw nothing.  Evidently not.

I once saw a ghost.

Harold & Maude was shot here.  It's easy to lose one's sense of reality here.  It's easy to gain a sense of phantasy.
author: herbert r.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in the city. I continue to be amazed that they actually have left the ruins open and allow people to walk on them - but I'm happy they do. We always bring out-of-towners here and it never fails to impress. There is something so unusual about having wild coastal ruins just a couple miles from the heart of the city. 

Love the cave and tunnel.
author: Sarcastic T.

description: One of my favorite historic locations in SF. You can walk around in the ruins of an giant bath house while the waves crash into the cliff walls nearby and the hike the coastal trail.
author: Matthew B.

description:
The Sutro Baths are a great little slice of forgotten San Francisco, and although as others have pointed out the ruins aren't exactly spectacular, there is something about the area that really appeals to me. It's definitely on my list of fun and different (and free!) things to show visitors to SF, and it can be a great place to hang around for an hour or two on a nice sunny afternoon.

It is pretty steep in some areas, so do be careful and take your time moving around the ruins. I would not much relish falling into that water, and there are plenty of old iron bars sticking out of various cement blocks. 

Of course, that is part of the fun, isn't it? Scurrying around on old cement pylons and daring your friends to see if they can jump across... I hope that isn't the way that some horror story begins. In fact, if there were to be a wacky monster movie for San Francisco, the Sutro Baths would probably make a good set for the scene where the heroine and her dashing hero go to discover the monster's hidden secret: it is the tortured soul of Adolph Sutro come back to stalk the living for having forsaken the old-timey Victorian bathing gowns of the Baths! Splendid.
author: Richard N.

description: My favorite tucked-away gem! I LOVE coming here on a sunny day or even a cool day! It's a great place to hike and explore, but my favorite part is going into the cave and climbing the rocks. unbelievable this used to be a bath house! The scenery is so surreal and afterwards, you can go to the Cliff House or another nearby restaurant overlooking the ocean. Believe it or not, I hiked all the way from this place to across the Golden Gate Bridge and back! I was dying of soreness the next day, but so worth it!
author: Lucky N.

description:
This is a beautiful place to do a little hiking, take some pictures, check out some historic ruins, or have a picnic.

The tunnel is supposedly haunted, as well, although I've never had any proof of this and don't know the history behind it.
author: Heidi G.

description: Be careful kiddies, it's dangerous down here.  There are holes in the cement, and slimy Black Lagoon creatures living in the pools.  The old pools are now supporting their own ecosystems.  My buddy suggested we bring sandwiches down here the other day, and we did...wow, the things that OTHER PEOPLE think up to do....it boggles the mind.  What a beautiful spot to eat a sandwich.
author: Randy F.

description: OMG! This place is amazing!! I am a paranormal investigator and my team and I went and checked it out!! wow.. Is all I can say!!! Its beautiful there yet spooky!! Great combo! Just be careful at night.. The water gets pretty high!!
author: Tammy G.

description:
Eh.  Food was OK.  Location and view was great, but not at night.

My husband and I went to dinner here for Dine About Town in January.  I wasn't impressed with their pre-fixe menu--very limited as if to say "you're too cheap to eat here if you're eating from this menu!"  But I did like their wine-selection menu to do with the 3 courses.  Staff was nice, but I still think the place is overrated.  

I would like to go back again during the day and see their regular men.
author: Jen N.

description:
a loooOoong time ago.. i forget the details.. but i think a bunch of my guy friends wanted to come here late at night.. and i was all dressed up (with 3inch heels).. and they still made me go down the trail!! i don't even know what i was thinking, i should have stayed in the car. by myself. late at night. a n y w a y s, i am just so glad i didn't twist my ankle or whatever.. but i did scuff up my heels pretty bad =( .. definitely a moment ill remember forever!

oh btw... its beautiful in the daytime.. the tunnel is a bit scary.. i could never do it alone.. but once ur on the other side its amazing! climb the rocks and just chill on the other end! don't try to climb over when its high-tide or you'll be swept away! me being courageous (or stupid) at that time followed my friends and made it across when the tides were pounding the rocks like crazy.. but hey! i made it to the other side and back without getting wet or hurting myself.. i didnt wear heels this time either!!
author: JUDY L.

description: A gorgeous vestige of our past in the city that has melted away with neglect and disrepair.  It is a beautiful spot, and you can never go wrong.  Frankly, I am so excited for the GGNRA's plan for this place, and cannot wait to see if they can possibly restore it to its original beauty.  Yay!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Saturday afternoon.  My sister and girlfriend are in town from LA, and their friend Zach who lives in SF wants to play.  We go eat, and then head over to the Sutro Baths.  He gives us an option.  Do we want to climb on rocks or run through trees?  We choose rocks.  Now had I known what was in store for me i might not have put on my Chucks when deciding to wear sneakers.

The Sutro Baths are a great spot for visitors.  You can read about the history, and check out what it used to look like before it got destroyed.  You can also opt to take a more adventurous route and explore the tunnels and rocks.  That's what we did.  

We walked through the tunnel, and like i said, saw the rocks, and then decided to see how far we could go on these rocks.  Keep in mind its been pissing rain all day, and everything is a bit wet...and Chucks have NO traction.  But I'm no sissy so i followed the crowd.  Over rocks, climbing rocks, sliding down rocks, using my hands to find grip in the rock to pull myself up, finding cracks to put my feet to lower my self, etc...it was quite the workout.  It was beautiful.  The ocean to my left, a cliff to my right i just assumed that we would have to come back the way we came to get to the car.  I was wrong.  Further along there is this cliff like hill that wouldn't be terribly hard to get up if it were dry.  Wet however was another story.  I ended up with dirt in my nails holding on to the dirt and rock for dear life, and after a few foot slips, thought i wouldn't make it.  But being in the back of the pack, i didn't want to get forgotten about, so i pushed on and made it up. I  mean, what would my sister tell my mother?  A path back through the trees lay ahead, and in the distance was our car. In retrospect, it was awesome, at the time i though i might die, and the moral of the story is....next time, i wear shoes with traction.  

Be careful, don't necessarily do what I did, but make sure you enjoy the nature out there for sure.  Worth the drive.  Get some food at the Park Chalet or the Cliff House and make a day of it.
author: Lauren F.

description:
when i was a freshman at uc berkeley, i smoked a lot of weed. 

& i mean A LOT & ALL THE TIME. mostly because i didn't have a job, and every time i don't have a job, i revert to super slackertime behavior. which basically, obviously, revolves around the grass.

sometimes my new friends & i would get it into our stoned little heads that we should go to san francisco and explore. 

i distinctly remember the night we 'discovered' the sutro baths. we parked along point lobos (not in either of the convenient parking lots) and proceeded to climb down the hill, oblivious to the convenient trails leading down the hill. we found the cave, walked through, scared, obviously, out of our brains, and were SO EXCITED YOU COOULDN'T BELIEVE IT. i mean, this was obviously the most amazing place ever! & it was all ours, for we had discovered it in the middle of the night! and no one else was there! all ours!

sometime later we realized that we were far from the only people who knew about these baths, but they never lost their appeal. that entire freshman year we probably went back several times a month, to smoke, sit, and explore.

going back makes me miss being younger, and makes me miss being unemployed.
author: Irene S.

description: beautiful concrete ruins, like a local Parthenon, bathed in light, birds, and sea. Can see Seal Rock from here. there's also a cave to walk through, and you're right next to the Land's End trails which wrap around the coastal cliffs towards Golden Gate, offering precious views. Definitely a spot to experience.
author: Nicky T.

description: Cool.  Fun hills and ruins to scamper over.  Looks like the Park Service is starting to restrict access to more and more areas, though.  I especially wish that the narrow parapet down from the promenade (?) area (where the sky tram docked, above the baths) would be rebuilt, so that it would be safe to go back down there.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I toiled and troubled for quite a while as to what should be my inaugural yelp. Then I remembered that it should really be my absolute favoritist spot in the city! There is a peace and a zen and a romance about this space that can't be measured. If you ever need a space to clear your brain and reboot your heart, this is totally the space.
author: Stephen S.

description: A fantastic place to bring out of towners.  Walk down the steps and walk through the little cave.  Explore the remains of what used to be grand pools.  Or jump around on the 'bouncy bushes'.  Or take a bottle of wine and sit and howl at the moon. There is a sense of magic here that is something you should experience at least once.
author: jen n.

description: Simply beautiful. Every visitor to San Francisco ought to visit Sutro Baths. As a resident, I like to go out here every 2-3 weeks and just enjoy the landscape.
author: Darrien A.

description: Such a wonderful, unpopulated area in the city.  If you go out on the little ledge that's blocked off, down the stairs, and onto the lookout point, there is an even better view of the northeast bay (almost to the GG Bridge), and the waves crashing onto the lower baths.
author: Darian H.

description: Amazing view, total adventure, great place for a first kiss or a riviting game of hide and go seek.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
so you know how there are places which you find both romantic and petrifying at the same time?.. in the i love the view of the ocean while smelling homeless people kind of way... 
  well this place is an absolute childhood landmark of mine. discovered in the early 1990's while visiting the famous Clifhouse with mom and dad, i couldn't NOT climb all over the ruins...so we trekked down the windy path and i climbed every inch of the ruins until i resembled the mud monster.
  on the romantic side of things, the rocks on the other side of the tunnel are really fun to climb around on, and eventually settle in and think. i find the thinking part romantic, not the settling in.... just to make that clear :)
  love this place. i try to come here at least a few times a year, and take all the tourists i can get my hands on!!!
author: Helen N.

description: Absolutely GORGEOUS.  We went a few days ago, around dusk, with the sun shining and pelicans flying back and forth and ducks (ducks!) paddling around in the ruins.  Based on what the area looks like now, I can't even imagine what the baths looked like, even seeing the old photos and renderings.  It's a great place to just wander around or to just sit and take in the scenery.  Make sure to wear shoes with good tread--the path down gets pretty steep and can be a bit treacherous.
author: diana s.

description: This place creeps me out, I mean that in a cool way believe it or not. Even when I go here in bright ass daylight I feel this intense psycho energy ,some voodoo spirit shit. It's a nice little hike down and you get a great view of the roaring ocean.cute little birds ,and odd old leftover structures and caves. Theres this like buildinghutty type deal in the middle and I swear there is someone sleeping in it, or dead bodies piled up that gave me shivers down my spine when I peered into the small window.
author: Lauren V.

description: A pretty cool place to go for a little hike if you're feeling outdoor-sy. There's a restaurant right by where you start to walk down that has a drawing of what the inside of Sutro's Bath used to look like. If you follow the path that leads up to the top of the hill it goes all the way around the coast to a beautiful view of Baker Beach and then leads up to the Legion of Honor.
author: Christina D.

description:
You can't beat the price!

One of my favorite ruins of California, be sure to walk into the cave during high tide.
author: Tone M.

description:
Spectacular views at our very own modern ruins! Early summers are notoriously foggy. Bring something warm to wear and be prepared to spend 20 minutes or two hours.

For photos and more:
http://locomotoring.net/2009/05/25/the-very-edge-of-san-francisco/

Nearby Cliff House is another SFO oldie. The SF Walking Tour guides have regular walks on this site. As usual, they are wonderful to walk with.
author: Mishti D.

description: I must have looked crazy, but on a very rainy Monday I went to Sutros Baths (It was slightly drizzling at the time), walked down the hill, rounded the corner, found a rock and sat down with my Subway heart healthy turkey meal (Lays chips not heart healthy but  necessary).  As I settled in, I watched the waves crash on the rocks, wondering how long it took for the waters to form the cliff.  Then it started raining harder.  People started passing by on their way back to their cars.  But I stayed.  The scenery was just too beautiful and I was just too content having lunch in the middle of a rainstorm.  It was a good Monday.
author: Sonic D.

description: A relic of by-gone era when a bathhouse was a family-friendly venue.  It's pretty cool use your imagination to figure out what went where and to marvel at how impressive the water pumping and heating system was in its heyday.
author: Rick E.

description: I love this place.  It's on my tour I give to out of towners.  It's got history, its got eerie decay, it's got spectacular views, it's got wildlife and cool plants, and it has a tunnel.  As much as I'd like to see a new version of what was, I'd hate to see this place go.
author: Nessie V.

description: It's a neat spot but it's too bad there's not much left of the old places anymore.  It's worth tracking down some images of what used to be there.  It was really pretty amazing.  It's still an interesting place to go and explore and walk around.  Some nice trails in the area too with pretty amazing views and scenery.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: A great place to visit to see remains of the past and to enjoy parts of nature at it's best with the ocean and cliffs. Back in the day as a teen, my buddies and I use to hike and goof off around that area a lot because there's always something to do or find there. One time we started throwing small rocks off the high cliff at incoming friends and one of my friend got hit knocked out for a few min. (he was fine by the way) What can I say we were in High School and stupid.
author: David M.

description: This is a cool spot to check out.  Especially after looking at the Cliff House gift shop where they carry books of the old Sutro Baths.  Sooooooooo cool!  The remnants are sparce but its a cool place to sit with your mate and chat, listen to the waves, watch the birds and have a smoke...
author: Suzanne L.

description: I recommend walking from The Golden Gate Park to the Golden Gate Bridge following the coast. It's no more than 2 miles, a bit hilly. You will walk past what is left of the Sutto Baths (built by millionaire Adolph Sutto) and the Cliff house which resisted the 1906 earthquake only to burn the year after and you will have a unique approach to the Golden Gate bridge. Along the way signs will remind you that this is a tsunami area and that there are coyotes crossing.
author: CasimirVessel

description: I like to go there to watch the sunsets and feel the cool ocean breeze, it's so refreshing, sometimes I sit in my car and eat my dinner and look at the ocean.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: I can't believe I never discovered this place 'till now. The baths are  supposedly old ruins, but I didn't really appreciate them all that much. However, what really impressed me was the location. When the tide is low, you can walk along the ruins to the beach. The view of waves rolling onto the rocks is amazing. Come at around sunset, and you'll get to enjoy one of the most beautiful sunsets. Do beware of the waves, however. They can be mean!
author: Barn M.

description: i am the up and coming queen of the cheap thrill! this is most definitely what i would call a cheap thrill. i spent a few hours just walking about near the water, climbing all over the ruins and taking lots of pictures! this is the perfect cheap thrill date spot too! take your person and sit right on the edge and watch the waves crash... oh heart! (gag)
author: Kristin Y.

description: One of the world's landmarks I really wish would be re-built.  I would have loved to seen the facilities.  Looked awesome!
author: James B.

description: anytime i see and read the history of the old city it's amazing.
author: Pickle R.

description: VERY cool!  The cave is a little spooky when the tide is full and rough and definitely don't go close to the sea when the tide is rough but the pictures you can get from this place are amazing!
author: Phil M.

description: I expected it to be a little bit bigger, but this place is awesome. The view of the ocean is gorgeous and mesmerizing, especially on a foggy day. It can even get creepy, in a nice way. It would be pretty cool to see this place restored, but I also like the feeling of ruins. It's a relaxing place to go and an impressive place to take visiting friends and family, but there's not really all that much to do there if you don't appreciate a view.
author: R D.

description: I went on a hike last week and really enjoyed a nice walk. You can see the golden gate birdge and the little cave is awesome. I never even knew it was there before.
author: Erica K.

description: beautiful views especially for those who are tourists this is a must see spot.  i love watching the sunset on ocean beach and this little piece of history adds to the romanticism of it all.
author: Christy B.
